What can i say, only a masterpiece, amazing story. I didn't play original Mafia, the only game from Mafia trilogy that i actually played is the Mafia II, long time ago. When i saw they made a reboot I coudn't resist, sure i buy the game on sale and didn't know what to expect but darn it, it is amazing game. Sure it has some of the problem like linear gameplay which doesn't really give you possibility of chosing how you want to end game. It would be nice if the gameplay is more fluid, open world like and that you have options, instead you must go by the script. 

Story is what is the best selling point of this game, at least to me it is well done, voice actors did a splendid job, and you had feeling like you are there, like it is real. Combat system is little clunky but still nicely done, it has realism, you dont need to spend entire clip by shoting your foe to head to die, one hit in head kill enemy. Driving, many similar games have big problems with driving, and they nailed it. You can feel the car and it is little bit harder then in GTA but its darn more realistic especially for cars from 1920-1930 era. You cannot expect fast acceleration on them but they act as they should, especially when there is rain. Overall fantastic game. It should be longer, more missions, side missions but it is okay as it is. I hope one day that if Mafia 4 is done, it will be done properly but still i am glad i played it. Do i recommend Mafia: Definitive Edition. YES!! If you play original, you will not be dissapointed by reboot version. If you don't want to buy it at full price, buy at sale and try, it is great. It lack in some areas but still, it is great.

Mafia: Definitive Edition takes players on a riveting journey through the seedy underbelly of 1930s Lost Heaven, offering a stunning reimagining of the classic 2002 title. Hangar 13 has masterfully breathed new life into the Mafia franchise, creating a visually stunning and emotionally charged experience that captivates both longtime fans and newcomers alike. The first thing that strikes players is the jaw-dropping visual overhaul. The meticulously recreated city of Lost Heaven is a testament to the developers' dedication to authenticity. From the smoky jazz clubs to the rain-soaked streets, every detail exudes the atmosphere of the Prohibition era. The character models are exceptionally well-crafted, and the facial animations convey a level of emotion that draws players into the narrative with unprecedented immersion. The narrative, while faithful to the original, has been expanded and enhanced to provide a deeper understanding of the characters and their motivations. Tommy Angelo's evolution from a cab driver to a reluctant member of the Salieri crime family is portrayed with nuance and authenticity. The voice acting is top-notch, with the cast delivering compelling performances that elevate the story to cinematic heights.

The gameplay has also undergone a significant transformation. While the core mechanics maintain the essence of the original, the controls have been modernized to provide a smoother and more responsive experience. Gunplay feels satisfying, and the cover system adds a layer of strategy to the intense shootouts that punctuate the narrative. Driving, a pivotal aspect of the Mafia series, has been revamped, offering a more realistic and enjoyable experience with vintage cars that handle distinctively. One of the standout features of Mafia: Definitive Edition is its attention to detail in recreating the era's soundtrack. The soulful jazz tunes and orchestral pieces complement the narrative beautifully, immersing players in the ambiance of the 1930s. The combination of stellar sound design and a meticulously crafted soundtrack enhances the emotional impact of key moments throughout the game. While Mafia: Definitive Edition pays homage to its predecessor, it is not without its flaws. Some may find the pacing a bit slow at times, particularly in the early stages of the game. Additionally, the open-world elements are limited compared to contemporary sandbox games, but this is a deliberate choice to maintain the focused narrative experience.

In conclusion, Mafia: Definitive Edition is a triumph, successfully modernizing a classic while preserving the essence that made the original so beloved. It stands as a testament to the potential of remakes when handled with care and respect for the source material. Whether you're a veteran of the original or a newcomer to the world of organized crime, Mafia: Definitive Edition is a must-play for its compelling narrative, stunning visuals, and nostalgic charm.

It's practically a rage game.

The story is flawless, nothing wrong with it. However, if you want to play to enjoy the story, i suggest you to play it on normal difficulty. I myself never play it in normal, only in hard and classic cuz I seek the challenges and thrill presented by Mafia II (classic), which I played long before this game was released. Sadly,  i don't got the same challenge and thrill from this game,.

The shooting mechanics are solid, although not as good as Mafia II. Unfortunately, this aspect is hindered by minimal feedback system: enemies don't get knocked back when hit and can still shoot the player. Thus, players must truly understand enemy movement patterns to shoot them without losing hp. If the player shoots other than at the head, enemies continue to shoot as if nothing happened. This is exacerbated by some enemies aggressively advancing towards the player's hiding spot, especially on hard difficulty—they are unstoppable!

The game features a fast-paced action element. However, the character animation of Tommy (the main character) is exceptionally slow, making him vulnerable to enemy attacks. As an example, it takes about 4 to 6 seconds for the player to get into and start the car's engine before being able to drive. It really suck, especially in situations where the player surrounded by the police, like in the "Election Campaign" chapter.

Melee combat is utterly unsatisfying; players only need to blindly press the "Q" button (if playing with a keyboard) until the enemy falls. If the enemy attacks, the player cannot cancel their attack, and the only response is to press the counter button.

The fuel system is poorly executed. The game NEVER tell the player about it and gas station legend in map is hard to notice. When your car ran out of gas, you have to take it to gas station to make it moving properly, otherwise it will stay like that. However, since the game never tells you about fuel system, you will think that there is a bug that makes your car broke, at least that what happened to me, it's give me a hard time till i check the community tab.

Above all, the worst aspect of the game is its level design. Despite its Mafia-style shooting, the game heavily incorporates out-of-place racing missions. However, the real issue is not the inclusion of racing segments, which are common in games like GTA, but rather the extreme difficulty and lack of enjoyment in these races.

In the Fair Play mission, especially on the classic level, players are not allowed to crash or fall behind because the two leading racers are truly unstoppable. This makes completing Fair Play nearly impossible.

In a side mission to obtain the mutagen car, players must follow a series of checkpoints in a rally. However, the checkpoint scope is very small, and some placements are misleading (the next checkpoint located behind the one just reached). Additionally, traffic in the game is also problematic. When players are required to obey traffic rules to avoid police attention, cars on the road always disrupt this, often appearing suddenly in the middle of intersections when the player is moving at high speeds.
First time playing this and was not disappointed!

[h1] Mafia: Definitive Edition [/h1]

Even though I was originally skeptical because I didn't know how the whole game would turn out... It was mainly because Mafia contained a certain moral message... A significant part of it has indeed been removed in the Definitive Edition, but it's not that catastrophic. It's probably not fair to compare the original game, created by Mr. Vávra, with today's remake, which at least has iconic Czech dabing. Although it's a bit strange to hear the same characters, but 20 years older.

[h2] Story [/h2]

I think everyone knows this story completely. The main protagonist Thomas Angelo meets Detective Norman, where he confides in him that he needs help getting his family out of the city and getting them a new identity due to events from the past days. So, Thomas begins to recount his story to Norman as a former member of the Salieri family.

In 1932, taxi driver Thomas Angelo is surprised by two mobsters, namely Paulie and Sam, as they are both chased by other mobsters from the Morello family. Sam points a gun at Tom, saying they both need to disappear quickly. This inadvertently involves Tom in a gang shootout.
After shaking off the mobsters, they go to Salieri's bar. Tom receives compensation from Mr. Salieri in the form of an envelope full of money with a message that if he needs a job for decent money, good guys like him are always welcome... And thus begins the whole story of Thomas Angelo. The original story is more or less identical, with a few deviations.

[h2] Ratings [/h2]

Ignoring certain missing things from the original game, it's an absolutely captivating game. A big plus for me is the better story of Sarah, which in the original game was quite tragic. I was also pleasantly surprised by the classic difficulty level, which I enjoyed, as well as the realistic car and motorcycle driving model.

[h3] Graphics: 10/10 [/h3]
[h3] Story: 9/10 [/h3]
[h3] Gameplay: 10/10 [/h3]
[h3] Overall Rating: 9.5/10 [/h3]

[h1] Mafia: Definitivní edice [/h1]

I když jsem původně byl skeptický, protože jsem nevěděl, jak celá hra dopadne... Bylo to především kvůli tomu, že Mafia obsahovala určité morální poselství... Značná část z něj sice byla odstraněna v Definitivní edici, ale není to tak katastrofální. Je asi neobjektivní srovnávat původní hru, kterou vytvořil pan Vávra, s dnešním remakem, který má alespoň ikonický český dabing. Přestože je trochu zvláštní slyšet ty samé postavy, ale o 20 let starší.

[h2] Příběh [/h2]

Myslím, že tento příběh zná úplně každý. Hlavní protagonista Thomas Angelo se setká s detektivem Normanem, kde se mu svěřuje, že potřebuje pomoc dostat svou rodinu z města a získat jim novou identitu kvůli událostem z minulých dnů. Takže Thomas začne Normanovi převyprávět svůj příběh jako bývalý člen rodiny Salieriho.

V roce 1932 taxikáře Thomase Angela překvapí dva mafiáni, konkrétně Paulie a Sam, když jsou oba pronásledováni dalšími mafiány z rodiny Morello. Sam na Toma namíří pistolí s tím, že potřebují oba rychle zmizet. Tímto způsobem se Tom neúmyslně zapojil do gangsterské přestřelky.
Poté, co mafiány setřese, jedou do Salieriho baru. Tom dostane od Pana Salieriho kompenzaci ve formě obálky plné peněz s vzkazem, že pokud bude potřebovat práci za slušné peníze, tak dobrý chlap jako on je vždy vítán... A tímto začíná celý příběh Thomase Angela. Původní příběh je víceméně až na pár odchylek totožný.

[h2] Hodnocení [/h2]

Když budeme ignorovat určité chybějící věci z původní hry,  tak je to naprosto úchvatná hra. Jako velké plus beru lepší příběh Sáry, který byl v původní hře až tragický. Dost mě překvapila i klasická obtížnost, která mě bavila i realistický model řízení auta či motorek.

[h3] Grafika: 10/10 [/h3]
[h3] Příběh: 9/10 [/h3]
[h3] Hratelnost: 10/10 [/h3]
[h3] Celkové hodnocení: 9,5/10 [/h3]

WELCOME TO THE CITY OF LOST HEAVEN
Mafia: Definitive Edition Review

Mafia: Definitive Edition, developed by Hangar 13 and published by 2K Games, is a ground-up remake of the 2002 classic Mafia. Set in the fictional city of Lost Heaven during the Prohibition era, this action-adventure game brings the beloved narrative, characters, and atmosphere of the original to modern platforms with a fresh coat of paint. With enhanced graphics, improved gameplay mechanics, and a faithful reimagining of the story, Mafia: Definitive Edition aims to captivate both fans of the original and newcomers alike.


GAMEPLAY (8/10):
The combat mechanics have been significantly improved from the original game, providing a satisfying and responsive third-person shooting experience. Gunfights are intense and strategic, with a cover system that adds depth to the gameplay. The realistic weapon handling contributes to the immersion, making each encounter feel impactful. The driving mechanics strike a balance between realism and accessibility, offering an enjoyable experience whether cruising through the city or engaging in high-speed pursuits.
The variety of vehicles, coupled with attention to detail in the design of the city streets, contributes to a sense of immersion in the 1930s setting. While not a fully open-world game, the semi-open world of Lost Heaven invites exploration with its detailed environments, period-appropriate landmarks and hidden collectibles.

GRAPHICS AND ATMOSPHERE (9/10):
The developers at Hangar 13 have gone to great lengths to recreate the world of Lost Heaven with meticulous attention to detail. The character models are highly detailed, showcasing realistic facial expressions and clothing textures. The environments are beautifully rendered, from the rain-soaked streets to the lavish interiors of period-appropriate buildings. Lighting and shadow effects further enhance the visual fidelity, creating a visually stunning experience that captivates players from start to finish. The graphical overhaul is particularly evident in the cityscape, with improved textures, dynamic weather effects, and a level of realism that was unimaginable in the original 2002 release. The attention to detail extends to the vehicles, showcasing the craftsmanship of the era's automobiles. The game successfully transports players to the Prohibition era of the 1930s, capturing the essence of the time with authenticity. The architecture, fashion, and overall design of Lost Heaven contribute to a rich and immersive atmosphere that enhances the storytelling. The attention to detail in recreating the period-appropriate setting is evident in every corner of the game. The city feels alive with its bustling streets, populated by pedestrians and vehicles that adhere to the era's design. The dynamic day-night cycle and changing weather conditions further contribute to the atmospheric immersion, creating a sense of time progression throughout the game.

SOUND AND MUSIC (8.5/10):
The game's sound design aims to capture the ambiance of the 1930s. This includes the sounds of city life, traffic, gunshots, and other environmental elements. Attention to detail in the audio, such as the distinctive engine noises of the era's cars, helps enhance the immersive experience. The characters are voiced by talented actors who bring the story to life. The voice acting contributes to the authenticity of the characters and helps players connect with the narrative. The game features a period-appropriate soundtrack that includes music from the 1930s. This helps to immerse players in the atmosphere of the time. The music is carefully chosen to suit the different moods and situations in the game, whether it's a tense action sequence or a more contemplative moment. In the game, players can tune into in-game radio stations while driving, featuring music and commentary reminiscent of the 1930s.

STORY AND CHARACTERS (9/10):
The story follows the protagonist, Tommy Angelo, a cab driver who becomes entangled with the Salieri crime family after a chance encounter with two members being pursued by a rival gang. As Tommy gets deeper into the world of organized crime, players witness his transformation from an ordinary citizen to a trusted member of the Salieri family. The plot is well-structured and paced, presenting a cinematic experience that captures the essence of classic gangster films. Themes of loyalty, betrayal, and the consequences of a life of crime are explored throughout the narrative. The storytelling is complemented by well-crafted dialogue, authentic voice acting, and a script that maintains tension and intrigue from start to finish. The narrative also introduces a diverse cast of characters, each with their own motivations, flaws, and unique personalities. The intertwining relationships within the Salieri family and the broader criminal underworld contribute to the complexity and depth of the overall story.

GAME LENGTH AND COMPLETION TIME (7/10):
The length of time required to complete Mafia: Definitive Edition can vary depending on individual playstyles, exploration tendencies, and difficulty settings. On average, completing the main story campaign will take most players around 10 to 12 hours. If you choose to engage in side activities, explore the open world, and pursue optional objectives, the total playtime can extend beyond the main story duration. Completionists who aim to find all collectibles and complete side missions may spend upwards of 25 to 30 hours in the game. It's important to note that these estimates are generalizations, and individual experiences may vary. Players who are more focused on the main story and less on exploration may finish the game more quickly, while those who take their time and thoroughly explore the world may extend their playtime.

CONCLUSION AND SCORE:
Mafia: Definitive Edition successfully captures the spirit of the original while elevating the experience with modern graphics and gameplay mechanics. The compelling narrative, memorable characters, and attention to detail make it a must-play for both fans of the original Mafia and newcomers looking for a gripping journey through the criminal underworld. Hangar 13 has not only revived a classic but has set a new standard for how remakes should be done. Mafia: Definitive Edition is a timeless tale retold with flair, and it stands as a shining example of the potential of video game remakes done right.

Mafia: Definitive Edition - A Polished Gem with a Nostalgic Sheen
Stepping back into Lost Heaven in Mafia: Definitive Edition is like revisiting a cherished film with a stunning high-definition remaster. The 2020 remake takes the classic 2002 mob story and infuses it with modern visuals, gameplay tweaks, and even a few narrative surprises. While it doesn't stray too far from the original path, it offers a welcome refresh for seasoned players and a captivating introduction for newcomers.

Visually, Mafia: Definitive Edition is a masterclass. Lost Heaven bursts onto the screen with meticulously recreated landmarks, detailed interiors, and atmospheric lighting. Cruising down sun-drenched streets in a gleaming 1930s car feels like stepping into a living postcard. While the core gameplay leans towards linear missions, the open world begs to be explored, showcasing the stunning visuals and offering a sense of immersion rarely found in remakes.

The story remains the heart and soul of the experience. You follow Tommy Angelo, a taxi driver thrust into the dangerous world of organized crime. The narrative unfolds with gritty realism, capturing the allure and brutality of the mob life. While some minor changes were made, the core emotional beats remain intact, ensuring a rollercoaster ride of loyalty, betrayal, and moral ambiguity.

Freeride missions, unfortunately, take a backseat in this edition. While you can explore the open world, there are no additional side activities or challenges beyond the main story missions. This might disappoint players seeking extended playtime, but the focus on the narrative might be welcome for those wanting a streamlined experience.

Collectables offer a slight distraction. Hidden around Lost Heaven are Tommy Bronte's Playboy magazines, wanted posters, and even golden Tommy statues. Finding them rewards you with lore entries and cosmetic unlocks, adding a touch of exploration incentive.

Overall, Mafia: Definitive Edition is a love letter to the original, offering a nostalgic trip down memory lane with a modern polish. The stunning visuals, captivating story, and immersive world make it a worthwhile experience for both veterans and newcomers. While the lack of expansive open-world activities might leave some wanting more, the focus on the core narrative delivers a powerful and emotional journey. If you're looking for a classic mob story brought to life with stunning visuals and engaging gameplay, Mafia: Definitive Edition is a must-play.

Mafia Definitive Edition is the remake of the classic 2002 game bringing the 1930 s to life with modern graphics, gameplay improvements and refined narrative. Without losing its essence this is a gift for the nostalgic fans and a great introduction to the Mafia games for those who are new. The game successfully balances action sequences,immersive storytelling and period-accurate exploration.

With themes of loyalty and friendship but also betrayal and revenge,Mafia offers a complex narrative with moral dilemmas and a strong accent on character development. By recounting his involvement with the Salieri, Tommy is confessing his past actions searching for redemption,a way to unburden himself from the things he done but also to make a deal to protect his family.

The narrative follows the story of Tommy Angelo,a cab driver that becomes entangled with the Salieri crime family. Drawn into a world of organized crime,Tommy climbs the ranks and earns respect and privilege to be part of the family. The retrospective narrative provides insight into the consequences of being part of a criminal group .

Mafia Definitive Edition is a substantial upgrade in terms of visuals over the 2002 classic, it's a stunning recreation. The game benefits also from improved controls particularly in shooting and driving mechanics. 
For me it was a great experience, it felt like a polished version of the 2002 classic. I had so much fun driving and exploring,even if this doesn't feel like a complete open world experience. 

In conclusion Mafia : Definitive Edition pays homage to the original release with a cinematic experience ,one to remember ,a gift for everyone who loves a good story and a excellent introduction to the Mafia games for a new player.

-trigger warning- 
Gonna do some gatekeeping here, because i think it is worth it. 

This game must be played on Classic mode, which refers to original Mafa 1's difficulty. (That game is still difficult than this tho. I remember dying a lot in that game but this one, except chapter 5 *the race*, it was a pretty smooth experience, not that hard.) 

Playing on Classic difficulty, means that you must not take any bullet, more than 2-3 anyway. Because you will die obviously. I think this should be intended difficulty setting because, it works better with the story too. Adds another layer to this adult story. It establishes a coherence between story and gameplay and makes narrative more well-seated. Like, this game has reminiscence of movies like The Godfather and Once Upon a Time in America, it is even like their videogame version. Its more of a dram than action-adventure. So, killing every enemies without thinking and running into them like in Mafia 3 in a dram story wouldn't make the narrative receivable.

But in Classic mode, you must take cover, wait for enemies move, observe them, wait for their ammos run out and manage your ammo carefully; these put you into more dangerous situations which is more accurate to a mob's life. Your life is at stake for the job and it is difficult to protect it when bullets are flying in the air. Enemies help to establish this coherence too. When they got shot, they dont get out from their cover and just shoot without teasing themselves. So you must make another move to make them get out or find another angle to see them. 

Like FromSoft games, they too make really hard bosses to beat because they want to tell us that they are real deal. They are legends. They wouldnt be like this if you could kill all of them easily. You would have a feeling like ''Huh, this is the Nameless King? Looks more like Fameless to me.'' or smth like that. 

Classic mode is not unjust or frustrating in this meaning. You just have to be a little more patient and hesitant. That's it. You wait for the opening, for the right time, you see the opportunity, you shoot and kill. More important, you survive another day. It is smoother experience than the original one. 

[b]Classic mode makes you say that ''wow, this is hard, being a gangster is hard, fatal even''. Reminds you this is not a pure action game. And i loved that. So wanted to appreciate that. I wish they hadn't ruined the rest of the Mafia games.

After the first four short introduction missions you get to play an old bucket racing simulator which is almost unbeatable without mastering very specific driving mechanics (I played on Classic but I heard complaints that lowering the difficulty does not help much), so you've been warned. But, if you win the race, here's what you'll get:

Pros:
+ Outstanding story
+ Unforgettable characters
+ Amazing music
+ Atmosphere
+ Decent graphics (city and transport)
+ Good gameplay (shooting part and probably driving because it's claimed to be realistic, while it may be frustrating sometimes, it brings some challenge)

Cons:
- Graphics (NPCs, Tommy and some scenes sometimes): the models and their animations look outdated (the cutscenes look great though), they just don't fit the realistic picture of the city.
- Gameplay: I would say that the missions could have been designed better because they feel outdated too. Like it or not, but gameplay is a key part of almost every game (except the interactive movie genre) no matter how great the story is.
- The race: it is a very questionable game design idea as by the moment the mission starts you didn't even get to know the game, so if you are not familiar with the original, chances are you will rage quit and uninstall the game.
- The credits song [spoiler]by Ice Cube[/spoiler]. It's nice but what the f?

P.S. I didn't play the original back in the day but I've seen a playthrough and watched some videos comparing these two games, so I am aware of the differences but I cannot agree with those who say the remake is worse than the OG.

Many gangster games lean into the romanticized or over-the-top nature of the criminal underworld. Mafia: Definitive Edition takes a different path, telling the much more grounded story of Tommy Angelo. His journey through the NYC stand-in of Lost Heaven as a member of the fictional Salieri crime family is compelling, emotional, and filled with interesting characters. As I progressed through the game, I found myself increasingly more invested in Tommy and the people around him. Without this investment, I don’t think I would have finished the game as the combat is mediocre and really served as filler for me between the story beats. There are a few memorable missions (a high speed chase in a race car sticks out), but many are just cover-based shootouts that grow tiresome quickly. With no sort of character progression (or any progression really outside of the story), there is no hook pulling you forward aside from seeing what happens to Tommy. That being said, if you find yourself interested in what happens to this made man, then you’ll find Mafia: Definitive Edition a fun romp through the 1930s Italian mafia.

At the very beginning, it should be mentioned that Mafia Definitive Edition is a successful remake of the already legendary production entitled Mafia: The City of Lost Heaven, which had its premiere date in 2002. What has changed from the original from 21 years ago? As befits a remake, the new old production from Hangar13 has not changed only in terms of the graphics engine, but also some dialogues have been changed and some of the characters have been partially rewritten, making the characters more interesting and the whole story more coherent and, most importantly, finally connects entirely with Mafia II, which takes place after the events of the first part of the trilogy. After the introduction, let's get into the details of the remake of the latest Mafia game. Like every part of the Mafia series, here we get a great linear plot with interesting characters all the time, a well-made climatic city. Staying on the subject of the city, apart from the fact that it has been really well designed, its biggest problem is that there is absolutely nothing to do in it, apart from scattered "collectibles" and about two or three hidden side missions, there is absolutely no more activity in it, which makes it empty and boring, it's worth noting that after completing the story line, we can't explore it freely, if we want to do it, we have to switch to a separate mode prepared by the creators. Minor aspects such as the driving model or the feeling of shooting is literally transferred from the third part of the trilogy and it is just + it is pleasant and there is nothing to complain about. The same is true with optimization and graphics, everything is fine. The disadvantages are definitely the music, there are no decent songs from those years, which is a pity because mostly the music was part of the great atmosphere in the second part. On + while passing the story, we can hear information about the ongoing war in Europe and the view of the Americans on this event. And finally, two quick disadvantages of the game you need to give it time before the story starts to get going, the first chapters are quite boring. The second thing is pointless collectibles that really don't give anything, they're just...

[h1]Mafia: The Definitive Edition - A Roaring Tale of Crime and Redemption[/h1]

[h2]Story[/h2]
Welcome to Lost Heaven, a city seeped in 1930s charm, fedora fashion, and enough mob drama to make even your grandma shout, "Fuhgeddaboudit!" Mafia: The Definitive Edition weaves a gripping narrative, complete with characters as colorful as a speakeasy cocktail. From cabbie to capo, Tommy Angelo's journey through the ranks of the Salieri crime family is a rollercoaster of loyalty, betrayal, and enough plot twists to make your spaghetti fork jealous.

The dialogue? It's like they swiped it straight from a gangster's handbook. Quick-witted remarks and sharp exchanges keep you engaged, and the voice acting? It's so on point, you'll swear you're sitting in a smoky backroom planning the next heist yourself. Choices matter, and the branching paths add a layer of unpredictability that'll keep you guessing who's on your side and who's just waiting to backstab you like a mafia-themed game of Clue.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Jumping into the gameplay is like putting on a perfectly tailored suit—it just feels right. The controls are smoother than a silk-lined Cadillac, and the mechanics are as polished as the brass knuckles tucked in your waistband. From heart-pounding shootouts to white-knuckle car chases, Mafia knows how to keep the adrenaline pumping.

The attention to detail is so meticulous that you can practically smell the cigar smoke wafting through Little Italy. The city's layout is a nostalgic trip back in time, with level designs that immerse you in the era. And let's talk about the cars—each one is a roaring testament to 1930s automotive elegance. The developers didn't just create a game; they crafted a time machine.

[h2]Graphics[/h2]
If the devil's in the details, then Mafia: The Definitive Edition is diabolically good. The graphics are as sharp as a well-dressed mob boss, with textures so rich you'll want to reach out and touch the pinstripes. The lighting dances through the streets, casting shadows that add an extra layer of atmosphere. It's not just a game; it's a visual feast that'll have you snapping screenshots like you're a mobster paparazzo.

Comparisons to other games? Fuhgettaboutit! Mafia sets a new standard for visual storytelling in its genre. It's not about hyper-realism; it's about capturing the essence of the era, and boy, does it do it with style. If other games are the competition, then Mafia is the mob boss looking down from the top floor, saying, "You call that a game?"

[h2]Sound[/h2]
From the jazzy tunes of the roaring '30s to the rat-a-tat of Tommy's Tommy gun, the sound in Mafia is the auditory equivalent of a perfectly orchestrated heist. The voice acting is so spot-on, you'll be wondering if Marlon Brando himself made a guest appearance. The ambient sounds of the city immerse you in its underworld, creating an atmosphere so thick you could cut it with a switchblade.

And let's not forget the soundtrack—the soulful melodies and energetic jazz transport you to a time when fedoras were mandatory, and speakeasies were the place to be. The sound design isn't just background noise; it's the unsung hero that elevates the entire experience.

[h2]Overall[/h2]
Mafia: The Definitive Edition isn't just a game; it's an offer you can't refuse. The story is a gripping tale of crime and redemption, the gameplay is a seamless dance between challenge and reward, the graphics are a visual masterpiece, and the sound is a symphony of 1930s nostalgia.

Should you play it? If you have a soft spot for fedoras, tommy guns, and a narrative that's more twisted than a mafia handshake, then yes, you absolutely should. It's not just a game; it's an immersive journey into the heart of organized crime, where every choice has consequences and every alley has secrets.

So, in the words of Tommy Angelo himself, "It's only a matter of time before they come for me... and when they do, they won't be gentle." Embrace the underworld, fellow gamer, because Mafia: The Definitive Edition is a ride you won't forget.

A good examples of a maybe button. This reboot has some pretty visuals, which tend to bug out all the time, and a very nice quality of life skip for unnecessary drives, but misses the mark for miles. Voice acting and delivery of the lines sinks the game hard. They decided to give the story a tiny bit more life but it really just boils down to politically correct horse crap that makes sure to tick all those lovely DEI marks. It's a period piece where the original at least had the stones to touch base on that. Here they made sure to make some certain cuts and additions to ensure no one was offended. 

As for game play the bread and butter of the shooting is okay but nothing to really write home about. For some reason they thought taking away the vast arsenal from the original was a good idea. Having access to two guns is kind of realistic I guess but once you jam a tommy gun down your pants it kinda defeats that argument. Guns also sound and feel like peashooters. The orginal had them kicking like mules. The 44 mag felt like you were blasting a hand cannon and knocking enemies on their asses with it felt good.  Here it feels like every other peashooter of a gun. Absolutely sad they butchered a classic like that; however, disregarding the original the gun play is okay. 

Grab it on sale. Otherwise just play the original. You might have to drive around more in the 1st game but the story with the better VO and gun play blow this reboot out of the park.

Edit: Played through to the end and the story telling just gets more virtue signally and tries desperately to make what was once a badass mobster story into a bs tear jerker. They made Pauli into the biggest pussy on the planet. His new VO certainly does enough justice in that regard but now his character ark is total trash cakes.  Every additional scene they made with Sarah just makes me want to pull the plug on my PC they feel so pretentious. 

Some of the new set pieces are very poorly designed and are extremely annoying to play. The only thing meaningful this reboot does is the combat, which does have some good moments but lord the guns are so bad. The enemies at least on classic difficulty can soak a few bullets with zero reaction. Only if your up close enough to kiss them with the barrel of a shotgun or after taking a few rounds will they show any real feedback. In the original the enemies actually reacted to getting shot each time, which made the combat feel so much more alive then whatever the hell this reboot tries doing. 

Tdrl - Stick with the original or pick this one up on a deep sale.

I regret not having played the original version. I tried a few years ago, before they announced the remake, because I had played Mafia 2 at the time and it quickly became one of my favorite titles, mainly because of the storyline. So, I tried playing the first part to learn more about its world and characters, but I couldn't; it had aged too bad. 
To my surprise, a few years later, they announced the remake, and I was very excited. Finally, I could close the complete arc that I had liked so much. 
Now, regarding the game itself: Graphically, it is beautiful; the vehicles, environments, and characters are sublime. Every detail is carefully crafted. 
Unfortunately, it's just a pretty picture to admire because gameplay-wise, the title is very weak. They could have taken advantage of the remake to add more variety, something else to do in the open world, perhaps a shop to customize our character, some mini-games, anything that would make exploring the city enjoyable instead of a chore. 
Once you finish the story, there's nothing else to do. The game could easily be a linear video game since the open world is empty and lacks activities. I think that's the worst part because, in other aspects, like the plot, the game is brilliant. 
There are also some issues with the animations, a bit clunky, but I've just finished playing Red Dead Redemption 2, and there's no comparison; maybe I just need to get used to it. 
To give it a rating, I would give it a well-deserved 7 out of 10, mainly for how gripping the story is, which, for me, is the fundamental pillar in any video game.

Only thing I wish they implemented is being able to enter certain buildings and areas (not just Salieri's) in Free Ride; instead you need an external mod for that which is quite silly, in my opinion.  :/

As a avid fan of open world shooter games, like GTA V and RDR2, I decided to try out the Mafia trilogy as I heard generally good things about the series. I enjoyed this game very much. The graphics are beautiful in the Definitive Edition, although my PC struggled a bit in terms of frame rate (if your CPU is old like mine, you might struggle to play this game). As I am more used to the mechanics of the aforementioned Rockstar games, it took me a little getting used to in terms of shooting, since the reticle is a circle and not the most accurate for shooting. I was also a bit disappointed that this isn't a true open world game, since the environment is very beautifully designed and yet you cannot explore the world freely. It's pretty much a linear set game, one mission to the next. I liked the progression since I have less means to distract myself, but I also like exploring. 

I found the story much more interesting than any GTA game, but that's just personal opinion. The characters were interesting, and the voice-acting was pretty good. The cutscenes look fantastic, too.

If you were expecting a GTA5 set in 1930s prohibition, I would pass this one. It just doesn't have the polish, and the writing is all over the place.

The atrocious TAA that causes smearing and blur cannot be turned off, even with mods and forcing the setting through NVIDIA's control panel.

The driving physics is atrocious. While setting the driving physics to "Simulation" in-game makes things a little tolerable, it puts you at a disadvantage in the racing and chasing parts.

There are forced stealth sections that should honestly have been cut down on this remake. This isn't 2004 anymore. Hangar 21 had an opportunity to create a modern experience that takes the best parts of the OG mafia and trims the clunky parts but... honestly I think they did the opposite.

The checkpoint system places you at the BEGINNING of the chase or stealth section when you fail them. Quite infuriating when you fail at the end.

With GTA5, the mission designs are flawed, yes. But there is downtime in-between missions where you drive around the city as a breather. In this game, you are thrown into one mission after the other. There is no time to wander and appreciate the city they've built. No freeroam (I know there is one in the menu) as part of the storyline. To do that you'll have to select it in the main menu.

[SPOILERS BELOW]

The story is the most egregious part. It starts off slow. Builds up to a betrayal you can see coming a mile away. The GTAs do this, and Mafia is no exception.

It's the abruptness and missing story beats that sour the whole twist. You find the supposed "diamonds" were narcotics, and the Don has been keeping the truth from your crew.

The "diamonds" serve as cover for cigars, but Sam was the one briefed first by the Don? At this point Tommy is the go-to guy for the Don after having taken care of the most important events in the game. YOU get Frank's ledger, YOU kill the other mob boss, YOU win the garbage race. The Don trusts you the most, enough to disclose the existence of a rat in the family (that turns out to be Frank), yet he keeps the cigar-dope job under your nose? Doesn't make narrative sense.

Ludonarrative dissonance is a word thrown around by video essayists, but it absolutely applies here. Tommy at multiple points shows he doesn't want innocent bystanders killed. He even makes certain jobs harder because of that. Yet in-game, he mows down hundreds of cops and goons who could've been just like him. Who's to say the enemies at the other end of the barrel isn't some heart-of-gold taxi driver down on his luck scooped up by the mafioso so they can pay their bills?

Sam is never shown to be the guy willing to throw his crewmates under the bus to get a leg-up in the mafioso career ladder. Instead we see him looking out for the other two in the Trio. Yet all of a sudden he caps his best friend, and tries to plug Tommy so Don looks at him kindly as the Godfather's favorite pet? What??

How did he even find out about the bank job? Yes he heard about it in the car but how did he know to go straight to the apartment afterwards? Why didn't Tommy split up right then and there? Why would you stay in town longer than necessary after poking at the hive's nest?

Why isn't there a lead-up to the bank job? It's supposed to be thing big end-of-all-heists that's supposed to get them out of their shitty lives as low-level grunts, but we don't see any planning. There are no missions that lay out the blueprints of the building, what you'll do, and how you'll get out of there.

It's just "hey lets rob a bank" and you are there at the next cutscene. Tommy does all this for his kids that we don't see until the final cutscene.

Tommy makes a deal with Irish to get back at the Don who betrayed him. The actual arrest and jail-time isn't a mission, but a montage of cutscenes. He gets old, we see his kid(s), now multiple (i thought it was just a "baby girl", and he gets popped at the end by the VERY DON HE PUT IN JAIL.

This one we ALSO see coming because Frank got capped at a dog race, but the Don was NOT in prison at the time. It's just a forced way to say "you can't escape the mafia life bro".

All of this ends with Vin Diesel--sorry, TOMMY--saying some crap about "family". Like the entire game was leading up to a Fast and Furious line. Very disappointing and not even worth the money at a sale price.

Mafia holds a special place in my heart, when everyone else was going nuts over Grand Theft Auto 3 I was exploring Lost Heaven. So I was excited to see this remake. Sadly, it does not live up to expectations. Despite claiming that they added content they have actually produced a game with much less content than the original. The difficulty is way down. The open world aspects are basically gone. Your hand is held through the entire thing. 

While the action scenes are still true to the original, and challenging, the heart and soul of the game is gone. You can no longer approach missions as you see fit. If the game wants you to use stealth then you're going to, or the mission will fail. If you want to approach the target from an abnormal area, you can't, you've been plopped down in a location with one way out, through the enemy directly. They made other weird changes like the getaway plane actually being a plane instead of a blimp like in the original.

They added a cutscene where Sarah says the politician you assassinate championed the 19th amendment. Even though this games takes place in the 30's and the 19th amendment was passed in 1968. So not only did they add a historical inaccuracy to a game that was once heralded for its historical accuracy but a game that's already heavy in exposition now has way more exposition. As far as I can tell that's the only content they actually added, cut scenes. There is significantly less game play in this version. 

Which brings me to my last complaint. All the car missions are gone, along with the need to learn to pick locks. These were multi-part missions that felt like at least half the game. Just GONE. They did give a nod to these missions through post cards, but they aren't integrated into the story, the cut scenes and dialogue is gone, and instead of entire missions it's just a scavenger hunt. 

The raised rail system isn't usable anymore either. In the original game, after you take the train in the story, you could take the train to get around town as much as you wanted. There was also a mission involving the train platform, that's totally gone. In this game you can't take the train, ever. 

I expected a LOT more. You can't access the airport or race track in free mode, which I expected in the remake. They REMOVED tons of missions, which I never expected in the remake, and it makes it bad. They added historically inaccurate feminist non-sense, albeit in one cut scene, still ruins it. 

Game doesn't even look much better, and has massively higher performance requirements. 

If you want to experience Mafia the way we all fell in love with it, ignore this version. The things that make this game bad are the same things that make Mafia 2 and 3 bad, no depth, no immersion, no heart, no soul. Just go to gog.com and get the original version. Mod it into 1080p, mod the original music back into it, play that.

This version is bad and the developers should feel bad.

[h1]Mafia: Definitive Edition - Everything It Could Have Wanted. 8/10 [/h1]

Mafia: Definitive Edition is a full-scale remake of the original 2002 classic. While appearing similar in looks and style to GTA5, Mafia focuses a lot more on the narrative and story it has to tell, with the definitive edition including a free-roam mode, where you can explore the city of Lost Heaven in your own time.

Technically, the game runs fairly well. Aside from some abrupt texture and model pop-in at close ranges, the game is a visual treat, with ample detail to recreate the feel of 1930s America. 

I was most impressed by the driving in the game. It feels much more weighty than you would expect, and I enjoy the feel of driving every vehicle the game features. The soundtrack is another stellar part of the game, using original motifs and melodies, but also a fresh true sound; the music really is timeless.

For a nicely crafted story, excellent open world, mobster themed gameplay and a sweet-as-fuck soundtrack to accompany it all, Mafia: Definitive Edition is certainly worth a try.

As someone who played and beat the original Mafia, I can't express how grateful I am for this remake enough. Though I did love the original game, the controls were just bad, and driving was an exercise in futility. This updating of what was an already good game, is vital to anyone getting into the series.

Now, this game is far from perfect. The story can probably be wrapped up easily in under 10 hours, maybe even less. There isn't any additional content either. Also, you're never really able to explore the open world too much because you're always going from mission to mission. I think there is a mode that let's you explore, but it isn't part of the normal game play.

All-in-all, it really is the definitive experience for the first Mafia game, and if you're looking to get back into the series, or start again from the beginning, it might be better to pick this up than play the original.

Something about driving 30's cars down the road while listening to a baseball game on the radio, just to get out wearing a pinstripe suit and then mowing down some rival mafia family members with a tommy gun scratches an itch within me.

Just like the original, the overarching plot is generic gas. Focusing instead, on running us through the 'best of' bombastic mafioso slice of life. And does so better than ever.

Sadly, after finishing the story, the city doesn't feel as lively as it should. Public transit is unavailable. Most areas are blocked off by indestructible fences. Bushes.  Aside from extraordinarily goofy missions and a ton of collectables, including outfits and vehicles, there isn't anything to do besides drive around.

[h1]Mafia: Definitive Edition[/h1]

«Mafia: Definitive Edition» — это переосмысленная версия классической игры «Mafia», выпущенная в 2002 году. Разработчики из Hangar 13 и 2K Games решили воссоздать эту криминальную эпопею с нуля, чтобы предложить игрокам современную графику и улучшенный игровой процесс.

Основное внимание в «Mafia: Definitive Edition» уделяется повествованию и созданию атмосферы 1930-х годов в мире организованной преступности. Игрок в роли Томми Анджело, члена мафиозного клана, продвигается в итальянской мафии посредством различных событий и криминальных операций.

Одним из главных преимуществ «Mafia: Definitive Edition» являются улучшенные визуальные эффекты и графика. Реконструированная окружающая среда, транспортные средства и персонажи позволяют игрокам полностью погрузиться в атмосферу места преступления.

Геймплей также претерпел некоторые изменения. Он стал более современным и адаптированным к современным стандартам. Бой и стрельба стали более плавными, а система управления машиной улучшилась.

Но главное достижение «Mafia: Definitive Edition» — сохранение и даже улучшение оригинального глубокого и эмоционального сюжета. Персонажи более живые, их отношения запоминающиеся, а повороты сюжета остаются захватывающими.

В целом «Mafia: Definitive Edition» — это не просто ремейк, а настоящая реинкарнация культовой игры. Она воплощает в себе лучшие аспекты оригинала и представляет собой современное воплощение для нового поколения игроков. Для тех, кто ценит красочные сюжеты, великолепную атмосферу и качественный геймплей, эта игра предоставляет прекрасную возможность пережить золотую эпоху организованной преступности в новом мире.

So, here I am, after 22 years, playing this game. The gameplay isn't too impressive, and if you've played the original Mafia 1, you'll understand what I mean. The original Mafia 1 is the hardest game I've ever played (except for the Souls-Like category), and it's really realistic for its time in 2002.

On May 13, 2020, 2K announced Mafia Definitive Series developed by Hangar 13. Hangar 13, hmm. I remember on July 18, 2015, 2K announced Mafia III developed by Hangar 13. After Mafia III was released, everyone hated it. The story isn't about the Mafia, the open world is awful, and all the missions are the same.

When Mafia Definitive Series was announced, every single gamer said, "F*ck that studio, that game will be awful." On September 25, 2020, Mafia Definitive Edition was released. It's not a AAA game, but it's working well and stays true to the original story with a few new mechanics. The graphics aren't awesome but look very good. Sounds are really good. Animations aren't as smooth as the original Mafia II, but it's not too bad, and the missions are faithful to the original. Cutscenes, oh man, they're like movie scenes. Every single detail is awesome in cutscenes. Hangar 13 deserves applause. They've taken a cult game and turned it into an really good one.

I pre-ordered this game as soon as the pre order was available and I.. have some things to say.


Gameplay

Absolutely astonishing. I love that they kept the feeling that the first game had in its design of the entire map and its missions that it offers. But it may be the definitive edition of a game that came out in 2002, but it didn't really be that game in a way. Mafia's gameplay was usually that you needed to avoid getting injured usually. The driving in the first game absolutely sucked, but it kinda felt rewarding in a weird way. Health didnt regenerate like we have it now. If you were low at a checkpoint then oh well, thats all the hp you're getting for the entire mission or unless you find a way of healing. Bullets felt lethal, ammo felt needed, different ways to do a mission were impressive. They added some of the feeling back into their classic mode in the definitive edition but it just really didnt feel the same. With that aside, the game really does feel polished, its a fun experience to go through having all of these intense scenes. I love how they remade the missions to feel a bit more enjoyable for the user. Introducing the player to driving in the new running man mission is an amazing way to show off the driving portion of the game. Although, im sure the animations dont feel like Tommy, right? Thats because the entire game runs on the Mafia 3 engine. Usually I dont care about this detail, but the original made Tommy look like someone whos in the mob, not the damn military. The animations for Tommy's actions in combat are really similar if not the same to Lincoln Clay in Mafia 3. Driving do feel smooth tho. Especially the ram feature. The ram feature allows your to make kinda tighter turns while speeding up the car you're driving for a really short time frame. This is really useful in Fairplay mostly. The guns didnt really feel that bad when it came to damage in the remake. The original game had very lethal shotguns that either blow you away or just kill you in one shot. The saw-off shotgun being a prime example of this. It fires 2 shots really quickly but then the reload takes a bit. The pump shotgun fires at a more steady rate but the reload time isnt really as bad on it. But wheres the lethal part in all of this? It's if the enemy has it. There exists a bug in the game where a shotgun can rapid fire, basically allowing a free kill on the main player. NPC's have health in the original where in the remake, they can indeed be shot at by enemies but they dont have health. They have an infinite amount of health since you cant hurt your allies in the remake, but in the original you could actually kill your allies. Of course if you did, the mission would fail usually. But whats interesting is that they fight back if you fight them or if you shoot a certain amount of times near them during the general start of missions where you start off in Saliari's bar most of the time. Ammo didnt carry over clips. Any bullet you didnt use in the clip you were using and you reload, the bullets just gone. For example if you're shooting a pistol and you have 2 bullets left, you reload. The 2 bullets wont carry over to the next clip, instead you have a different clip with the max amount of bullets that can be held within a clip. This detail was really similar to the real world where bullets dont magically transfer over to the next clip.

Story

Mafia's story has always been simple, but the definitive edition made the characters feel more important. Especially Sarah. Sarah was Tommy's love interest in both games, however the original game only had mention of her through dialogue after her main mission. The definitive edition made her feel as a character. They gave her a more important role aswell as including her in some cutscenes and spare dialogue in future plus missions before her main one. Still prefer the old ending cutscene with sam at the art gallery. The message was more meaningful instead of giving us the whole "we had good times Tom, but eventually we all die.". I did love that they made sam's death a bit more satisfying in the remake. Story is just generally explained better in the remake than the original. 

Free Ride

Free ride mode in the definitive edition feels... Limited????? Its a weird way to describe it but to be honest you only have a handful of easter eggs, Lucas Bertone missions, and the exploration of the map. The original had a save feature where you had to interact with saliari's bar in order to save your game. You could chose what car you wanted to start with, what part of town you wanted to spawn at, the conditions of npc behavior, and even different varients of the map. You could kill gangsters that can be seen on the street or just driving a car. You get a chunk of money for just killing one of them, but usually they're pretty lethal with their weapon choices.

Summary

I overall enjoy the definitive edition of a game I got to play when I was little. It brings so many memories of the good days in Mafia. No doubt, the game has its flaws. But with all of the improvements, the minor details arent that major. Overall I'd rate the game a 8/10

I was there when Mafia 1 came out. I was at the occasion of announcement for the official release back in the early 2000s. When the game came out, i didn't wait and purchased it. It's probably the most "played through" game in my life till this day and I play it (Mafia 1) at least once a year ever since. I stopped counting after 24th playthrough.
The definitive edition is far away from "definitive", unfortunately. New visuals mean almost nothing to me. The game is underwhelming at best, annoying at worst. The interface and controls are very sad - non-responsive and stupidly frustrating because of the "take cover" mechanism. The game is missing serious sections of the original and feels very empty. Don't let me start about the physics aspect which was a showcase of the original 5 years ahead of any competition in same/similar genre.
No challenge getting new cars or doing quite challenging sub-quests. It's like a school run race, where everyone gets medal for participation. It leaves good impression of the cinematic story, but very bad aftertaste because of wasted potential. Seems the developers and the distributor wanted to appeal to modern audience, probably taking "it" for completely stupid, lazy and not able to value good challenge and better game mechanics.
Unfortunately it's not a definitive, nor good "successor" of the original. The storytelling is bit more dynamic (not entirely a positive if you ask me) and parts of the story changes make sense. The visuals are better (duh), but if it's for the cost of taking away from the other strong aspects of the original game - it's not a good deal for me.
If you are lower on IQ, new to gaming, or loving game consoles and some "standard" modern day "arcady" game mechanics, this is for you. If you expect a gaming masterpiece (especially for PC gaming) with strong story and exceptional game-play, rather move on.
It's still worth playing just for curiosity, but don't pay full price for it.

I recently had the pleasure of experiencing the Mafia Definitive Edition, and I must say, it's nothing short of a gaming masterpiece. Hangar 13 has not only successfully revived a classic title but has elevated it to new heights with stunning visuals, immersive storytelling, and refined gameplay mechanics.

First and foremost, the graphics are jaw-dropping. The developers have painstakingly recreated the city of Lost Heaven with incredible attention to detail. The architecture, the streets, and the atmosphere all contribute to a nostalgic yet fresh experience. The character models are meticulously crafted, making the protagonists and antagonists alike feel more lifelike than ever before.

The narrative is where Mafia Definitive Edition truly shines. While staying true to the original storyline, the revamped script and voice acting breathe new life into the characters. Tommy Angelo's journey from a cab driver to a key player in the Salieri crime family is both compelling and emotionally charged. The storytelling is so well-executed that even those familiar with the original game will find themselves captivated by the revamped narrative twists.

Gameplay improvements are evident throughout, providing a more polished and enjoyable experience. The gunplay feels satisfying, and the driving mechanics have been fine-tuned to strike the right balance between realism and accessibility. The integration of cover mechanics adds strategic depth to shootouts, making every encounter a thrilling experience.

The attention to detail extends beyond the visuals and narrative, permeating every aspect of the game. From the authentic 1930s soundtrack to the period-appropriate vehicles, Mafia Definitive Edition effortlessly transports players to the Prohibition era. The inclusion of side missions and collectibles also adds longevity to the game, encouraging exploration and engagement beyond the main story.

In conclusion, Mafia Definitive Edition is a triumphant reimagining of a classic title. It successfully combines the nostalgia of the original with modern gaming standards, resulting in a visually stunning, emotionally resonant, and thoroughly enjoyable experience. Hangar 13 has set a new standard for remakes, and I can't wait to see what they have in store for the future. Bravo!

It follows the original to a fault, even to the point of replicating the broken race episode, which astonishes me really. It took me one hour to complete that stupid mission, but I do find it funny that it's almost as broken as in the oringal. Once again Hangar 13 had the perfect opportunity to deliver a much more broader, interesting experience and expand on what the original game had achieved, but they opted for a more stream lined game instead, with little incentive for exploration. If anything, Mafia is a text book example on how to do a respectful remake, that's for sure, but it could've been much more tho. The ending is still as great as I remembered, with a little tweak that makes it even more emotional. I do miss a little bit of the old faces and voices, but it's understandable that they had to go with new ones of course. If you like story driven games, and specially if you haven't experienced the first Mafia, you should try this one out.

- Nice Good looking cars ✅
Cons:

Final Opinion and vote: All and all , and alright Game, expect for these cons , so i still reccomend to buy this game when it's in Sale, because the core it's always from the OG game , and if you play this one, you will have some of the Feels from the Original One, so that's Good. TL;DR: get it on sale, as a remake this game lacks some of the original game stuff. If you want an open world game, then this is not for you since this one is a linear story game where if you go where the game don't want you to, it will start a countdown that makes you go back where you were going before.

I proceed to rate the aspects of the game:

- Main history: 7/10 it would be an 8/10 if it wasn't because of that nonsense changes they've made for this remake (some missions were cut and some dialogues were changed for worse), the original game story isn't even perfect since it has some inconsistencies but definitely the original has the best version of the story. The last thing I'm adding here is that in one mission you can pass through the door without killing all the enemies and yet Tommy will tell that he has killed all of them, nothing more to add here.
- Gameplay: 3/10 and I'm being generous, I've beaten it in classic difficulty to make it challenging I guess. The gameplay is awful, and the gunplay is seriously really bad, also I hate the combat system, it annoys me. Even if I played in classic difficulty and somewhat I enjoyed the game only because of the story until the end, enemies are bullet sponges (this is something I hate from modern games) and the gunplay makes it worse. At least the gameplay is better than the original game, but for our standards it's bad.
- AI in general: 3/10 the AI in general made me laugh sometimes, that's why I gave it an extra point, because in general it's annoying and frustrating when it comes to allies AI (sometimes they get stuck in one room for some reason), and the enemies AI? Well... seriously, how can I pass through my enemies at 10 meters without being seen? This AI is a bad joke to the game industry 
- "Free Ride" mode: 3/10 lacks content and it is really boring since you can't use money in the game, and indeed you can't do activities that requires money for payment except por paying fines (when the police catch you). The only somewhat fun stuff this mode includes are secret cars, weapons, outfit, missions and more collectibles, other than that as I've said before, it lacks of content and makes Lost Heaven feel empty even if the map is somewhat kind of big. 
- Graphics and design in general: 8/10 they are nice to see not gonna lie (overall I love how Lost Heaven looks, I think they've done a really good work in that aspect), but there are some details I don't like of the game, like Tommy's daughter for example (seriously, couldn't they've done a better design and not make her look like a simple NPC?).
- Collectibles: 5/10 there are some decent collectibles like the ones in the main story missions, but overall the rest are all generic trophies and I don't think I will collect them all, maybe I'll do it in the future, I don't know to be honest.

Overall rating: 4.3/10 not a good remake as someone might say, it could be better. Not worth at full price.

Sooo, Let's start by simple things that came into my mind first. The game looks great. It's not ugly, it's visually very appealing. Lots of Colors, huge world and blablabla. I've never played the original game besides a bit in free ride and an demo version  I believe so I don't know how close it is to it's source material, but I've heared its a great remake.

The Game has a really good atmosphere, offers an Noir Mode, which is super cool, gives it old movie vibes and offers a pleasant singleplayer experience BUT, as far as it feels for me, it runs on the Mafia 3 Engine, which I really dislike. The Shooting feels odd, not as satisfying as in Mafia 2, the Driving is Awful in my opinion and those 2 make a huge portion of the game. The Physics are just wanky. Honestly, I liked Mafia 2 more, even if those physics were pretty weird. Just, I'm driving 30' Cars, not modern sports cars, so they should feel shit.

Regardless, let's talk about mission design. Overall I loved the missions, the Story they tried to (re)tell was a pleasure to follow trough, but with about 10 hours of playtime just way too short. I know the original Story ain't as long but still sad. A mission that I really hated tho, was the Mission where you had to race. As mentioned earlier the driving physics are really bad, and it was an unpleasant experience being forced to win a Race that was no fun at all to me. I had to do it like 3 times Over coz the wanky physics screwed me over. There is also a Mission where you have to protect booze whilst being in the back of the truck. It's a fun Railshooter experience but still a bad and unpleasant mission, so Dislike that 2.

On the other Side, you had missions that were more engaging such as the old Prison or the final Mission. Really a lot of Fun to play these, even tho it's sad, when you grew accustomed to these Characters. I  will still love Vito and Joe more.

Talking about those, There is a Mission in Mafia 2 that correlates with the game here, where Joe and Vito have a cameo, which I really like. I never understood this mission in Mafia 2 until I played the Remake and watched Videos to inform me.

Now I wanna be angry about 1 more thing, which may exclusively be to the German version of the game. Mafia 2 had great voice acting, this game however... Neither atmospheric nor really good. The Characters never whispered in Situations where they should've been. There Is a Scene where they scream about killing someone whilst on way to him, super stupid. Also most of the time it sounded like people where right next to you when  they were not. A lot of times the voice acting sounded expressionless, which makes me sad, but the VA of Vito Scaletta was atleast the right one.

What to say at the end of the game? I wish there was more Content, more Guns, more boom, but it's just the Remake of the original Mafia. I've heared great things and wanted to play it myself, ending up paying 40€. It's a pleasant and great experience, tho on Hard it's stupid to have to run to a Medkit every gunfight.

I recommend this game to fans of the Mafia Franchise or to people who like a decent gangster Story BUT, I do not recommend it to be brought for 40€. This game is more like a 20-25 € Experience, not worth 40 Bucks. Since the game has no real DLC, it loses it's charm very quick, and the open world feels really empty.

Remember, whether it's money, work, or even close friends, they are all but fleeting. Only family is eternal.
——Tommy·Angelo

Mafia: Definitive Edition is the modern retelling of a classic story in the franchise. The game follows the tale of Tommy Angelo as he navigates the perils of life as a gangster in the 1930's city of Lost Haven. Tommy's struggle between the life he has chosen & life he wishes to have throughout the story, helps to make him a memorable protagonist in the franchise.

Pros:
+Great Story: The story while detailing Tommy Angelo's rise from struggling cab driver to mafia capo also does a great job portraying the realities of life in a 1930's prohibition era Lost Haven where the Salieri and Morello crime families are feuding for control of the city. The story also does a great job detailing the origins of these crime families as well as their downfall.
+Great Graphics: The city of Lost Haven simply looks beautiful from its bustling streets to its towering buildings. This makes for a brilliant 1930's themed backdrop as you visit various locations throughout the story.
+Good Combat: The game while being somewhat bare-bones in this aspect does offer some one-handed, two-handed & melee weapons for use in combat. The cover system can feel a bit clunky & imprecise when taking on groups of enemies & there is no skill tree to complement combat.
+Good Controls: The game's controls are simple and responsive when in combat or racing through the rainy streets of Lost Haven to outrun the law.
+Great Soundtrack: The songs played through the available radio stations in game definitely complement the 1930's look & feel of the game.

Cons:
-The game's story is very short and condensed within 20 chapters which can be cleared in 5-7 hours if not less. Outside this there is nothing to do, leading to minimum replay value except if achievement hunting.

A Masterful Reimagining of a Classic Tale - "Mafia: The Definitive Edition" Review

Rating: 10/10

"Mafia: The Definitive Edition," developed by Hangar 13 and published by 2K Games, is a ground-up remake of the iconic 2002 title, "Mafia." With enhanced visuals, expanded storytelling, and modernized gameplay mechanics, this remake delivers a fresh and immersive experience while staying true to the narrative brilliance that defined the original.

Storyline : 10/10
The narrative in "Mafia: The Definitive Edition" remains the heart and soul of the game. Following the rise of taxi driver Tommy Angelo through the ranks of the Salieri crime family during the Prohibition era, the story is a cinematic masterpiece. The remake not only preserves the compelling storytelling of the original but enhances it with added depth to characters, extended dialogues, and additional narrative layers.

Gameplay and Immersion : 10/10
The gameplay has been thoroughly modernized while preserving the essence of the original. Driving, shooting, and exploration feel polished, offering a seamless experience. The city of Lost Heaven is beautifully recreated with attention to detail, capturing the ambiance of the 1930s and providing an immersive backdrop for Tommy's journey.

Graphics and Atmosphere : 10/10
Visually, "Mafia: The Definitive Edition" is a triumph. The remade cityscape, character models, and environmental details showcase the capabilities of modern gaming technology. The atmospheric lighting, weather effects, and meticulous attention to period-specific details transport players to a bygone era, adding to the overall immersion.

Voice Acting and Soundtrack : 10/10
The voice acting remains stellar, with the cast delivering performances that breathe life into the characters. The original score has been re-recorded, and the soundtrack maintains its iconic jazz and swing elements, perfectly complementing the tone of the narrative and enhancing the overall experience.

Game Design : 10/10
The remake introduces refined game design elements, including improved combat mechanics and more diverse mission structures. The pacing is well-managed, and the integration of additional narrative content seamlessly fits into the original storyline. The attention to detail in recreating the era extends to the vehicles, clothing, and architecture, contributing to an authentic 1930s experience.

Nostalgia and Innovation : 10/10
For fans of the original "Mafia," the remake is a nostalgic journey that revitalizes cherished memories. The innovative enhancements, however, make it an equally enjoyable experience for newcomers. The delicate balance between nostalgia and modernization is a testament to the developers' understanding of what made the original a classic.

Conclusion : 10/10
"Mafia: The Definitive Edition" is not just a remake; it's a lovingly crafted reimagining that pays homage to the classic while elevating it to contemporary gaming standards. The gripping narrative, enhanced gameplay mechanics, and stunning visuals make it a must-play for both fans of the original and newcomers alike. In the realm of video game remakes, "Mafia: The Definitive Edition" stands as a shining example of how to honor a beloved classic while bringing it into a new era.

I was just starting high school when Mafia first came out. The game was great, but incredibly hard at the same time. I remember trying to pass the race mission for like a million times before finally calling it quits. With this remake, I got another shot at seeing the whole story of Mafia.
The mentioned story takes place during the time of prohibition (1930s) in the city of Lost Haven, somewhere in America. You are Thomas Angelo, a regular cab driver with Italian roots. Finding yourself in the right place at the wrong time, you meet Paulie and Sam, a couple of gangsters who drag you into the criminal underworld. 
There are two things this remake brings to the table: difficulty levels and improved graphics. I naively started the game at 'classic' difficulty, but was forced to tune it down when I got to the race mission (after I spent a couple of hours trying to pass it... it was even harder than I remember). The improved graphics are nice, but could have been nicer. The rest of the game is basically the same as in 2002 when it first came out. Be warned though, what was good in 2002 is pretty terrible today. Glitchy controls, retarded AI and rows upon rows of enemies you'll be showered with - that's what you should expect. Luckily the game has incredible story, great voice-acting and quality cut-scenes, otherwise it would be completely unworthy of playing. It's also pretty short and linear (which was a common thing 20 years ago), with almost no side-content beside main missions.
This remake could have been great. Instead, it feels like it was made only to make a quick buck with a little face-lift on a 20-year old game. I would recommend buying Mafia: Definitive Edition only if you like gangster movies and only if you find it on sale.

One of the most short but impactful single player games I have ever played, hands down. The first time I saw this game, I wishlisted it and waited till it was on sale. When I bought it, I never really expected much; but the beginning, it immediately hooked me. The setting felt so damn realistic, along with the small details such as your car radio losing signal under a bridge, really intrigued me. The most important part, though, was 100% the story. Told a classic noir story about a man who goes to many troubles in order to provide himself and his family a better life. The ending was quite tragic, but very meaningful, spreading the important message that family is your greatest weakness but also your greatest strength. This very well could end up being a gaming experience that I will never forget. Amazing storytelling, amazing gameplay, amazing setting. My only real gripe with this game is the slight performance issues at times, but they weren't a big nuisance nor gamebreaking. 

9/10 would recommend.

Mafia Definitive Edition is an amazing and immersive gaming experience that successfully resurrects the glory of a classic game. With stunning graphics and meticulous attention to detail, the game manages to recreate the dark and intrigue-filled world of the Prohibition era.

One of the most striking aspects of Mafia Definitive Edition is its distinctive atmosphere. The developers carefully crafted every corner of the city of Lost Heaven to fit the lifestyle of 1930s America. From vintage vehicles to period-appropriate clothing, everything exudes an authentic and deep sense of time and place.

The story is compelling and emotionally charged, with characters that feel truly alive. Players will engage in the tale of the protagonist, Tommy Angelo, and witness dramatic shifts in his life as he becomes entangled in the world of crime. The gripping narrative, experienced with genuine intensity, makes it difficult to relinquish control of the game.

The gameplay is highly satisfying, striking a good balance between action and role-playing elements. Diverse and challenging missions provide a non-monotonous experience, offering a variety of strategic choices to complete tasks.

Moreover, Mafia Definitive Edition updates its technical aspects. Updated graphics, high-quality sound, and an engaging soundtrack contribute to an overall captivating sensation.

In conclusion, Mafia Definitive Edition is not just a remake but also an artistic masterpiece that pays worthy homage to the original game. For gamers seeking a deep, emotionally resonant, and visually stunning experience, Mafia Definitive Edition is an excellent choice.
