A Deep Dive into Loyalty, Betrayal, and Family Bonds

Mafia: Definitive Edition, a masterful recreation of the 2002 classic, transcends mere nostalgia, presenting an enriched and visually stunning experience that, at its core, explores the intricate dynamics of loyalty and the profound importance of family.

The Rich Tapestry of Storytelling:

At the heart of this gripping narrative is Tommy Angelo, a taxi driver turned reluctant mobster whose journey into the criminal underworld of Lost Heaven unfolds with cinematic brilliance. The script, expertly voiced characters, and meticulous attention to detail in character development create a narrative tapestry that not only pays homage to the original but elevates it to contemporary storytelling standards.

Visual Splendor and Historical Authenticity:

The visual overhaul is nothing short of breathtaking. Lost Heaven, the game's setting, feels alive with the hustle and bustle of 1930s city life, and every frame reflects the glamour, grit, and authenticity of the era. From the architecture to the fashion, the developers have meticulously recreated a world that not only looks beautiful but feels immersive and historically grounded.

The Salieri Family:

The standout element that elevates Mafia: Definitive Edition is its exploration of family dynamics within the Salieri crime family. Unlike many crime sagas that dwell solely on the brutality of the underworld, this game takes the time to delve into the emotional intricacies of the relationships within the criminal fraternity.

The Salieri family isn't just a criminal organization; it's a tight-knit group bound by trust, shared experiences, and a profound sense of loyalty. Each character feels distinct and human, making the player genuinely care about their fates. The family is portrayed as more than just a collective of criminals; it's a surrogate family where bonds are forged in the crucible of danger and ambition.

The Significance of Family:

Tommy Angelo's journey, while laden with criminal endeavors, is fundamentally a quest for belonging and purpose. Amidst the chaos and danger of the mob, the game subtly underscores the importance of family as an anchor that keeps characters grounded. It's not just about rising through the ranks; it's a search for identity, belonging, and a sense of self in a world teetering on the edge of lawlessness.

Ambient Immersion and Emotional Resonance:

The game's atmospheric soundtrack, period-appropriate radio broadcasts, and meticulous attention to historical detail contribute to an immersive experience that transcends the gaming medium. It's not just playing a game; it's living in a meticulously crafted world that captures the essence of the 1930s.

In Conclusion:

Mafia: Definitive Edition is not merely a remake; it's a profound exploration of human connections in the tumultuous world of organized crime. Through its captivating narrative, visual brilliance, and nuanced portrayal of family bonds, it stands as a testament to the storytelling potential of video games. It's a journey that goes beyond the pursuit of power, reminding us that, even in the darkest of times, family is the thread that weaves through the complexities of loyalty, betrayal, and ultimately, redemption.

10 Hours of story gameplay only

Graphics: 8/10
Audio: 7/10
Story: 6/10
Gameplay: 5/10
AI: 4/10

> Mafia: Definitive Edition is not a bad game. It is a mediocre game with a mediocre story. The first half of the story is building up our character and the environment pretty well, but after the half of the game you can sense a feeling of rush, and therefore some plot elements makes no sense. But even with all it's failures, the story is decent, and you can pretty sure have fun with it. But I concur that after you beat the game for the first time, most people will not find go back to play it again. The game has no reason to make you play it twice. 

> The gamepley was clunky, especially when we travel on foot or shoot with our weapon. The driving is not bad, but the AI could have been better. Apparently they were designed in a certain way and don't notice the player's car at all. The shooting isn't satisfactory either. Even though the gun sounds were decent, it didn't make me feel like I am shooting with a weapon. 

> One of the other clunky part of the game was unfortunately the FPS. I played with a solid 90 FPS with ultra settings but the clunkiness of the game made me feel like I was playing with 40 FPS. Your movement feels slow, especially the camera speed and angles. Something definitely feels wrong.

> The voice acting: Our main character's voice acting feels so unnatural and forced. I know that voice acting is not an easy job, I have also had voice acting lessons but this is still not an excuse in my eyes. Every other character's voice felt natural, unless when Don Salieri speaks Italian; it felt very weird but other than that I have nothing bad to say about other voice actors. It is only that our protagonist that I have a problem with. 

> The music: The radio on cars were a good touch of the developers, but I would have wished to see a variety for music, especially in action scenes. To be honest, that one action music that plays in every mission and in every scene, whether goofy, sad, or happy or not, I am really bored with it. The last mission of the game should be dramatic, it should have evoked certain emotions in you, but instead we had this same, goofy action music playing on the background, and that's why I didn't feel the emotions that the developers tried to surface inside of me. I wished it could have been better, because that music part was really annoying. 

> One thing that also bothered me was the feeling of "finishing the game as quickly as possible and move on". Yes, that was a real issue for me. I can't talk about how other players felt but while I was playing the game I was able to barely tolerate two missions in one day. I just didn't want to play more than two missions because I have had already better games that awaited me around the corner. The game didn't make itself a priority for me like how it would make with other certain games. It turned into a chore for me to finish it, because let's be honest, I didn't want to keep a 50 GB, 10 hours worth video game for what I believed to be mediocre. I am so glad it is finished finally, but that doesn't mean I hate the game and I can't recommend other people when it is on sale. 

Conclusion: If you want to buy a Mafia game, you should definitely buy this one on sale. It is not a bad game. You can see that people behind this project tried their best. And I can say that they have managed to do a decent job, but don't expect a mind-blown experience. It will be a one-shot thing that maybe you will play it once in a year just for memories and action.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[u]Story[/u]
Compared to Mafia 2 & especially Mafia 3, this feels like a proper Mafioso story. Bootleggers trying to get that sweet liquid gold, while doing the occasional illegal act. [spoiler]As well as changing the ending twist for why Tommy & Paulie decide to go against their Don.[/spoiler]
[u]Voice acting[/u] 
Compared to the original, Tommy especially feels vastly improved. No disrespect to the original VA, but in this entry, you can better gauge Tommy's emotions; while in the original, he felt much more one-note.  
[u]Shorter Opening Taxi Section[/u]
The opening taxi section is much, much shorter. Allowing you to get on with the game. 
[u]Being able to skip optional driving[/u] 
Was nice being able to skip these on my Classic playthough, since I went right into that after finishing up getting all the collectibles on my Hard playthrough. 
[u]Gunplay & Cover System[/u]
You dive into cover swift and cleanly; as when you aim and fire.  
[u]Weapon Variety[/u]
Weapon variety isn't too large, yet not too small. Just the right amount that fits the current era. 
[u]Driving[/u]
I played with my transmissions being automatic, not manual. With that said, the driving felt smooth and responsive. I personally felt little to no difference between regular and simulation options, except the race. There you cannot brake as hard, or else you will spin out. 
[u]Movement & Sprint Speed[/u]
Sprint feels like an actual sprint, unlike Mafia 2's light jog. You [b]book it[/b] when you tell Tommy to!
[u]Collectibles Carry Over Playthroughs[/u]
Self-explanatory
[u]Chapter Select & Collectibles[/u]
If you missed any collectibles during a mission, you can simply select the chapter, find it and leave. 
[u]Ending feels much more realistic[/u] 
Unlike the original where it felt like some happy ending, this ones feels much more realistic and subtle. [spoiler]You see Tommy's rage at being sent away for 8 years. As well as the other characters being arrested. And they had Tommy go out with dignity; here he knows he's about to be killed and takes it with a smile.[/spoiler]

[h1]Neutrals[/h1]
[u]Extremely Simplistic Melee System[/u]
The melee system here is even more simplistic than Mafia 2's three button version. Here it's two, with a technical third, if you hold the attack button to do a "power attack"
[u]Reused finishing animations[/u]
You will see the same finishing animations quite often.  

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[u]Race[/u]
Anyone who has heard about Mafia knows about the dreaded race, and it hasn't changed here. It is just as difficult and time consuming as it was in the original. Only real difference is you don't die from a broken neck, if you roll your car over. But you might as well, as if you crash at all, you're going to lose. No ifs, ands, or buts. You have to be close to perfect in order to win the race. My initial Hard playthrough took me 2 hours. While my Classic took half an hour, which I'm going to credit to me immediately going into it after my Hard playthrough. I understand it's to remain faithful to the Original, but come on... There was no reason that it had to remain as hard as it did.
[u]Death Screen Takes 5 Seconds to complete[/u] 
5 seconds doesn't sound like a lot, but if you're stuck on a section, it can seem like an eternity. 
[u]Some story beats feel odd/missing[/u]
You'll notice there's no real side stuff brought up. You're never really told when Tommy marries Sarah, have a daughter or get their house, unless you're really paying attention to the conversations that can potentially be missed. 
[u]No Backstory on Tommy except at the very end[/u] 
I understand not everyone cares about character's backstories, but it would have been nice to learn some throughout the story. You instead only really learn about Tommy's past if you read notes in his house in the very last chapter. Notes you can miss, if you speed out of his house and go to the Art Gallery. 
[u]No long-term Wanted System[/u]
If you shake the police both on foot and in your vehicle, you'll be free to walk/drive right by the same Police Officers who were chasing you seconds ago and nothing will happen. It would have been nice for the team to implement that same Wanted system as they had in Mafia 2. I.E. Remembering your car's plates or what you look like. My main reason for this criticism is after you [spoiler]assassinate Turnbull,[/spoiler] you can literally run back to where you make your initial entry into the building. Hide there till the police give up their chase and literally run back out where you came in from, past those officers and end the mission. Seems rather silly. 
[u]Fox Collectibles[/u]
These feel unbelievably tacked on and an excuse to make the player explore the map. The countryside, especially. 
[u]Some weapons feel underpowered[/u] 
Tommy Gun takes a quarter to half a magazine to kill via bodyshots. 
Magnum (Yes, a MAGNUM REVOLVER of all guns) takes 3 bodyshots to kill. 
[u]Tommy Gun does not sound tough enough[/u]
One of the most iconic weapons of American history and it sounds like a peashooter. 
[u][spoiler]Joe[/spoiler] looks terrible in the ending cutscene[/u]
This is a nitpick, I know. But c'mon... Tell me he doesn't look awful compared to his original design...

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Despite my large list of cons, it's still a good game that I recommend. Everything is vastly improved, compared to the original release. Only warning is to be ready to edure a hell that is Chapter 4/The Race. Once you get past that, it is smooth sailing.

It truly breaks my heart to have to give this game a negative review. Neutral would be much more fitting, but alas, no such option exists. The story is genuinely incredible. But I cannot, in good conscience, recommend a game that feels as incomplete and botched as this one does. The reality is, this game is more like a movie, except every couple of minutes you have to play a jank-ass minigame to progress.

The story really is the biggest thing this game has going for it; perfect for those who love those typical mob vibes. Now I must say, the old version's gameplay was downright horrific; janky engine, unintuitive controls, the whole lot. So I think it's safe to say that the Definitive Edition has come leaps and bounds over the original in some respects. 

However, I would be lying if I said its gameplay is good by any metric; there are many glaring issues that make it frustrating to play at best. The engine is jank as all hell, the controls have stupid mappings (and changing them makes certain enemies unkillable, ask me how I know), and the god-awful mouse acceleration cannot be turned off and makes shooting a disgustingly bad experience, to name a few. Overall, they did make [i] some [/i] progress towards fixing these issues over the original game, but it feels more like a low effort reskin of an old game, rather than a fix of the archaic museum piece that Mafia is. 

Mafia II was a far better game, in my opinion, in almost every respect, and I do think that anyone looking to experience the thrills like Mafia II's again will be disappointed in Mafia: DE. Just about every part of this game is frustrating and immersion breaking; the fistfighting is clunky, the controls don't make any sense, and the enemies don't seem very balanced. Most games will make you tougher to compensate for how many enemies you have to kill. For whatever reason, it feels like Mafia has taken the opposite approach, making you eat sh*t with every bullet you take, while you get nothing but your limp d*ck. It makes it very hard not to die, and this game will make you sit through 20 seconds of watching Tommy flop to the ground, followed by the most braindead loading screen known to man before letting you get back into action. There are a couple missions that beg to reduce their difficulty, because beating them is not a challenge, it's a middle finger to you and your skills. 

Now I cannot entirely blame the devs for the way this game feels. It is reminiscent of the original Mafia's gameplay experience, and this presents the dilemma: do they keep some of the original ([i] highly [/i] questionable) design choices to be truthful to the original game, or do they change them to emulate a better execution (like Mafia II's), thus sacrificing the identity of the game, and perhaps even the freshness of experiencing a new playstyle? Me personally, I don't consider the jank to be part of the original charm, so keeping it around is not a plus. But they managed to cut a bunch of what made the older game as immersive as it was, like side quests, the driving missions, the enterable shops and public transport. All of the worldbuilding that was [i] already done for them [/i] was just tossed away, and the game feels a lot more barebones because of it.

The graphics and sounds truly are better than the original by miles; this is doubly so the case the cars. But I feel like I'm mostly just spending time comparing this game to its predecessor, which, regrettably, speaks volumes to the execution of this remaster, let alone to its merit as a standalone game. I want to like it, because good mob stories just fill that gap in the heart. But to rework a game as much as they did, and for [i] this [/i] to be all that they have to show for it, I am not impressed.

It's classy, it's beautiful, it's something that every Mafia fan could hope for. Or is it? I've been pondering this question when I played this cinematic triumph from beginning to the credits and while everything is covered it still misses that tiny detail what made original Mafia so special - and yet again I could state that this remake trusts on its own values and doesn't stick in 20 years old formula. 

Speaking of formula, one big difference between the games is a racing mission, that really reflects the distance between the games in a bigger picture as well. In this Definitive Edition it was many times more arcade - still challenging, but much more forgiving. If you made f.ex. a tiny mistake and hit the wall no harm done and back the track but in original Mafia the axle between the tire and trunk would bend causing wobbling tire and ruining the race. More laughable thing in the game was that if your car turns over you can use your Baron von Munchausen powers and magically flip the vehicle on its right side. In original of course this led to brutal death for poor Tommy being crushed between the track and the seat.

So I do say that the Definitive Edition is made much more user friendly, also the checkpoints are pretty frequent and losing the cops is much simpler and even less enjoyable. However this comes with the pros as well - fighting system isn't perfect, but still a lot better than random change of fists in the first one, also many of the unnecessary dull parts have been cut like planning of the bank robbery for in the remake it is much more smoother and the whole episode can be done swifter than the loong travel with the Paulie in the original. Shame that they erased Yellow Pete. Not to mention the Free Ride Extreme mode. They really did not hesitate to use the scissors for dozens of miles of driving has been completely erased, replaced by cutscenes, saving passive playtime for some, but taking away fun exploring time from others. Many cases when I sighted something missing I felt controversial - I did not like it always, but occasionally I understood the changes. I never were mad, but more like baffled. What I can't forgive that I never heard Django Reinhardt's 'Belleville' from the radio though.

And what about the tiny detail, which I mentioned in the beginning? How to define that? Is it the nostalgia? Perhaps, but I believe it is more in how they changed the story's philosophy. What made Mafia so unforgettable masterpiece was the story of doing right and wrong, being a good or bad person, is the love and friendship worth shit? Changes in script has ripped a hole into the game's soul, but has been replaced with something that is as worthy as the matter which is now gone. There is no knots and loose ends are shut.

I'd like to image original Mafia as elder Don seeing his legacy being turned more glamorous than ever before, but missing the respect and honor which were very fond to him. However, this young gogetter Remake sees that all of it is still in there, respecting the legacy, but making the details into its own image. This is Mafia of the third decade standing on its own feet and the original 2002 one remains still one of the best games ever done! If I were you I'd play both of them through and then decide.

I enjoyed this game a lot more than I thought I would have. First of all, I opened the game and there were 4 options to choose from: easy, medium, hard and classic- I played classic at first and played it for the majority of the game and did not regret my choice (except for the driving bit where I tried for what felt like hours before giving up and swapping it to easy..) There is also the option to change difficulties at any point however changing from classic to anything else and then back again will get rid of the "Win Classic Mode" badge thing.

The game brings you back to the 1930's in America with it being historically accurate - from the drinking bans to the mafia gang break outs - it accurately depicts the life of Italian bandits during the great Depression and takes you through the story of Tommy Angelo with flash forwards to bring his story together.  The game took you through twists and turns, heartbreaks and betrayal and I loved how they pulled everything together at the end. 

The game's graphics were really good with the characters looking almost human like in the cut scenes (obviously you could tell they were from a game) and continued to be this good throughout the whole game. I did have a problem with the end scene/ epilogue which was glitching a bit though. Even the mouths moving looked like they were actually saying the words which made the game more realistic. It was the perfect mix between story and action!


"Remember that money, jobs, even best pals will come and go. But family? Family is forever." - Tommy Angelo

SPOILER: The epilogue was my favourite bit I think. Just the fact that we saw Sarah and Tommy get old together and Tommy walking their daughter down the isle melted my heart. I loved how they made his speech cover the scenes that were happening in the background so not only did we know what happened to Tommy and Sarah, we also knew what happened to other people - I also loved the sound affects and the sombre music that was playing among his speech. The last bit did break my heart though with Tommy dying but it also somewhat brings the whole thing together, especially with the whole family surrounding him at the end comparing that to him being a lonely taxi driver with no one at the beginning.

Let me preface this review by saying I am a hardcore purist who generally hates remakes and has played the original game this is based on. That clarification out of the way: this is a solid remake I'd recommend to most people over the original (which is really the highest praise I can give a remake). TL;DR it's a solid 8/10 with a great story that has been retold with skill and reverence for the original. Not perfect, but worth the 14 hours I spent.

Now, for those who like more detail, let's get into the weeds.

There's some Eurojank in here, namely the AI is pretty rough when it comes to anything (combat, traffic, heck even just pedestrians crossing the street act weird) and also the movement system isn't as polished as something you'd get in a Rockstar game. But, those flaws aside it's a well done retelling of pretty solid video game plot for the time it was released. You may feel something by the end of this, and while that feeling may be frustration at some of the later segments of the game when the rough edges of the movement system and AI start to show themselves as the challenges ramp up, it's much more likely it will be a feeling of sorrow at the fate of the trio of men at the center of the story's narrative.

And narrative is king here, the gameplay doesn't overstay it's welcome unless you drop into the free ride sandbox mode (which is pretty fun, do recommend checking it out, a good place to practice driving if you're struggling as well). The game it's self is a quick ride, I beat it in about 14 hours according to steam and that's including time messing around in sandbox. The story is what you're paying your ticket for, as are the generally nice visuals. Voice acting is solid as well and specifically I really like Paulie's voice actor who made me care way more about the character than I did in my run of the original (though I do miss Tommy's original voice actor, guy was aces).

Gameplay-wise the shooting is passable, but really what makes this game worth a recommendation over the original is the inclusion of more modern systems such as cover and improved stealth. The original was an ambitious game and would lay the groundwork for titles like GTA:SA that would add stealth systems to the open world crime genre, but suffice to say those clunky old stealth systems that feel like they were made in an afternoon of coding can be rough today. This system isn't the best but is solid enough that I found myself rarely reloading due to botched stealth, probably a bit too forgiving but for a more casual game like this that's just right really.

Driving is phenomenal and you can tell is the part of the engine they spent the most time on (which is funny because then they let you skip driving to and between missions like they were ashamed of it, that poor programmer haha). Specifically I really liked the manual drive and recommend playing that way if you want a little more challenge. Learning what gear does what on what terrain was a cool revelation moment and felt very natural aside from me ALWAYS forgetting how to reverse for a quarter second (I blame decades of GTA). It takes getting used to and the real test was that race but it adds a lot of character to the driving, and is very true to the original experience. Also of note is that not every car has the same handling or gear set-up, which really adds another nice level of detail to the world. For example the slick four door luxury in 2nd gear is gonna be going pretty fast while at the same time getting good handling for hills and turns, meanwhile the clunky work truck in 2nd is gonna struggle to get speed but will handle pretty nicely (and it's 3rd gear will be closer to the luxury's 2nd).

Mission structure is pretty solid. Unless I'm mistaken they removed some stuff from the original and also added a bit, but for the most part it hits the same important beats. Some of the changes felt unneeded, but some of the narrative ones felt like they added a lot.

In the end every remake is going to have issues, you can't recreate a game decades after it's release and end up with the exact same product. We will see if this changes because of modern games being so polished, but I have my doubts any true remake will ever be 1:1. Teams change, times change, and people change. The trick with Remakes is recapturing that original spirit and remaining largely true to the original vision while innovating and changing enough to reinvigorate the experience.

Mafia: Definitive Edition manages to deliver what seems to be an increasingly hard thing these days; A captivating solid remake of the original that stays true to the source while knowing what it wanted to accomplish too.

This is one of the games that makes me wish Steam allows me to make a neutral review. As someone who played the original, the Definitive Edition leaves much to be desired.

The graphics and environment are absolutely stunning. Yet, the game feels stripped of purposes to explore. Storyline no longer takes you all around the city; Many driving of the missions are skipped with cutscenes; The side quests from Lucas Bertone are gone. The public transport from the original are barred from us now. All in all it's a shame that the developers cut these contents that make the original so beloved.

In fact, imo, the DE lacks details of the original level. Of course, the city and the graphics give much more details visually. But the details in the stories and the details in the gameplay are gone. Replacing them are the overtly-hand holding that makes the game feels more like a film. The original shines as it allows you to make your own choices from time to time; For instance, in the mission Molotov party, you can choose to block the backdoor of the bar with a crate to earn yourself a few more minutes before you wreck the cars. In the same mission, a better car that you can collect is hidden in a garage. The remake, however, directly point you to that car. Another example is Visiting Rich People, in the origin you can have Salvatore to pick the prosecutor's car for you (which also teaches you how to pick that specific car). This is entirely optional and requires player's thinking. Or in the Running Man, where u can tell a lady who is waiting in an alley that her date got the address wrong as you found him earlier in another similar alley. In Definitive Edition? These are all gone. The mission feels short as it forcefully holds your hand and strips you of freedom to explore the levels. This strips players like me the sense of achievement when I finish the mission in different ways (and succeed in doing so).

I like the developers' attempt to give characters more depth. But the drastic change in terms of personalities sometimes feels a bit too much. The reduction of missions doesn't help either as characters feels much less relatable, namely Ralph and Lucas. Especially since their function in game is mostly gone now. However, I do applaud the developers's effort in trying to give more insights of the era with the additional or changed dialogue.

Mafia 3's combat system is not something I like at all, but it is acceptable. With the classic difficulties, it does prove to be a fun challenge to manage your resources. So I would say the gun play is much more modern and enjoyable than the original.

All in all, Mafia: Definitive Edition has its merits, but loses on many other aspects that made the original Mafia so praised and loved. The game feels rushed, and there are many contents that felt like they were cut at the last minute. I recommend waiting for a sale at least at 50%.

Edit #1: Grammar, spellings, etc. Confirmed that in Running Man you can talk to the lady; My mistakes, and many thanks to @steve who mentioned it in the comment.

Low on features, dead open world with little to no interactivity. I realize Hangar 13 wanted to keep faithful to the original, but damn add some side activities or open world interactivity! Most annoying parts are the stealth missions with terrible stealth mechanics, they are almost exactly the same as the MJ missions in Spider-man PS4, except there is no way to distract guards, and someone usually always has line of sight on you.

Overall Mafia II is still a much better game. Hangar 13 had the chance to make this something truly special, but it seems they were burnt out after designing the open world. I would recommend just playing Mafia II, and watching a play through of Mafia Definitive Edition on YouTube.

Overall, the game is solid and adequately makes you feel like a Mafia badass. But still there are a lot of areas where it falls short. At the end of the day, this is just a game from 2002 with a fresh coat of paint. And that coat of paint is very very good don't get me wrong (see GTA definitive editions for an example of the same idea executed horribly), but the core gameplay feels very dated to me. My biggest gripe here is with gunplay. It's just so unsatisfying. You'll shoot an enemy anywhere but the head and he won't even react to it. Feels like my guy is firing an airsoft gun not a deadly firearm. I was willing to excuse dated level design on account of the game being 20 years old, but the gunplay and clunky movement should have been fixed in the remaster. 

At the end of the day it was fun, but I get the feeling of a lot of missed potential. The open world is so cool and interesting to look at from afar, but there's really not much to it, it's just a backdrop. The story is great and well written, but the gameplay doesn't really excite that much. I'd recommend if it's on sale but otherwise I think you'd be better off just watching The Godfather or Goodfellas.

I recently had the unfortunate experience of playing Mafia: Definitive Edition, and I must say that my overall impression of the game is far from positive. The game promised a nostalgic journey through the world of organized crime, but it ultimately left me frustrated and disappointed, thanks in no small part to the abysmal race mission.

Let's start with the gameplay mechanics, which are a mess. The controls feel clunky and unresponsive, making it incredibly challenging to navigate through the poorly designed streets of Lost Heaven. The handling of the vehicles is downright atrocious, with a lack of precision that leads to constant collisions and frustration. It's as if the developers wanted to recreate the feel of driving a tank rather than a classic car.

Now, let's address the elephant in the room—the race mission. This particular segment of the game is an absolute disaster. The difficulty level is outrageously high, and it seems the developers completely overlooked the fact that players should enjoy the game, not suffer through it. The rubber-banding AI is infuriating, as opponents magically catch up and overtake you, no matter how flawlessly you drive. The result is a maddening loop of frustration that forces players to replay the same section ad nauseam.

To make matters worse, the race mission is a clear example of poor game design. The narrow streets and tight turns make it nearly impossible to maintain any kind of lead, and the constant need for flawless execution leaves no room for strategic or enjoyable gameplay. It's a shame that such a poorly designed mission tarnishes what could have been a decent remake of a classic title.

All in all, Mafia: Definitive Edition falls short of its promise, and the horrible race mission is a glaring example of the game's failings. The frustrating gameplay mechanics and lackluster design choices make it difficult to recommend this title to anyone seeking an enjoyable gaming experience. Save yourself the headache and look elsewhere for a more satisfying trip down memory lane.

A Masterful Remake at an Unbeatable Price!

I recently had the pleasure of diving into the world of Mafia: Definitive Edition, and I must say, it exceeded all my expectations. Purchased at a mere $10 during a fantastic discount, this remake of the original Mafia is an absolute steal.

From the moment I started playing, it was evident that Hangar 13 put a tremendous amount of effort into revitalizing this classic title. The graphics are stunning, breathing new life into the city of Lost Heaven with meticulous attention to detail. The character models, environments, and even the vintage cars exude a level of authenticity that immerses you completely in the 1930s setting.

The narrative, which was already a strong point in the original Mafia, has been masterfully reimagined. The storytelling is gripping, with well-developed characters and a plot that keeps you on the edge of your seat. Voice acting is top-notch, capturing the essence of the era and the personalities of each character. The cinematic sequences are a treat to watch, seamlessly blending with the gameplay to create a truly cinematic experience.

Gameplay-wise, Mafia: Definitive Edition strikes a perfect balance between modern gaming conveniences and the nostalgic feel of the original. The controls are intuitive, making it easy for both newcomers and fans of the original to pick up and play. The shooting mechanics are satisfying, and the driving sequences are a joy, offering a mix of exhilarating chases and leisurely rides through the beautifully crafted city.

What truly sets this remake apart is the love and respect it pays to the source material. The developers have not only enhanced the visuals and gameplay but also retained the essence of what made the original Mafia a classic. The attention to detail in recreating the atmosphere, music, and even the little nuances of the characters' movements showcases a deep understanding and appreciation for the original game.

Considering the depth of content, the quality of the remake, and the sheer enjoyment I've derived from Mafia: Definitive Edition, the $10 price tag feels like daylight robbery (in a good way!). It's a testament to the developers' commitment to delivering an outstanding gaming experience without breaking the bank.

In conclusion, if you're a fan of the original Mafia or someone looking to experience a gripping crime drama in a beautifully reimagined world, Mafia: Definitive Edition is an absolute must-buy, especially when snagged at such an incredible discount. Don't miss out on this gem that seamlessly blends the best of the past with the conveniences of the present gaming landscape. It's a journey back in time that's well worth the investment!

Mafia Definitive Edition delivers an extraordinary gaming experience, seamlessly blending an exceptional story with truly amazing remastered visuals. This reimagined classic takes players on a captivating journey back to the 1930s, offering a taste of the past with a modern touch.

For those yearning to experience the charm and grit of the 1930s, Mafia Definitive Edition is highly recommended. The game successfully transports players to a bygone era, allowing them to explore a meticulously recreated world filled with intrigue and danger.

Additionally, Mafia Definitive Edition becomes an even greater value when purchased during sales. Given the game's exceptional storytelling, stunning visuals, and immersive gameplay, it stands out as a must-have for both fans of the original and newcomers alike. Don't miss the chance to grab this gem at a discounted price and embark on a memorable journey into the heart of the 1930s.

There are games which are called remakes, remasters, reboots, reworks, this edition, that edition AND there's this game. 2K made a completely new game and I'm honestly surprised how they pulled this off. The original game (even though it looked impressive for its era) looks like something you would order from Wish compared to this game.

The game is very faithful to its original with a few additions to help you discover sub-plots or some scenes that felt underwhelming. The voice lines are completely new, the motion capture quality is insane (not uncharted 4 level but it's still damn good), there are new locations to discover, new secrets to find... pretty much every single thing is brand new except the story. I was not a strong fan of the original game, always liked the second game more but with this new game, I feel like now I can embrace it with all its glory. 

The optimization is all over the place, it's a bit dicey whether you'll have a problem or not but if you stick around for a couple of hours, the game can easily compensate for the annoying issues. If you have a 144hz monitor with an Nvidia GPU, what you need to do is > 
Open the Nvidia Control Panel > Manage 3D Settings > Program Settings > Either add manually or select the game from the menu > Change preferred refresh rate to highest available. This will allow you to play the game (or rather allow you to) fullscreen 144hz. Otherwise, it sends you back to the desktop unless you Alt+Enter and open windowed mode.

And finally, the car race part is still extremely annoying if you don't change the driving settings to regular from simulation. You might lose a couple of hours getting frustrated for nothing. All in all, though, I strongly recommend not sleeping on this game.

-Graphics and environment detail are great

Cons:
-Bad performance

-Set pieces during missions are clunky, buggy or downright broken. If you diverge even slightly from the intended path the missions mostly fall apart.
-No character customization whatsoever from what I've experienced.
-Controls are horrible for mouse+keyboard and key rebinds offer only very basic options. (Who had the brilliant idea of toggling back from WALK to RUN every time you stop moving? Completely ridiculous).

I still remember the first time I fell in love with the world of Mafia running the original entry on my aunt's laptop during a sleepover. The game was not even mine. It was a second hand present from my old cousin who loved it and recommended it to try it. I was 12 back then (yes, underage, sue me ;))

Almost two decades later, we had the opportunity to relive the original (and great) story with updated graphics, and the experience was overall very satisfactory.

The story presents slight tweaks on the story, which were not needed, and I would personally have enjoyed more an even more replica of the original drama, but the new one is quite nice nonetheless. The graphics are more than sufficient to appreciate the beauty of NY (Or Lost Heaven) of the early 30s, and the gameplay satisfies but does not reinvent. I don't need reinvention on a remake, so works for me.

The cars are beautiful, and the feeling of entering accidentally in the Salieri Family is as interesting as it ever was.

The one thing I miss on this remake, is the Free Ride and Free Ride Extreme. They were great additions, specially the later. A reinvented game mode for that would have been cherry on top.

I don't recommend this game any less because of the flaws listed above, and if you are a lover of mafia games, or yet better, of Mafia, don't miss this one!

Of course, you won’t get the same emotions that you got from the original Mafia in 2002. But still, how good it is to return to Lost Heaven and relive the story of Tommy Angelo!

[h3] Pros [/h3]
[list]
[*] Amazing graphics (the nights are simply a treat for the eyes).
[*] Good soundtrack.
[*] Redesigned game mechanics only complement the atmosphere of the 1930s.
[/list]

[h3] Cons [/h3]
[list]
[*] There are differences in some plot points with the original Mafia.
[*] Side missions are completed very quickly, and then the game begins for those who will enjoy a simple drive through an American city in the 1930s.
[/list]

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
If you are a fan of the original Mafia, then the game may disappoint you in terms of the plot, but not in terms of graphics or the world itself (as you progress through the story). If you have not played the 2002 Mafia before, sure, play the remake, and then if Tommy’s story touches you, maybe you’ll decide to go through the original and understand why the same old Mafia of 2002 is so loved.

Mafia: Definitive Edition offers an immersive reimagining of the classic 2002 game, plunging players into the intricacies of 1930s organized crime. As Tommy Angelo, a cab driver unexpectedly drawn into the Salieri crime family, players navigate a gripping tale of loyalty, betrayal, and redemption. The game, rebuilt from the ground up, boasts modern graphics, enhanced gameplay, and new features like a free ride mode and collectibles, capturing the era's essence through authentic cars, weapons, music, and outfits. It's a cinematic experience for fans of the original and newcomers alike, standing as a remarkable remake in the action-adventure genre.

However, the game isn't without its drawbacks. One notable issue is its length; Mafia: Definitive Edition is relatively short compared to other games in its genre. This brevity might leave players wanting more, especially those accustomed to expansive open-world games with numerous side quests and a lengthy main storyline. The game's focus on the main quest, while ensuring a tightly knit and story-driven experience, also means there's a lack of side quests. This absence of additional content can be seen as a missed opportunity to explore more of the richly recreated world and its characters.

While the main quest is excellently crafted and provides a compelling narrative, the game's short duration and lack of side content might not satisfy players seeking a more prolonged gaming experience with ample exploration opportunities. In this respect, Mafia: Definitive Edition might feel limited to those who enjoy diving deep into side quests and spending many hours in a game world.

In summary, Mafia: Definitive Edition excels in delivering a visually stunning and narratively engaging experience that faithfully captures the spirit of the 1930s and the original game. However, its relatively short playtime and the absence of side quests may leave some players desiring more content and depth. Despite this, it remains a must-play for fans of the series and those who appreciate action-adventure games with a strong focus on storytelling.

* Well-designed, loyal remake, sticked to the og one.
* Map, car and costume design.
* Changes with cutscenes and episodes compared to og Mafia

* Enhanced accessebility options, you can turn off some features that were in the original Mafia, also you can skip some unnecessary ride sequences.
* Musics

[h1]CONS[/h1]
* Animations that may feel like they're bugs, while running, jumping and changing weapons. Also they felt old despite game has decent driving mechanics.
* Lack of weapon variety.
* Traditional mission format.
* Episode transitions.
* It must have been longer.

[h3]Introduction and General Impressions[/h3]

The original Mafia game was an exceptional title, but this Definitive Edition takes a classic and elevates it to something truly extraordinary. While the game remains true to the original storyline, its significant enhancements in various aspects make it a compelling experience for both newcomers and those familiar with the original.

[h3]Enhanced Controls and Accessibility[/h3]

One of the notable improvements in the Definitive Edition is the game's control mechanism. The controls are more intuitive and responsive, significantly enhancing the gameplay experience. The seamless transition between a controller and keyboard/mouse, including the updated in-game button icons, adds a layer of user-friendly design that is much appreciated. This flexibility, particularly when switching from foot to vehicle sections, elevates the gaming experience.

[h3]Audio and Music Upgrades[/h3]

The audio in the Definitive Edition has been meticulously upgraded. The music remains faithful to the original’s tone but has been beautifully remastered, resulting in a richer and more immersive auditory experience. The enhanced sound quality adds depth to every scene, drawing players deeper into the game's atmospheric world.

[h3]Storytelling and Character Depth[/h3]

While the core content of the game remains unchanged, there are subtle yet impactful enhancements in how the story is told and how the characters are developed. These changes add more depth to the characters and give a fresh perspective to the narrative, enriching the overall storytelling experience. This aspect makes the game even more engaging, especially for those who are revisiting the story from the original game.

[h3]Graphic Excellence and Cityscape Visualization[/h3]

A standout feature of the Definitive Edition is the stunning graphical overhaul. The city, a central element of the game, is breathtakingly realized with meticulous attention to detail. The lighting, textures, and overall visual presentation are of the highest quality, making every part of the city, from quiet alleys to bustling streets, come alive. This attention to graphical detail extends to character models, vehicles, and environmental elements, creating a cohesive and immersive world that is both visually impressive and highly engaging.

[h3]Performance[/h3]

On the technical front, the game performs exceptionally well. Running the game at max settings in 1440p on a 5700XT results in smooth, uninterrupted gameplay. This level of performance ensures that players can fully enjoy the beautifully recreated world of Mafia without technical distractions.

[h3]Conclusion[/h3]

Mafia: Definitive Edition is not merely a remaster but a comprehensive overhaul that significantly enhances an already great game. The combination of improved visuals, refined controls, enhanced audio, and deeper storytelling makes it a must-play title. Whether you are experiencing Mafia for the first time or revisiting this classic, the Definitive Edition offers a complete, immersive, and nostalgic experience that stands out as a benchmark for how remakes should be done.

A Captivating Remake with Some Bumps Along the Way

Mafia Definitive Edition is a game that's got me all nostalgic and excited about the gangster world of the 1930s, but it's not without its share of hiccups. Here's my take on this remastered classic:

First of all, the visual overhaul in Mafia Definitive Edition is nothing short of impressive. The city of Lost Heaven looks stunning, and the attention to detail is astonishing. The characters, cars, and even the clothing feel like they've been transported straight from the '30s. It's a love letter to the era, and I couldn't be happier with how it looks.

The story is where Mafia truly shines. Tommy Angelo's journey from a simple cab driver to a feared mobster is compelling and engaging. The narrative is gripping, and the voice acting is top-notch. It's like being in a classic gangster movie, and I couldn't get enough of it.

However, there are a few rough edges. The gameplay, while generally solid, can feel a bit dated at times. Gunfights can be a tad frustrating, with some wonky hit detection, and the AI of both your allies and enemies leaves something to be desired. The controls, especially on a controller, can take some getting used to.

Another minor complaint is the lack of modern quality-of-life features. Fast travel could have been a real time-saver, and the mission structure, while well-crafted, can sometimes feel a bit repetitive.

In the end, Mafia Definitive Edition is a fantastic experience if you're looking for a slice of the '30s gangster life. The story and visuals are its strong suits, but it does stumble a bit in the gameplay department. If you can overlook these minor issues and are ready for a trip back in time, this game is well worth the ride. Just remember, it's not without its share of bumps on the road to the top.

I know some of those features weren't in the original and I can see how some might argue that they neither belong in the remake.

[h1] [b]  Mafia: Definitive Edition [/b] [/h1]

Out with the old and in with the new, eh? Mafia: Definitive edition breathes a whole new breath of life into a game we all thought we would never see again. A remaster of the 2002 classic, is is worth your time, or your dough? Lets get into it.

[h1] [b] The Good [/b] [/h1]

[b] [*] The Graphics [/b]

- Rarely ever my first point, but in a remaster of this caliber? Oh yeah, its a big point. This game was originally released in 2002... which is about nineteen years ago. This is an [i] old [/i] game. Point is, we're talking about a game that had around PS2 or original Xbox level quality, for reference. It looked just horrible. Somehow, through what I imagine to be a horrifying amount of work, it has been turned into one of the most beautiful and realistic games that I've played this year. It literally is just a whole new game now. 

[b] [*] The Story and Characters [/b]

- There's nothing quite like a game with an enthralling story and characters that both warm your heart, and dig in under your skin. Mafia is one of these rare games, a game that truly captures the essence of humanity. No cheap, gimmicky characters that are just two-dimensional stereotypes. Each and every character has depth, and much more to the that meets the eye. Truly a master of storytelling. 

[b] [*]The World [/b]

- I'm a sucker for a good setting. Taking place in the city of Lost Heaven, Mafia gives the player a whole new wide-open world for them to explore, along with a special game-mode called "freeride" which is purely focused on exploration. Its a big, beautiful world out there, and its yours to explore. 

[b] [*]The Ranged Combat [/b]

- The Mafia game's are known for their combat, specifically just how fun and simple they make blowing someone away. This remaster just makes it a bit more fun, with new weapon mechanics applied and updated combat to make gunning down the rival gangs and police of Lost Heaven just that bit more fun. You might wonder why I mentioned the ranged combat specifically, well...

[h1] [b] The Bad [/b] [/h1]

[b] [*] The Melee Combat [/b]

- It is just... atrocious. On the "good" side, it is literally just spamming Q, or whatever key you bind. On the bad side, it is completely unresponsive and built around a horrid and broken counter system. To melee attack an enemy, you must counter them. It doesn't matter if you swung first, they're not attacking, or you are literally watching your baseball bat connect with their skull, if you don't wait for them to attack first to counter and stun them, your attack will not count. It is so pathetically broken. Not a big deal, as you can just pull out your gat and blow 'em away, but I see what they did. They thought they could get away with an unfinished melee system. Nah

[b] [*]The Length [/b]

- Now this isn't a complaint, complaint. This is more of a "be aware of this". Sure, they ain't charging $60 for this, but they are asking for around $30. Thing is though, without hunting all collectibles down (which aren't that cool, anyway) this game is truly around 10 hours long. $30 for a 10 hour game? I don't regret it, as I loved the game, but I don't feel great about it. A common complaint about remasters. 

[h1] [b] The Ugly [/b] [/h1]

[b] [*] The Vehicles and Vehicular Combat [/b]

- Somebody shoot me. 90% of the driving and vehicles in Mafia: Definitive Edition are just horrible. Every car acts like they're the main star of Tokyo Drift, clipping anything makes you take immense damage and lose all speed and momentum (not how physics work!) and is over all infuriating. Its literally only tolerable to drift with around 3 or 4 of the 40+ vehicles available.

[h1] [b] Overall [/b] [/h1]

Mafia: Definitive Edition is an amazing example of a remaster. It is actually one of the best looking remasters I've ever seen, and legitimately looks like a whole new game. Most of the combat is quite fun, and the story/characters are memorable, plus more. The only downsides are opinion-based, such as driving and what-not. I would truly recommend this to anyone who wants to play. A prime example of what a remaster should be.

[h1]You're like that dog Tommy, every time you flash your money around, you're a b*tch in heat, and everyone in that club is now looking to f*ck you, and once you get f*cked, you're no good to us[/h1]

Not many games leave a lasting impact on me, but I’d be damned if I never told you that [b]Mafia[/b], which has to be one of the greatest games I have ever played. It has a fantastic story with some stellar gameplay to go along with it. I should note that I have not played the original from 2002, so the [b]Definitive Edition[/b] is the only version that I have played.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]Fantastic crime drama story with amazing characters
[*]Stellar gameplay with some nice weapons
[*]A big open world to drive around in
[*]Beautiful graphics that give off that rich mid 1930’s feel
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]Lock-on was a bit clunky during car chases
[*]Obnoxious bug that will unintentionally fire your gun when aiming
[*]Other minor bugs
[/list]

[h1]Story[/h1]
The year is 1930, [b]Tommy Angelo[/b] is a struggling taxi driver during [b]The Great Depression[/b], one night he was strong-armed into helping two members of the [b]Selleri[/b] crime family. After saving both [b]Paulie Lombardo[/b] and [b]Sam Trapani[/b] from a rival mafia gang, [b]Tommy[/b] is rewarded for his help and is offered a position thanks to [b]Don’s Ennio[/b] organization. [b]Tommy[/b] is reluctant at first, however, the rewards he starts to get end up being too big to ignore. However, he also starts to get into more dangerous jobs that also increase in risk.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3065652962
The story for [b]Mafia[/b] is fantastic, it manages to create a very nice and enjoyable crime drama and I love the chemistry between the characters. The trio you get is all just enjoyable and at times they have a charm that makes them special. The story really starts to shine in the later parts of the game, but I can’t explain it due to spoilers, so you will just have to take it from me and this review.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]Mafia: Definitive Edition[/b] has some new things to it that make it different from the original, one of the new features of the game is that you can now ride motorcycles, which is a first for the series. The gameplay mechanics are mostly based on the 3rd game in the series, including the classic difficulty, where ammo is managed differently, and police respond to crimes more frequently. There is also a [b]free ride mode[/b], where you can take part in side missions, there are also some taxi missions and a racing mode for you to access too.

During missions, you will be thrust into combat-based missions, some of them require melee but the large majority of them will make you use guns for various reasons. There are a few nice weapons for you to use but my favorite has to be the [b]Tommy Gun[/b]. It actually made me feel like I was in the 1930s and the gun just felt nice to use regardless. I wish I could have used the sniper rifle more, as it was only used in one mission of the game, and you only took one shot with it, overall, though, the guns felt nice to use and I never had any issues with any of them.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3065646661
Since [b]Tommy[/b] was a taxi driver before joining the mafia, he will be driving for most of the missions in the game. The driving in the game is fine, although the cars are a little hard to control at times, I think this is because they wanted the cars to have an old-like feel to them while driving. One feature that I love is the fact that you can have a limiter on the speed that your car can have, this helps in driving at times. Mainly because I don’t want to accidentally charge my car at full speed while turning because of the controls. I wish more open-world games with driving did something like this as I just love it all together.

I do in fact have three issues with [b]Mafia: Definitive Edition[/b], the first one has to do with when you are aiming your gun. Sometimes when you start to aim, your gun will fire automatically, I have no idea as of to why when I never pressed the trigger button, so I assume this is a glitch. Then there is the issue with the lock on during car chases, while they were few and far between, the lock on is a bit of a mess. The issue here is that sometimes the target you were firing at will change, and there is no way to switch targets at all. This makes the car chases a little clunky when aiming, not a huge issue, as it rarely came up but still something that annoyed me.

[h1]Graphics and Performance[/h1]
The graphics for this remake are really beautiful and detailed, they give off this rich 1930s feel and charm that I loved. I tested the game on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50, and 16 GB of RAM, I experienced no issues while I was playing and got 60 FPS.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3065655032
I did encounter some minor bugs while I was playing, however, nothing game breaking but there were some. One of the oddest ones I have come across was this one bug where cars will just far from the sky, it actually happened to me during a police chase in the game. This actually resulted in me failing the mission and I had to redo it.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
Despite my issues with the game, [b]Mafia: Definitive Edition[/b] is a fantastic game and one I highly recommend for those who love crime dramas. If you are someone who likes story-heavy games, then I think this would be a fine purchase for you to get. Although there is only 12 hours of the main game so I would wait for a sale.

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Mafia: Definitive Edition, a loving reimagining of the classic 2002 title, is a nostalgia-infused journey through the gritty underworld of organized crime. Spending 9.6 hours with this game was like revisiting an old friend and experiencing a vintage story with modern sensibilities.

The game's narrative thrusts you into the shoes of Tommy Angelo, a cab driver reluctantly drawn into the criminal world of the Salieri family. The storytelling in Mafia: Definitive Edition is nothing short of exceptional. It's a tale of friendship, loyalty, betrayal, and the cost of living life on the wrong side of the law. The characters are vividly brought to life, with superb voice acting and authentic dialogue that immerses you in the era of the 1930s.

One of the standout features of Mafia: Definitive Edition is its painstaking attention to historical accuracy. The city of Lost Heaven is a meticulously crafted, bustling metropolis that perfectly captures the essence of its time. From the architecture and vehicles to the fashion and music, every detail serves to immerse you in the Prohibition-era atmosphere.

The gameplay is a perfect blend of action and realism. Driving is an integral part of the experience, and the game's handling of classic vehicles is both authentic and enjoyable. Shootouts and combat scenarios offer a satisfying challenge, making every bullet count in a true-to-life way.

Mafia: Definitive Edition boasts impressive visual enhancements compared to its 2002 predecessor. The character models, environments, and lighting have been overhauled, resulting in a game that's as beautiful as it is evocative. The weather effects, especially rain, create an ambiance that enhances the immersion and visual appeal.

The 9.6 hours of gameplay likely only scratched the surface of what Mafia: Definitive Edition offers. The game's missions, which range from high-speed chases to intense shootouts, maintain a high level of variety and excitement throughout.

One of the minor drawbacks of the game is the occasional clunkiness in character animations and facial expressions, which can feel a bit outdated compared to contemporary titles. However, this is a minor blemish in an otherwise finely crafted experience.

In conclusion, Mafia: Definitive Edition is a remarkable reimagining of a classic title, showcasing the power of nostalgia and storytelling in gaming. With 9.6 hours of gameplay, you've likely experienced only a fraction of the narrative's depth and the immersive world it presents. It successfully bridges the gap between the past and the present, allowing both newcomers and fans of the original to enjoy a timeless tale of crime, loyalty, and consequence. This is more than a remaster; it's a passionate homage to a bygone era of storytelling in gaming.

A great, well crafted 1 - 1 remake, with some very minor changes to the story and minor incorporated references to other games in the series that since released. It is also worth mentioning that the police are not as strict as the original game and the player is rather encouraged to deviate from the rules of the road which is one major departure from the original.

I was pretty surprised the game is faithful to the 2002 version in structure beat for beat which I appreciate a lot and what is more the remake comes with the benefit of Lost Heaven being visually better than ever.

Now with a modern engine, aesthetic details such as neon lights, billboards, towering skyscrapers, 'Americana' and all the nuance in-between shows that the developers took their time crafting a 1930's American city with great care. Additionally aside from minor changes, the map/city layout effectively feels like the original which is even more impressive. Only downside is the public transport is no longer usable but that's not too much of a problem.

You can tell that the game is developed on Mafia 3's technical foundation however the game is faithful enough to the original to feel different.

Like the original, there are no side quests or district missions like Mafia 3, there is just the same 20 story chapters and the free ride mode alongside new collectables that encourages the player to explore the city.

I especially liked the graphics of the game, one of the most impressive so far that I have seen so far. It ran very well even on my 1050 graphics card with 16 gigs of ram. To be blunt I have never played the original Mafia however treating this as it's own game, I would honestly give the game a 9/10.

10/10 Fantastic game with fantastic story and fantastic gameplay. As an OG fan of the original Mafia game, I confess I am very biased but I highly recommend this game to all Mafioso lovers set in the 30s.

This review is largely unnecessary seeing as aside from the odd game hoarder like myself that just buys anything when it goes on sale, the vast majority of people who pick up this game are people that played the original over 20 years ago. Still, I feel compelled to write a review saying that this is one of the best games of all time. The gameplay is simple, the writing is a bit flat compared to modern titles, and the controls can be cumbersome and hard to handle at times especially when driving (which makes up the better half of the entire game). However, this game is pure cinematic mastery to its core. Every second feels like you're watching The Godfather or Goodfellas except you're the one that's there experiencing it firsthand, the actions are taken by you and the consequences are a result of you, and its only made better by the fact that the game itself is ancient and the only thing they did was glow up the graphics and make it run smoother. As a game it's lacking at times, there are precious few collectibles and the game doesn't have a money system like its sequels, so if you're hoping for a 1930's version of GTA you'll likely be disappointed. But if you come expecting a moving piece of art that puts you at the center, then buy this game and take a breather from the preachy paper-thin writing afforded by modern titles. 9.5/10

[h2]A rezurrection that could be counted on? A rezurrection that should be counted on![/h2]

I always envyed that I never could play the first story of [i]Mafia[/i] back in 2010 when [i]Mafia 2[/i] came around, which was an excellent game and I loved every part of the experience. I remember my big brother having the first [i]Mafia[/i] game on retail in his bookshelf and I was always curious towards how the game played and how the story was told. Was it the same or was it different?

After I played Mafia 2, which set the standard of my expectations of the environment and gameworld overall. Expectations of the people in it and the performance of it; such as walking, running, climbing, shooting, interacting, driving etc. 

With this in mind, I cannot be disappointed in this [strike]remaster[/strike] of Mafia. I've looked up the original and this is a total [u]remake[/u] of the original story and it shines, bright! 

It's an excellent game and it holds tight to the feeling and aesthetic of what [b]is[/b] a Mafia game. Stunning. Total blessing to have this available. Great story, great characters and great gameplay.

In the Definitive version, There are lots of pros and I will mention them, however firstly the graphics are in a really good; I mean really really good. But here are some other pros:
- No optimization problems
- Texture Details assigned according to the materials
- Lighting and reflection quality like global lightning are really realistic
- This is a very subtle detail, but it is one that I like very much; When you look inside the window, the image inside has depth of field detail, that is, they did not paste the image directly on the windows. I found the open world very successful in terms of detail, from the details of the buildings to the electricity poles and public areas.

The story is a bit slow, there is a slow narrative and the vibe is just like Red Dead Redemption 2. But there are some issues:
-The ending of the story feels a bit rushed and quite unsatisfying.
-I personally wish there was an open world during the story. The game takes place on a huge open world map, but frankly, I would like to be free during the story, just like in GTA or Witcher style games. Because some areas cannot be visited at all, even throughout the game.
- The story is well-knitted but it doesn't hold up. To be honest, I could only finish it in 6-7 times because playing the game starts to get tiring after 1 hour.
- Car mechanics are annoying, literally soo soo annoying. Even the sfx file of brakes are giving me discomfort. The thing I hated most in this game was driving.
- The aim thing is also a bit strange, to be honest, it doesn't go where you push it. You can't just give the guys a thumbs up and move on. It's weird but it doesn't bother me.

Apart from that, the atmosphere, graphics and plot of the game are really nice. This atmosphere comes to the fore especially in the definitive edition. It's definitely a game you can try if you like mafia style stories, you won't regret it.

Mafia Definitive Edition is a stunning remaster of the classic 2002 game that takes players on a gripping journey into the world of organized crime during the Prohibition era. Developed by Hangar 13 and published by 2K Games, this modern reimagining successfully captures the essence of the original while delivering an enhanced experience for both longtime fans and newcomers.

Visually, Mafia Definitive Edition shines. The game's meticulously recreated 1930s setting in the fictional city of Lost Heaven is a true testament to the attention to detail and craftsmanship of the development team. The city streets are bustling with life, period-accurate vehicles, and an atmosphere that oozes authenticity. The character models and facial animations have been significantly improved, bringing the cast of characters to life in a way that was not possible in the original.

The narrative remains the heart of the game, and it has lost none of its allure over the years. Playing as Tommy Angelo, a taxi driver drawn into the criminal underworld, you'll experience a gripping story filled with drama, betrayal, and moral dilemmas. The voice acting is top-notch, with the characters' performances enhancing the emotional depth of the story.

Gameplay in Mafia Definitive Edition has seen a substantial overhaul to match contemporary standards. The driving mechanics are vastly improved, making it a joy to cruise through the city's streets. Gunplay, however, can feel a bit dated, lacking the fluidity and precision found in more recent titles. Nevertheless, the game's focus on cover-based shooting and limited ammo resources adds a layer of tension and strategy.

One of the standout features of this remaster is the inclusion of collectibles, including vintage magazines and postcards that provide insight into the era. These collectibles not only encourage exploration but also add a layer of historical context to the game.

Mafia Definitive Edition's soundtrack is a highlight, featuring a timeless selection of jazz and orchestral music that perfectly complements the atmosphere of the 1930s. The sound design, from the roaring engines of classic cars to the chatter of NPCs on the streets, further immerses players in the game's world.

Despite its many strengths, Mafia Definitive Edition does have a few minor flaws. Some AI behavior can be unpredictable, and occasional graphical glitches can temporarily pull you out of the experience. Additionally, the game's pacing can feel uneven at times, with some missions feeling rushed while others drag on.

In conclusion, Mafia Definitive Edition is a lovingly crafted remaster that pays homage to the original while making significant improvements in graphics and gameplay. It successfully transports players to a bygone era of crime and intrigue, offering a compelling narrative set against the backdrop of a beautifully realized 1930s city. While it may not be without its flaws, the game's nostalgic charm and engaging story make it a must-play for fans of the original and newcomers alike.

Game of my childhood. Legend.

Disclaimer: I am a 37 year gaming veteran, a casual gamer, so you may have a completely different experiences or perspective.

Positive: great acting, good dialogues, coherent story, nice environment art. No bugs.
 
Negative: the main story is painfully linear, it's more like watching a movie and having to do the driving yourself, as well as the shooting. You cannot deviate right or left, you cannot decide how you want to complete a mission, e.g. quietly or violently, nothing that you do influences what happens next or how NPCs react to you, there is absolutely zero decision making. There is only one way to play the game, and if you leave the area that you should be in during a mission, you fail and start from the checkpoint again. Enemies are programmed in a perfectly determined, predictable way. It's getting repetitive and boring very early. The main story ends after about 20 hours of casual play. Lack of saves may be slowing you down and be a bit annoying. There are a few parts that are really hard to complete, especially the freaking race. The difficulty level could be a bit better balanced. I played on Classical difficulty and it wasn't really that hard (except for the race, Jesus Christ!). You may get stuck there for good. The linear nature of the story means that you cannot in any way skip this part, which is absolutely nonsensical. 

 In the free ride mode (the other mode is the story) there is really almost nothing to do. I mean, there are two dozens of extra missions, taxi driving, races, and that's it. There is nothing to explore, no buildings to enter, nothing to loot, nobody to interact with. As for an RPG that I thought Mafia is. Driving mechanism is a bit weird, not realistic at all, but also not as fun as in GTA. And so is the camera movement (compering with GTA or RD2). 

I miss the days when open worlds really meant open and interesting spaces to explore, like Fallout or Fallout 2. Ah, nobody makes games like this anymore. There aren't too many weapons to choose from. All cars drive more or less the same. Cars don't get damaged (anyone remembers Carmageddon?). The world is vast, but during the main story I had a feeling I am revolving around the same places over and over again, the same bridge, the same tunnel, the same roundabout in Chinatown. And it wasn't inviting or anything, I feel no reason to explore. You can collect comic books, and... that's it. Nothing else. We should not be calling this an "open world", it should be called "empty world". It's very beautiful, all models, roads, buildings are very well made. But there is nothing to steal, nobody to rob or nothing to buy. I imagine Mafia could really be an "extortionist simulator", where you have different gangs and you start beating restaurant owners to give you money, fight the other gangs, bribe cops, get your buddies out of prison etc. to build your own underground empire. I also imagine Mafia world to be a perfect environment to play Arma III in ;) 

All in all it's a good game for a couple of days, I bought it with a great discount for just over $10, so it was ok. But if I paid the full price I think I'd be a bit disappointed. 

After these 20 hours I don't really feel like playing more. Compared with Red Dead 2 the story is incredible short.

Beginner's Guide & Tips:

Don't pick the Classic difficulty level right away. It can cause you a lot of trouble, especially if you haven't played Mafia The City of Lost Heaven or you remember little of it. A normal or high difficulty level is the optimal setting for a first playthrough.

Rely heavily on covers. They are a new feature in Mafia 1 Remake, so using them is not so obvious. Try to hide behind indestructible covers as much as possible and remember to destroy covers used by enemies.

Often look at the mini-map displayed on the screen. The mini-map is primarily for checking the best route, but it also shows, e.g. locations of opponents and police officers, or items that can be examined.

Heal by using first aid kit points. They are hanging on walls in locations where opponents appear. Since you can use each point once, don't take the first aid kit if you have received only minor damage.

Remember the traffic regulations. Any violation carries the risk of starting a police pursuit. First of all, you should avoid hitting pedestrians and other cars. In addition, you should also activate the maximum speed limiter.

Cars are best stolen quietly by breaking into them. You do this by using the lockpick received at the beginning of mission 4. Breaking a car window or throwing a driver out of the cab will alert police officers

You can freely change the difficulty level

Be sure to use covers during fights

Some opponents can be eliminated with stealth takedowns

Use dodges in melee fights

Use the mini-map...
The mini-map is always visible in the bottom right corner of the screen and this is a major improvement over the original game. The mini-map has several important uses:
It displays a suggested route to your destination – you won't have to open the world map. This is particularly helpful in those stages, which involve, for example, reaching a designated location within a time limit.
It displays enemies' icons – they are marked in red. Keeping an eye on the mini-map reduces the risk of getting attacked by surprise.
It displays icons of police officers and police cars. This is very helpful in those missions and sequences where you have to escape the police or when you want to avoid getting detected again after losing a tail.
It marks first aid kits and supplies. You can locate first aid points and chests with ammo supplies faster.
It marks important places and secrets. Important locations to explore are marked, for example, in A Trip to the Country mission. Thanks to the markings, you can find the collectibles scattered around the city.

Try to avoid breaking the law when traveling around the city
If you don't want to get the attention of police, do the following things:
Do not exceed speed limits – The game has a built-in speed limiter and once you turn it on, the vehicle will never go too fast.
Don't attack civilians – This includes directly attacking people on the street, hitting pedestrians with cars, and throwing drivers out of their vehicles. If you need a new vehicle, it's best to use a lockpick and steal a parked car.
Do not crash into other vehicles – The traffic in the game is not very dense, but you should still avoid driving too close to other cars. Also, watch out for vehicles leaving side streets or turning up at intersections.
Don't go through intersections at red lights – If you're in no hurry, wait for the lights to change. You don't have to wait too long for the green.
