TLDR: If you're the type of person to play a game once on the easiest difficulty, you'll prolly like this game. If you play games on the hardest difficulty or only buy games you'll play more than once, I don't recommend this game. If you like collectibles or care about your achievements on Steam, I strongly recommend you DO NOT GET THIS GAME. The game does NOT respect your time at all.

If you've watched/read/played/heard *any* gang/mafia/triad/yakuza type media, then there won't be the slightest surprise or unforeseen turn in the plot. That in itself isn't a bad thing if you like this type of plot, but don't expect anything more than a very standard gang plot. The only two characters I liked in the whole game were Tommy and Ralph, though. The guns very much feel like they are guns of the time period compared to modern games- every gun has a ton of bullet spread and any form of movement widens the spread further. This turns out to not be a ton of fun in practice, though, as it can be frustrating to be shooting at an enemy clearly in your crosshair and not be hitting them. Whether the cars drive well or not is sort of personal preference in this game, but I didn't enjoy them as much as any other game that has you driving around a city this frequently. Whether you love, hate, or anywhere in between, the plot, however, you probably won't replay the campaign that often as the game has so many little parts that take forever to get through for no reason. Your character moves so slowly in certain important locations like Salieri's bar, but you spend so much time in those places! You always spawn somewhere, slowly walk to a cutscene or unskippable dialogue, then get in a car and drive to a cutscene before the mission actually starts! Things like this almost completely remove replayability for me. The collectibles are terrible, is another thing. There are so many and the map is massive and you can't even get 1/4th of them in the campaign. You have to drive around the city with a third party interactive map for the free roam collectibles to be even remotely bearable.

Well, I agree, except this doesn't redeem the game one bit. Physics are wonky and the driving is unpleasant due to how unpredictable stuff on and around the streets can be. Some lamp posts can be taken down, but the majority won't. Some wooden elements are destructible, but a small stop sign in the middle of nowhere can insta-kill you if you're driving fast enough.

There's a "free ride" mode at the end where you can keep torturing yourself with secret missions and a bunch of collectibles that you can only possibly find with a guide open on the side.

After having done pretty much everything this missed chance at a graphics novel had to offer, I can confidently say: skip!

I like the Mafia games, and they offer a nice and detailed experience of mob life, and this game is no different. That being said, while I do enjoy the game, I don't think it's worth buying, because the game can crash and overheat your pc, and also you will get the hard drive not installed error. I had this happen to me at least twice where I had to go back into the game after playing for even no more than 40 minutes. Also there is a bug in where the game will glitch out and prevent you from moving forward, in which you'll have to redownload the entire game. I'm warning you now so that later you don't run into it and then request steam for a refund and you can't get your money back. The game is too demanding graphically, so I think you should only buy it if your pc is above fit for the game, not if it even matches it, because my computer was a 64-bit windows 10 with nvidia gtx 1060 graphics card, and it STILL wouldn't prevent the crashes, even though the game ran properly when it wasn't crashing even though it could run, my NVIDIA GTX 1660 graphics card wasn't able to keep the game running.
Finished the game with all achievements finally but still had the problem in my classic difficulty playthrough as well. Luckily this game had autosaves or I would be REALLY in trouble seeing as no matter how low the settings were my hard drive failed from overheat thanks to whatever this game was graphically pushing my graphics card to do. After finishing it, and the problem not changing, I doubt I'll return to it, but it was ok I guess in story regard, and the gameplay was nice too, but I couldn't really enjoy it because of the crashing trouble. I have increased playtime but that's cause I was playing for achievements and it was too late back then to refund it but given how troublesome the definitive experience was for me, I doubt i'll try mafia 3, but i have to see if my pc can even run that using the demo. Mafia 2 worked just fine though.

There is clear difference in how Definitive edition handles the entire City of Lost Heaven:
Original Mafia is like being in the events themselves. Raw experience, sometimes lenghty, sometimes unpolished, sometimes unfair, but thrilling and unforgettable.
Definitive edition is like having the events told. Lengthy parts shortened, unpolished parts polished, unfair parts changed to make them seem fairer and thrilling parts embelished to seem even more thrilling. But somewhere along the line it just loses the energy and feeling you had from the experience itself.  It tells the story well, you can almost see the events, but its just not the same as being there.
To sum it up. The storyteller is good, if you want to witness the story of Tommy Angelo for the first time and are modern player, this is for you. If you want to relive The City of Lost Heaven however, there still standard edition being sold.

I prefer the original game in many ways, but the remake is also decent. It kind of depends on your expectations. Mafia DE is probably closer to the gameplay and presentation of Mafia 2. Mafia 1 had a more open and less scripted level design, it had no cover system, and it feels more "pure". It's jank, but it has "soul". The remake is solid, but definitely feels more like one of those big corpo movie remakes. The story and characters have been changed quite a bit, the mission environments are more linear and scripted, and the gameplay relies on a cover system like Mafia 2.

So basically, if you're familiar with older games and you don't mind some early 2000s jank, Mafia 1 is better thanks to its writing, presentation, and music. If you prefer modern stuff that's closer to Mafia 2, play Mafia DE. If you have enough time and money, playing both won't hurt either.

I've played the original in my early teens ages ago and seeing it remade with modern graphics is just mindblowing. The feeling of the 30s is unmatched, cars and bikes are beautiful and Lost Heaven, albeit a bit different in places, is substantially the same as it was back when I first visited it. Cutscenes have incredible fidelity now and the action is more visceral than it ever was. The story itself is pretty good, short and bittersweet as it should be, it doesnt overstay its welcome too much and it provides pretty nice setpieces throughout to enhance the experience. Overall I got what I paid for, and I'm satisfied, though if I had to point out a flaw that would definitely be in the absurdly high heating of my GPU even during indoors conversations, some stuttering in places, and a very silly usage of physics. I saw a truck fly across the street and get stuck in place halfway through a mission on a 90 degrees angle in mid air, my bike got stuck into some geometry during a chase, and several other occurrences of cars just flying or flipping over at high speed. Granted its nothing you cant live with and it only occurs occasionally, but it happens a bit too frequently for modern games' standards.
What I cant live with however, is the game crashing during the dreadful race mission. Again, physics related problem which occurred regularly. I suggest skipping the mission entirely through save edit.

Title: Mafia I Definitive Edition - A Nostalgic Journey into the Heart of the Mafia World

Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5)

Mafia I Definitive Edition delivers a thrilling blast from the past, allowing players to relive the unforgettable tale of Tommy Angelo in a completely revamped and visually stunning experience. With its masterfully crafted narrative, well-developed characters, and improved graphics, this game breathes new life into a classic that has stood the test of time.

The story and characters take center stage in this game, and they do not disappoint. As players follow the journey of Tommy Angelo, they are drawn deeper into the seedy underbelly of the Mafia world. The narrative is skillfully narrated, making players feel as though they are part of an authentic Mafia movie. The emotional depth and complexity of the characters leave a lasting impression, making players genuinely care about their fates.

Visually, Mafia I Definitive Edition is a true marvel. The developers have put in meticulous effort to enhance the graphics, elevating the game to a level that rivals modern titles. From the intricately detailed city streets to the character animations, every aspect feels polished and immersive. This newfound visual fidelity breathes fresh life into the game, making it just as engaging as it was two decades ago.

However, despite the graphical overhaul, the controls may feel a bit clunky and take some time to adapt to, especially for players used to more modern gameplay mechanics. While it may take a bit of patience to master the controls, the engaging story and captivating world make the learning curve worthwhile.

Mafia I Definitive Edition stands as a testament to the power of a well-crafted story-based game. The developers have taken great care to preserve the essence of the original while elevating it to a new level for the current generation of players. This game is a must-play for both newcomers and fans of the original, as it offers an experience that is both nostalgic and contemporary.

If you are a fan of compelling storytelling, rich character development, and an immersive world that oozes with atmosphere, then this is a game you should not miss. Mafia I Definitive Edition offers an unparalleled journey into the heart of the Mafia, and it is sure to leave a lasting impact on any player who ventures into its gripping narrative. Dust off your fedora and don your best suit; it's time to revisit the Mafia world in all its glory!

Mafia 1 Definitive Edition is, even with all the upgrades to graphics and gameplay, a game that still doesn't feel modern or fully remade.
It is not a bad game by any means, but I find it hard to recommend, perhaps only with a heavy discount; It's way too short (10.5 hrs) for me to recommend at full price.

The good:

- Graphics: San Francisco looks gorgeous in this game. The whole game is beautiful. Especially the cars and  the buildings.
- The characters: Although I definitely feel they could have been fleshed out more with a longer story, the cast of characters is among the strongest aspects of this game.
- Driving: This is not a racing game so it's nothing too extraordinary but it works fine.
- Immersion: The game sells the feeling of being in the mob pretty well, although it doesn't properly portray the danger you're in. Tommy, Sam and Paulie feel too invincible and free from consequence. 
 
The decent/mixed:

- The Story: It has a lot of references to popular gangster films and tries to homage them, however, don't expect the Godfather here. The story is an 8/10 and honestly left me with mixed feelings over how rushed it felt with that ending.
- The gunplay: It's not bad but it lacks weight. Idk but it just doesn't feel as satisfying as it could. There's also very little gun variety.
- Level design: Some levels are very fun, but others at times feel like little more than shooting galleries.
- The police: At lower difficulties they are pretty dumb, at higher ones they are omniscient. 
- Stealth: Nothing to write home about. Simple but it gets the job done.

The bad:

- Lack of content: This game could've really used some side missions to make it a little longer and flesh out it's characters and world. The story is just back to back main story and cut-scenes for 10 hours. Having such a beautiful yet empty city is a waste. 
- The melee combat: Two buttons for it. Punch and dodge. You basically just have to mash them and there's 0 depth to it. 
- The AI: It's bad and makes later gunfights feel boring (Uncharted 1 level of AI, maybe worse). This also affects stealth sections, making them feel trivial.
- Impact of the story on the world: The world doesn't seem very reactive to the way the story progresses, which makes you feel like there's very little danger/stakes to the crimes or scenarios you participate in (This is worsened by the John Wick level of feats Tommy ends up being tasked with past a certain point). Only near the end after the Bank level did this feel different.

What's missing:

- Any progression system: You don't level up, unlock/upgrade your equipment, gain skills or anything like that. Tommy has the same skills at the beginning of the game as he does in the final mission. Not even his health is improved.
- Interactivity: There is a free roam mode where you get to drive around the open world outside of missions but there's nothing to do. The world is pretty, but empty.
 
Conclusion: Decent game, but buy only with deep discount. Had potential to be much more.

Mafia: Definitive Edition is an outstanding remake that sets a new standard for reviving classic games. This lovingly crafted reimagining of the original Mafia brings the iconic 1930s crime saga to a new generation of players with breathtaking visuals, enhanced gameplay, and a level of immersion that surpasses all expectations.

One of the standout features of Mafia: Definitive Edition is its jaw-dropping graphical fidelity. The developers have painstakingly recreated the city of Lost Heaven with incredible attention to detail. Every street, building, and vehicle feels authentic, and the visual enhancements bring the game world to life like never before. The lighting effects, weather system, and meticulously designed interiors create a captivating atmosphere that draws you into the world of organized crime.

The gameplay improvements in Mafia: Definitive Edition elevate the experience to new heights. The controls are responsive and intuitive, making gunfights and car chases feel dynamic and exhilarating. The addition of a cover system adds a layer of tactical depth to the combat, allowing for strategic approaches to intense shootouts. The driving mechanics have been refined, offering a satisfying balance between realism and fun as you navigate the streets of Lost Heaven in a variety of classic vehicles.

The narrative in Mafia: Definitive Edition remains as compelling as ever. The story follows the rise of Tommy Angelo, a cab driver who becomes entangled in the Salieri crime family. The writing is top-notch, with well-developed characters, intricate plot twists, and moments of genuine emotional depth. The voice acting is superb, lending authenticity and depth to the characters' personalities. From the intense moments of high-stakes drama to the quieter, character-driven scenes, the story keeps you engrossed from start to finish.

The attention to detail in Mafia: Definitive Edition is simply astounding. The period-accurate soundtrack sets the mood, immersing you in the atmosphere of the 1930s. The radio broadcasts, ambient sounds, and bustling city streets all contribute to the sense of authenticity. The world feels alive, with pedestrians going about their daily lives and reacting realistically to your actions. Exploring the city's various districts uncovers hidden secrets, collectibles, and side missions, providing hours of additional content beyond the main story.

The addition of bonus content, such as additional missions and behind-the-scenes features, further enhances the value of Mafia: Definitive Edition. The developers' commitment to delivering a comprehensive package is evident, showcasing their dedication to the fans of the series.

In conclusion, Mafia: Definitive Edition is a stunning remake that surpasses all expectations. Its breathtaking visuals, enhanced gameplay mechanics, and captivating narrative make it a must-play for both fans of the original game and newcomers to the series. The attention to detail, the immersive world, and the gripping story combine to create an unforgettable experience that will leave you yearning for more. Whether you're a fan of crime dramas, open-world games, or simply appreciate masterful storytelling, Mafia: Definitive Edition delivers an exceptional gaming experience that shouldn't be missed. Strap in for a journey back to the roaring 1930s and prepare to be blown away by this modern masterpiece.

This is probably my 3rd time playing through and I'm honestly surprised I never wrote a review for it. It's another shining example of how to do a remake the right way. I don't know if anyone has tried to play the original Mafia before but it has not aged well at all, mechanically it's damn near impossible to play by modern standards. This remake does a flawless job of modernizing the controls and gameplay while still maintaining the integrity of the original game. There are some voice actor re-casts that some people are annoyed with, mostly Paulie but I think Paulies new voice actor is the superior acting. Paulie always gave offf that classic mobster goon vibe but his voice never really fit that energy, in this remake it's spot on in my opinion. The game itself is relatively short, you can blast through it in about about 8 to 12 hours depending on difficulty you play on. I just finished a run on Classic (hardest) difficulty and it took me just over 12 hours to finish. This included about 2 hours of me redoing the race because my god that was the hardest part of the entire game I swear. The only other gripe I have with this remake is that Hanger 13 for whatever reason decided to use Temporal Anti-Aliasing, which don't get me wrong on higher resolutions it typically is a solid AA solution. But if you're playing on a 1080p monitor you are in for a bad time with animation ghosting. It usually only shows up in very specific lighting situations but it's always annoying to see a character's arm ghosting like that one scene in The Matrix. The issue is that you don't have the option to just have anti-aliasing off entirely because if you are on a strong enough setup then an AA solution isn't something you actually need so only having the option to set it to low, medium, or high (none of those settings will alleviate the ghosting) instead of just turning it off is a problem. There is a mod that disables the TAA but sadly that has its own issues such as characters hair being bright white anytime they are in direct light, I tried the mod out and was happy the ghosting was gone but the bright white hair in light ended up being a deal breaker for me so I reverted to not using it. All in all though a solid 9 out of 10 experience, if only I had the option to turn TAA in the game itself I'd be able to give this a 10 out of 10.

A brilliant remake of the original game, this improves it in every possible way and is the best way to enjoy the amazing story of Mafia 1. I highly recommend playing this if you're into story-rich games!

Set in the fictional city of Lost Heaven, players assume the role of Tommy Angelo, a down-to-earth cab driver who inadvertently finds himself intertwined with the Salieri crime family. The narrative-driven gameplay follows Tommy's rise through the ranks of organized crime, exploring themes of loyalty, moral dilemmas, and the consequences of one's choices.

Lost Heaven is a breathtakingly authentic city, with its stunning architecture, vintage cars, and atmospheric ambiance capturing the essence of the 1930s. The developers have spared no effort in creating a living, breathing world.

Gameplay mechanics are very solid offering a perfect blend of action, exploration, and storytelling. Driving through the city streets feels smooth and enjoyable, while engaging in gunfights delivers a satisfying and immersive experience. 

The story is told from Tommy's perspective and it starts from the end of the game and Tommy presets the story in chapters and later on ends where the game starts. 

Some minor issues, bad AI in combat and the balance of the game in missions is a bit off but overall a very good experience and Hangar 13 delivered on this one.

This is most likely one of the best games I've ever ended up playing. As a lifelong Mafia 2 fan I decided to give this a shot, picked it up on sale for 15€ and tried it out. At first I wasn't impressed, the gunplay is passable but quite repetitive, almost every gunfight plays out the same and there's like 3 guns to choose from. By far the worst part for me was the driving, the fact that the protagonist is an "expert driver" and drives in pretty much every mission wasn't helping either. I even had to download a savefile to skip a racing mission which you have to win to progress the story, which I gave up on after an hour of restarts.

The setting and story is where the game shines the most, every character is memorable, every mission has its meaning and leads perfectly up to the big, satisfying finale. The city is extremely well made, graphics are beautiful and everything feels quite alive. I played using the Czech dub because that's how I played Mafia 2 many years ago, it was very well made too and would recommend it to any Czech speaker. 

(On a side note I recommend turning off the subtitles, while I love playing with them there are a few key moments in the game that are "spoiled" by the subtitles cutting off suddenly)

The last few missions are the best part of the game in my opinion, it ties everything together beautifully, the main antagonist, the start of the sequel, everything, don't wanna say too much so just play it yourself, it really is worth it.

Eh, played better. I was mostly there for the story. The driving was GOD AWFUL, I hated it. The gunplay was fine. but the story is what kept me interested. Probably not going to play another Mafia game, I'm at least satisfied.

Do yourself a favour and play this game on Classic Mode - the only mode it actually makes sense if you invested your money into this game. You will be done with it pretty quick. After nearly 30 hours I am finished with playing through all missions, side missions and collecting all achievements/trophies.

There are a few weapons and explosives, but nothing special there.  Lots of cars.  You'll spend a great deal of this game driving.  However, it doesn't force you to drive unnecessarily, as you can often skip drives to story missions.  There's a small amount of sneaking and taking down enemies, but there's definitely more firearm combat.

The main game itself has a good story, but it's not super great either.  It can be pretty predictable.

After that, there's not a whole lot else unless you're a completionist.  There are a ton of collectibles, none of which show up on your primary map, but they'll appear on your mini map only when you're close to them.  There are no hints whatsoever to where they are.  You literally just have to search every inch of the city.

There are also side missions that the game makes no effort to make known to the player.  You have to go to certain places and interact with certain items and that's how you activate them.  Would have never known about them if I hadn't read about them online.  That said, some of these side missions are hope diamond sized pieces of crap and the guy who designed them should have his temporal lobes ventilated via lead dispersion.  Same with Classic difficulty.

There's an achievement that requires you to complete the game on Classic difficulty.  A word of warning:  This difficulty setting is blatantly unfair and will require you to "git gud" and try over and over to finish at least two certain story missions.

Ultimately, I can see why this game was a favorite back in its day and why the Definitive Edition would be a welcome change.  If you'd like an action game based on the life of a 1930s NYC mafia member, you should play this.  If you're a completionist, get this only if you're ready for the challenge.

If you need a solid entry to the Mafia Franchise, this is a good start. 


Performance is fantastic and the game looks great, even on low settings. 


Gameplay is... fine. If you ever played any third-person shooter with cover and driving mechanics, the gameplay should feel very familiar. There are some unique mechanics that comes from the original game, like police reacting to traffic violations and cars having limited gas. Stealth is very finicky, at least on Classic difficulty, you can easily be spotted and fail the mission if you need to be stealthy. 


Which brings me to my next point: the game is aggressively scripted. This is an antithesis to the design philosophy of the original Mafia. The original game didn't care if you got spotted or if the alarm got raised, too bad, you still need to finish the job and even accounted different choices and mistakes the player can make. In this game you need to stick to the script or the game can hit you with a game over, if it doesn't, its pretty easy to break the scripting and find exploits. 


Still, the real appeal of this game is it's expanded story that foreshadows and references the other Mafia games, and the expanded characterizations and relationships of the characters. Most of the changes I think works, as world-building and characters have been Hanger 13's strong suit. For the story alone, it is worth the play through.

                                                           MAFIA

Here is the most successful and eye-catching game of the series . This game cheers our eyes with its environments, music and venues that successfully reflect the difficulties of the period, the corruption of the state, the life of a citizen and the work of the mafia. Like our first game, the second game does not lack any of these features. You already know what happened in the last game 

                                                      GRAPHICS 
Usually the "definitive" versions are a bit nasty and feel like a quick job, but with this game it's different. They gave the "definitive" versions of the 2nd and 3rd game for free, but bought this game with money. And yes, this game has been really successful. I've played it  on classic difficulty with no problems.
The optimization has been done successfully and is visually stunning.
There is not much missing in this section.

                                                        SOUNDS

- The period music, atmosphere, vehicle sounds and of course the voiceovers are successful and draw you in.
- -/+ Gun sounds average.

                                                      GAMEPLAY 

Everything was perfect, including vehicle handling and missions.
- The hitting feeling is successful.
- Introduction to the mechanics of the cover and the operations you perform there are successful and error-free.
- There isn't much in this section.  

                                                     VEHICLE USE

I liked the driving, I liked the feeling of the vehicles of the period


                                                          (PLUS)  

+ They have faithfully preserved the atmosphere of the 1930s without disturbing the atmosphere of the same original game.

+ Cutscenes deepen the story characters as personalities in great detail. Of course, this put the scenes in the mood of hollywood movies. Of course, after all, this is Remake, the men cannot "copy paste" the 2002 scenes as they do today. I appreciated the time and effort they put into Motion Capture, even though I found it unnecessary that they lengthen the scenes in some episodes pointlessly.

+ The driving feel of the vehicles is just like the turtle, with the driving mechanics it gives the feeling that they are really 1930 vehicles. If you play as a simulation, like in the original game, the vehicles make you feel their clumsiness with very fine details.

+ The artificial intelligence of the cops is exactly what I wanted this time, even the NPCs in the city have nice artificial intelligence, when you do excessive speed or have an accident, the NPCs in the city can take your license plate and report it to the police. If you play in the simulation, the cops are not eye-catching, just like in the original game, they don't give you a speed show like the fast sports cars in the GTA and NFS series.

+ Classic difficulty gives you the pleasure of "Mafia The City Lost Heaven", enemies can fly you with a single sniper bullet at long range or with a single shotgun bullet at close range. even gun bullets, First Aid first aid kits are very difficult to find in the section, and this really gives you the feeling of tension in the action in a very tense way.


+ A nice feature has been introduced for players who do not like Skip Drive-style long journeys, but if you experience it as "Skip Drive" all the time, you will not understand the dialogues between the characters in the story, and you will not be able to properly experience the story flow and the atmosphere of the city in the game. Of course, after all, it's your game taste, how you want to play, especially for those who will do "Speedrun" :D

+ For players who want to explore the brand new Lost Heaven city, it's nice to think of a Freeride free roam mode where you can do side quests for snacks, just like in the original series.

                                                      (CONS)
 
- NPCs in the city are just idly wandering around the city in normal quiet situations and saying hi to Tommy Angelo. They only react according to the situation that the player has experienced in the city. You made a remake game in 2020, brother, at least it should give a little bit of NPCs a sense of vitality that will fill our eyes. For example, if they added small random events like "Random Event" like in Gta V and RDR2, this would make the city of Lost Heaven in a 2020 game feel much more cultural, I'm sure they could make nice random events to fit the cover. The open world of the game is not even that huge, so not only does it consist of creating an authentic visual city atmosphere, but also design the interior accordingly and enrich it with various artificial intelligences in your next games.

- I get that you don't mess around with the open world, you stick with the Original series, but it would be nice if you didn't at least remove Lucas Bertone's alternate side missions from the Original game. I guess they decided to remove them from the game in order not to spend more money and time on reworking those side missions.

- Unfortunately, the enemy artificial intelligence is still grinning a lot, some enemies do not react to bullets at all even though they eat "Headshot",

- There are minor animation glitches in the game, but they don't outweigh the ''Cyberpunk

My review is from the perspective of someone that hadn't played the original Mafia.
The game was a great experience overall, with some minor issues. The gunplay was kind-of annoying until I took a thompson and got closer to enemies to tap them in the head. It's your usual rambo gameplay where you're a taxi driver, a guy who does races (a racist), the best killer in town, undefeatable street fight champion (could beat Tyson), and so on. You could be an astronaut as well if it gave you an option. This doesn't mean the gameplay was bad, it's like any other game of the genre. What made the game enjoyable were the fantastic characters, the story and the graphics that have enhanced the experience significantly.

The most annoying aspect of the game was the driving, and considering that you're spending about half the game driving and there's even a racing mission made it a little frustrating at times. I guess that's just how the old cars felt huh. The characters have made the experience so much better. Their personality and their voice have been incredibly fun to listen to. Combining it with the story made a wonderful experience.

However, everything else is downright bad. Its a classic story of a random guy meeting mafia by accident and continuing to be working under them until...you know the drill, it has been written so many times. Story itself is about 10-12h long, where cutscenes take most of the air time. The rest of the time you will spend just driving from point A to B, and the rest few hours left are actual gameplay.

There is really nothing to remember the game for. Graphics felt nice and voice acting was also well made, but the game feels empty. Its just a driving simulator with a lot of hidden things to collect. And good luck collecting them all without a guide.

I played the original some years ago. This reboot is decent enough graphically, but as a cover shooter it's nothing outstanding, especially in today's games market. Just like other games of the franchise, there is little to no freedom or inclination to explore outside of the mission parameters, no side-quests to complete, no skills progression or character customisation.
The city setting looks and feels convincing, and the map is one of the game's best features, but with no optional side-quests, no meaningful collectables (only meaningless collectables), and no weapons to buy or customise, all it is, is a series of missions strung together with cutscenes and a lot of driving in between. 
It's not a terrible game - there's just not enough depth to keep me interested. It is effectively a sandbox without any toys, and that's a shame because it could have been so much better with a bit more thought toward content.
If you already know what to expect from this franchise, or you're just looking for a quick 1930's gangster shooter fix to satisfy your inner Lucky Luciano, then you may find it enjoyable enough while it lasts. I'd recommend only getting it on sale however, otherwise you're gonna feel more like a schmuck than a wiseguy...capiche?

A narrativa é sensacional, tendo um ótimo desenvolvimento tanto da trama como dos personagens, e fazendo varias referencias ao clássico poderoso chefão.
O gameplay é simples tendo excelentes partes de tiroteio, um arsenal modesto de armas, e perseguições alucinantes de carros.
Quanto aos veículos, tem uma grande variedade e todos eles são muito únicos, dando para sentir quais são mais pesados e lentos e os que são mais leves e rápidos. Claro dando destaque aos lindos e únicos visuais dos anos 30 de cada um.
A progressão da historia é por capítulos, uma melhor que o outra, porém quando estiver jogando o modo historia você não tem opção de fazer side quests.
Há o modo separado chamado free ride onde você tem a liberdade de fazer o que quiser, como as side quests ( que são bem desafiadoras e zueiras ) e explorar o mapa atrás de colecionáveis que são as revistas em quadrinhos. 
Quanto ao mapa e a ambientação é tudo muito bonito e detalhado, passando bem a vibe dos anos 30. 
Este de longe é um dos melhores remakes já feitos, levando em conta que o original infelizmente ficou muito datado.
O jogo é uma ótima experiencia narrativa, bastante fiel ao original e com um gameplay muito mais fluido que o enriquece ainda mais.

The Mafia Definitive Edition is a shining example of how a remaster should be done. This game takes the beloved original and elevates it to new heights, delivering a nostalgic and thrilling experience that captures the essence of the Mafia series.

Young gamers who never played the original will likely love this remake. Some older gamers who have played and liked the original may hate this reboot because it's not a 100% exact copy. I happen to fall among the latter, and since the original Mafia is my favorite game ever and holds such a special place in my heart, it would make sense for me to be picky and b!tch about the reboot, how it misses some details, how things have changed and so on. But you know what? When I played Mafia: DE I was overrun by the same ecstatic emotions that I felt when I first played Mafia and I totally loved this new rendition.

What else made this possible if not my nostalgia for the story, the city, the characters, etc.? But I didn't care - I loved it for what it was, loved to see the beauty of Lost Heaven backed by amazing visuals, loved to relive the story, loved the cars, the missions, pretty much everything. Yeah they could've worked on some characters a bit more, yeah they could've let us do some side jobs for Luca Bertone instead of simply using postcards for car missions, of course they could've let us play every part that was playable in the original instead of covering some bits with cutscenes, among a few other things. These are improvements that won't see the light of day, but I will never think that's enough to bash this game.

The game has been criticized for many reasons by the original's fans, from voice actors doing an allegedly crappy job to the gameplay being generic, and some gamers went so far as to immediately write Mafia: DE off because they saw Hangar13's name on it. I don't get it. Playing the remake I could often feel the love that the devs put into it, and not once did I think they were just doing their job making minimal effort. Mafia 1 was extraordinary in its details, it was a difficult yet rewarding game, and I suppose being so hardcore is why some of its fans can't get over the modernized remake. However, times have changed, the standards have changed, and I believe nowadays you often gotta appeal to a much wider audience than some 20 years ago if you want your game to succeed. And it probably just so happens that that audience is a tad more generic than it was in 2002.

In any case, I understand the criticism that this game got from some long-time fans of the franchise, and they definitely don't have to like Mafia: Definitive Edition. As for me, I didn't like it either. I loved it.

First off, I have to say that this game barely gave me any bugs. The only problem I had occaisionally was the knock out prompt not appearing when I sneak up on someone. No frame rate drops, no glitches, no crashes. This is the first game I can say that about in years. I felt like I was on a pre WWW console, where games were made right the first time.

The story is great. The voice acting is top notch as well. The Don is clearly a Paul Sorvino knockoff, but in all the best possible way. The mission structure is jut like a mafia movie. I will admit I love mafia movies, so I'm clearly biased. I thought they did a great job of portraying characters you get invested in. It's been a while since a game has gotten me this well.

The setting is great. You can add a noir filter if you'd like. A lot of the areas are beautiful at night. Dimly lit set pieces that you'd expect from the setting. The way the red bricks light up at night was great.

I played on Normal. The game play is good. Aiming with a controller is just terrible. I use a mouse to aim, but mostly play with a controller due to my wrists. The cover system is ok. I thought it should have more options to switch cover and orbit than it does. Maybe it's because I've played other cover shooters that give you more options to move around. There were also cover objects low enough to vault over, but the game won't allow you. It was just odd. Also, when you leave cover, the game takes you out of ducking. This will cause enemies to hear you immediately when sneaking up behind them. Guns felt good. Movement overall feels good. I actually don't think that driving is bad. The devs did make some poor decisions about what you could hit with a car. I've hit shrubs and boxes on the ground that slammed me to a halt....

I like the option for GPS to be road signs informing you where to go at intersections. You needn't look at the minimap at all, and there's not lines on the ground to follow. It's far more immersive. The radio also really sets the mood. I never once felt the need to skip the drive (probably would on repeat plays,) because the city is great. The length of the game keeps it from overstaying it's welcome. Major point for manual transmissions in cars!

I'm also not a fan of the available controller schemes. I didn't find them at all intuitive. Most cover games use a somewhat consistent scheme because it works. This is just personal opinion though.

I never bother with realistic traffic/police. I don't want a traffic ticket in a game any more than I want one in real life. I'm glad the option is there for the masochists that do. The same with the original difficulty that reloads weapons the real way. Thanks for not forcing me to do it. I am glad it's there. The speed limiter is also a great idea for people who do want to play with realistic police on. It also works as an E brake very well.

The games biggest flaws are  vehicle health, collectibles and Free Ride mode. Your health and your vehicle's health are shared. The level of dumb in this decision...ugh. The collectibles are useless. They offer nothing. They couldn't even bother writing a synopsis of every story that you have to collect. They tie into Free Ride. The entire premise of it is just dumb. Leave the game to reload the game in a mode that you can't even explore properties that are mission sandboxes. Then leave that mode, and reload the game again to continue the story. It exposes just how empty the world is. A much better way to do this would to be able to turn missions off and on again in the game. It's just a way to force trophy hunters to go see all the empty buildings they made. Seriously, most of the buildings are empty. Just walls and floors. Had they made the world with more detail, it would've been fun to explore. The Free Ride races all exemplify how this company doesn't understand driving. There's so many small objects that slam your car to a halt that thou should be able to plow through. The experimental vehicle races are just frustrating, as the vehicles are usually impossible to control. Driving just isn't that great, and thankfully the story works around it.

Overall, I recommend it. Solid 8 out of 10. First game I've given this high of a rating to in years.

Oyunun hikaye anlatımı güzel, ancak karakterlerle bağ kurmamızı sağlayabilecek kadar kuvvettli hissettirmiyor.
-Oyunun dövüş mekanikleri 2000'li yılları başlarındaki kadar iyi. Dövüş mekanikleri çok özgür hissettirmiyor. Klasik bir siper al ateş et mantığına göre dizayn edilmiş elbette hikaye ağırlıklı gidildiği için rahatsız etmiyor.
-Araba sürme mekaniği biraz hantal kalmış. Hikayenin geçtiği yıla göre düşünürsek belki o yılda eski model arabalar için o rahatsızlık hissi normal midir bilemedim.
-Oyunda görevleri arası bir yerden bir yere giderken açık dünya algısı yaratılmak istenilmiş, ancak ben böyle bir beklentiyle oyunu satın alamadığım için benim hoşuma gitti, ancak ben açık dünyada istediğimi yaparım taraklarında gezecek olan varsa bu oyun o oyun değil.

Eksiler(Oyunun hikayesini bitirdikte sonra yazdığım kısım)
Ana hikaye bitirdikten sonra serbest gezinti modunda oyunu deneyimleme imkanı sunuyor, ancak açık dünyası ruhsuz ve yapılacak kayda değer birşey olmadığı için bunu büyük eksiklik olarak tanımlayabiliriz. En azından 20-30 dakikalık küçük bir görev eklenebilirdi.
-Oyun beklenti yüksek tutulmadığında hikaye olarak ortlamanın üstünde kalitesi var evet, ancak oyundaki neredeyse hiçbir karakterle bağ kurulacak kadar güzel bir olay örgüsü veya oyunculuk göremedim. Ana karakter için çok önemli olan eşiyle ilgili sahneler bile o kadar ruhsuz ve kısa tutulmuş ki karakterin evlilik kısmı hiçbir şekildei inandırıcı olmamış kısa bir düğün sahnesine bile razı olabilirdim. Ayrıca güzel diye tanımladığım hikaye bir yerde sonra o kadar yüzeysel ilerliyor ki sanki gerçek hikayenin özetini oynuyormuş gibi hissettiriyor. işin en ilginç kısmı ise kötü adamlarla yüzleşilen hikayelerde boss fight kıvamında özel hissettiren bir dövüş sahnesi olur ve dersin ki burası en zor kısım burayı geçersem oyunu bitirdim hissini oyuncuya verir. Zorluk konusunda bu oyunda öyle büyük bir dengesizlik var ki göreceli olarak basit bir kamyonu alıp bir yerden bir yere götürme görevinde yaşanan zorluk final sahnesinde yaşanmıyor.


Özetle: Oyun hikayenin açılış kısmını ve oyuncuyu ısındırma kısmını güzel yapmış. Oyuna sudan çıkmış balık gibi atmadan önce göreceli olarak kolay diyebileceğimiz işlerle oyuncuyu ısındırıyor. Hikayenin dallanıp budaklanması ve ağır çatışma sekanslarına girmek biraz zaman alıyor. Gördüğüm eksilere rağmen bu oyun bir klasik olarak oynanmaya değer bir oyun gibi duruyor.

[h1]Well done Hanger 13[/h1] 

[u]What I liked about the game[/u]
[list] 
[*]	The developers have made a lot of improvements to the gameplay. A cover system has been added which really improves combat. The vehicles handle better. It is much easier to throw grenades and Molotovs. Hand-to-hand and melee combat is much much better. They have also improved the stealth and now you can take down enemies quietly and hide their body.  

[*]	Hanger 13 have kept those little gimmicky things which made the original special, like being fined or arrested for speeding and refueling your car.   

[*]	Tons of collectables, like pulp magazines and cigarette cards. 

[*]	Although not as generous as free ride extreme you can unlock jobs in free-ride mode which award you with unique cars and weapons.  The game has some awesome unique cars, like the Crazy horse, Flame spear, and the Disorder. You can also unlock new clothes.  

[*]	The game looks absolutely stunning. Hanger 13 has done a very good job remaking the city and the countryside, and all the cars, characters and cut scenes. I like the characters new look, especially Tommy, Paulie, Sam and Salieri. I like what they did with the countryside, having the city and country in one big map with no loading screens.  

[*]	The developers have reworked some of the missions, like Only for relaxation. Some Missions have been made longer and there is much more going on in the levels. The notorious racing level is still there and it is still very challenging. The cut scenes have been changed as well.  

[*]	They have added motorbikes.  

[*]	Brilliant soundtrack.  

[u]What I disliked or was disappointed with[/u]

[*]	I would have liked to of seen some of the gimmicks from mafia 2 be in this game, for example buying drinks from the bar, getting your shoes shined, or being able to buy clothes from shops. I would I liked to of seen some new weapons. 

[*]	There are only 2 types of motorbikes. 

[*]	I wasn’t keen on the vehicle collisions; it felt like bumper-cars.  

[*]	Shooting while driving wasn’t great. 

[*]	Some of the missions were cut a bit, like Moonlighting.

[*]	I didn’t like some of the rewards you got in free ride mode, like golden weapons and cars that don’t belong in that period.  
[/list]
[u]Conclusion[/u] 

Mafia Definitive edition is a fantastic remake; probably one of the best. Hanger 13 has done a fantastic job remaking the cars, the city, the countryside, the cut-scenes and the characters. My biggest complaints are that some of the mechanics needed improving and they could have gone that bit further with the game. If you enjoy games like GTA or the other Mafia games then I highly recommend you buy this game.

Went into Mafia never having played the series before, didn't even know this was a remake of a 2002 game until halfway through playing it. This game would've been competing with the likes of the original GTA 3, which is some pretty stiff competition. This game is less open-world than GTA (not really openly exploring stuff most of the time, moreso going through setpieces in a world), but that's about the only bad thing about it.
That being said, this game's presentation and worldbuilding kinda blew me away. The characters in this game are great and you actually get to feeling bad for them as the years of crime take their toll. Story is riveting pretty much all the way to the end and even has an epilogue that segues into Mafia II. The soundtrack fits the times and there's even small details I really appreciated like how radio broadcasts will follow the player's exploits. Of the 3 mafia games in the trilogy, this is probably the best one.
The biggest downside to this game is it's owned by 2K and they suck. You have to use their stupid launcher to run this game, and while it hasn't caused performance issues with this version, it apparently might be exacerbating issues with this game's two sequels. Just one of many instances where the game is great, but the publishers are a bunch of pricks.

THE PHANTOM GABAGOOL: PLAYABLE EDITION

Remaking a classic game is a gamble. As a developer, you are faced with the unenviable task of recreating an old title, making it new and contemporary, but also staying true to the source material because nostalgic fans will bitch about it on Twitter if you don’t. 

With rolling the dice on a remake, you could get great things like the new Resident Evil games, Destroy All Humans, and Black Mesa, but most of the time, studios vomit out titles like Super Mario 64 DS and Goldeneye 007: Reloaded, generally middling games that fail their namesake. Whether this failure stems from bad work or the glossy, rose-tinted fantasy of nostalgia, remaking, NOT remastering, an ancient relic of gamer past is a balancing act of accessibility and allowing the player to relive the past.

Mafia, the original 2002 PC game, was the perfect relic to put through the hi-res machine and make anew. The game in its 2002 form is unplayable at best. While it may have broke the barriers of yesteryear, it is not fun in 2023, with bad control mapping, ridiculous difficulty spikes, and optimization issues. So thankfully, we have an alternative to screaming at the monitor because our mobster guy failed the effing race level again. 

The new Mafia (the “Definitive Edition,” you might say) is a solid sandbox game that is easy to play but hard to complete. It is a perfectly balanced nostalgia-fest that recontextualizes a classic story for a new crop of gamers. Gone are broken save points, sound issues, and unfair bullshit and what takes its place is a polished, measured masterclass of game design with decent graphics and old school simplicity.

Shooting and overall controls work perfectly on a keyboard or controller, with no archaic mapping that harkens to Windows 95. Blending the good Mafia II, Gears of War cover shooting mechanics from the era of 360/PS3, the new Mafia has comfortable, difficult but fair aiming that is fun and action packed. Movement is smooth but has the weight of realistic character action. Perspective and better camera work helps make the new Mafia accessible where the original wasn’t. Yet, difficulty of the linear story mode is somewhat identical to the 2002 counterpart, IF you want it to be. Which brings me to the difficulty options…

In this new Mafia, you can adjust your experience and cater to your taste, whether it be a smooth story playthrough or an old-school trial by fire. This gameplay editing is extensive too, so have fun with shaking things up a bit! Providing this makes old games accessible and opens more barriers for shared gaming communities. You can play easy and still have a challenge, but not the long, grueling triumph of completing Illusion Softwork’s original masterpiece. It’s honestly perfect.

The visuals are serviceable to modern standards, but share the same limitations of Mafia II, a game from 2010! It looks more polished than the original and has a completely new cast for familiar characters. It’s a remake in a cinematic sense as well, barring only identical story elements. That is commendable and gives a new, fresh perspective on an older story. This helps the franchise move away from problematic aspects of the first two original games from 2002-2010. This makes the story palatable, but maintaining story integrity. I personally don’t mind problematic things, but I see the logic of the decision. Overall, it’s a great remake storywise but the visuals are decent. I wanted more ambition there but it’s a decent revision that isn’t an eye sore. And it runs well, which is a rarity for modern releases! Thank God! Mamma Mia! **Italian kissing and hand motions**

Hangar 13’s Mafia: Definitive Edition is a great remake of average presentation. It’s timeless and accessible. It’s old and new. Fresh and moldy. Easy and difficult. A balanced release. A masterpiece? No. That’s Mafia II. But damn close!

A lot of reviews compare Mafia: DE to the original Mafia game, I have not played the original, so this review is from that perspective. As far as I can tell, this game just cuts out some meaningless driving time.

The original Mafia is also available for a much lower price, it's an old game with poor graphics, but functionally the same as DE, minus the achievements. If you want the story, aren't a fan of the price tag of the DE and don't mind some 2002 graphics and other jank, then that's probably a good option.

[u][b]Open World:[/b][/u]
Mafia: DE, for a start, is advertised as an Open World game, and while it is Open World, the story is very linear and there's no side content besides a few hidden vehicles and collectables to find. Unless you are on the "Free Ride" mode, you're always in a mission, and for the most part, you can't deviate from it very much. Some missions prevent you from going off track, some prevent you from leaving your vehicle, but some do allow to you explore before you go to your objective if you like. The point I'm making is that the Open World doesn't come into play naturally, while you are driving around different areas for different missions, you're usually going from A to B, this isn't a bad quality, but just know that this game doesn't play like GTA does, it's a story game primarily.

[u][b]Story:[/b][/u]
Now, the story is great, engaging enough with likeable characters. There are a few moments where you'd think problems could be resolved civilly, and that maybe things could be resolved by talking things out, but it can all be justified by it being a Mafia game, it's all about shooting people and every call being that of "The Don". I found myself immersed regardless, the story and growth of the main cast is entertaining and great, the twists and turns are incredible. 

I found the missions to be relatively challenging, playing on Classic. I could take very few bullets and the enemies could take a lot more, it's all about abusing cover and hitting headshots. One thing of note, the cars are very "boat-like" for the most part (which makes sense as they're cars from the '30s), a lot of the missions involving a lot of fast driving can be quite tedious, the race mission is on another level of tedious though. The driving isn't terrible, fun at points, but compared to the story or combat, it's not great.

[u][b]Collectables:[/b][/u]
As far as collectables go, if you care about them, I would highly recommend looking up the locations of the ones in missions in advance, there are some areas you cannot access in Free Ride, so if you miss them at the time, you'll be replaying the missions to the point where you can get them, you can quit out after though and retain the collectable progress. I spent around 6 hours getting the collectables post-story completion, a lot of that was replaying missions to grab ones I had missed.
In total, there is absolutely loads to collect:[list]
[*]10 Magazines
[*]22 Cigarette Cards
[*]50 Mystery Foxes
[*]80 Comics (4 Comics with 20 editions each) [/list]

A lot of this review sounds like criticism, but understand that I can't give a ton of insight and detail on the good aspects of the game without spoiling things.

My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead, murdered by my brother-in-law Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, Hank came to me with a rather, shocking proposition. He asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using his connections in the drug world. Connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was... astounded, I... I always thought that Hank was a very moral man and I was... thrown, confused, but I was also particularly vulnerable at the time, something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me on a ride along, and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin so I agreed. Every day, I think back at that moment with regret. I quickly realized that I was in way over my head, and Hank had a partner, a man named Gustavo Fring, a businessman. Hank essentially sold me into servitude to this man, and when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. From what I can gather, Hank was always pushing for a greater share of the business, to which Fring flatly refused to give him, and things escalated. Fring was able to arrange, uh I guess I guess you call it a "hit" on my brother-in-law, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured, and I wound up paying his medical bills which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge, working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring, and did so. In fact, the bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen in the ranks to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA, and about that time, to keep me in line, he took my children from me. For 3 months he kept them. My wife, who up until that point, had no idea of my criminal activities, was horrified to learn what I had done, why Hank had taken our children. We were scared. I was in Hell, I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, to end this nightmare, and in response, he gave me this. I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. I... All I could think to do was to make this video in hope that the world will finally see this man, for what he really is.

I did not play the original 20 years ago, thus I approach this re-make without nostalgia. I found Mafia Definitive Edition to be captivating, engaging, and indeed quite pretty. It's certainly will never be a contender for the 'best ever' game. However, it [i]is certainly[/i] a game I would wholeheartedly recommend to anybody that enjoys cinematic or action games. It runs smoothly, doesn't have any particularly grating mechanics (a demonstrable benefit of a re-make over a re-master), and I didn't encounter any notable bugs. Compared to many modern games the mechanics might seem simplistic, but they are refreshingly simple rather than frustrating. It feels a little odd to have an expansive open world coupled with linear game-play, but it allows one to switch-off and just be taken along with the story. When on sale this can be found with the trilogy of Mafia games for less than £20, well worth it. I would say standalone that Mafia:DE is comfortably worth upwards of £10.

TL;DR: Do not buy this game if you hate "cinematic" games, want an open sand box crime game, or expect a half-decent linear shooter. So.....
.....this is gonna be a very unpopular opinion, but Mafia: Definitive Edition is a extremely disappointing game in all regards. I've only played Mafia II before, and never touched the original Mafia (2002), but it seems like developers didn't take any features that were introduced in Mafia II. You have the entire city modeled with so much potential yet never do anything interesting with it. I realize there is a free ride mode but what I've heard is that it's just there for collecting cars, do some phone booth missions and maybe some taxi services and races but that seems to be it. There was no real incentive to try it, since there are no places to rob, no guns to collect, heck there is no money even FFS (in a game where you are a criminal). Anything that could add some immersion or create interesting gameplay experience. Say what ever you want about Ubisoft sandbox-game design but atleast you have stuff to do and gameplay in general just works.

This is a story-focused game, so obviously you are here for that but game could have a magnificent story for all I care but it matters very little if gameplay is dogshit. Gunplay is one of the worst I've experienced in a AAA game. The way it's done is inexcusable; 
- aiming is unnecessarily clunky, using a circle instead of reticle (with pistols), leading to shots you really shouldn't miss. Tommy not having a military background unlike Vito (Mafia II) is not an excuse; he would learn to shoot better eventually, but it's not reflected through gameplay. He can pull a perfect sniper shot in one story mission but somehow still has issues getting accurate shots in-game.
- Enemies (most of the time) do not react to being shot, until you get a fatal hit. They are bullet sponges on higher difficulties which makes guns feel really weak, so you really want to go for headshots.
- Movement can be inconsistent. Sometimes Tommy moves where you want him to go but other time he might make a circle or having delay which is really bad when in middle of gun fights
- Cover mechanic is just terrible; it's easy to accidentally take cover in wrong spot or getting out of cover when you don't intend it to happen and it's even worse when you add that tanky movement I mentioned previously, so that might lead to unfair deaths. And if you don't use that magnetic cover function, instead try to "dynamically" take cover and shoot (like you would in any decent shooter), Tommy refuses to shoot until game decides he can, despite having a clear line of sight.
- No way to choose your gear before missions. The reason why Mafia II open-world worked is because you could choose what gear to take (by buying or stealing). It allowed you to prepare for next encounters and waste your money between missions however you pleased (with few exceptions).
- Lack of real arsenal. I think there was like four side-arms and three primary guns in the entire game, unless I missed some. I'm fairly sure Mafia 2 had a few more than that (and felt like proper guns, not like BB guns).
- Either game is getting tedious and you die due to clunky design or is simply too easy, because game tells everything you have to do without letting you figure out anything yourself. There are no complications, where you have to figure out the next step. It's just the same old, go to point B, shoot people or do not get caught and follow the narrow path we (devs) designed for you. DO NOT BREAK AWAY FROM THE SCRIPT! What is it with modern AAA games, when they can't let you just play the damn game without any hand holding.

What also shouldn't be given any excuses, is the way story is presented in-game. Cutscenes are fine and mostly well executed (and thx god can be skipped) but unfortunately this game has forced walking sections, which take away control from the player (and these you cannot skip, so you are forced to wait). Other times game gives you 15 seconds of gameplay until interrupting you again with another cutscene or unskippable dialog. It's painful to experience this kind of story telling everytime I touch a AAA-game that tries to be like a movie. Game devs, please understand that there are alternative ways to tell a story, using in-game mechanics and possibly some element of player choice so experiencing short comings feel more personal (like
[spoiler] losing all your money and your house in Mafia II late-game so you as a player would feel as pissed as Vito did or letting you stealthily break the safe for bigger payday or fail to do so by raising alarm and killing guards leading to getting only 1/3 of the reward [/spoiler]

Not 10 out of 10, but a solid remake nonetheless. Took about 8 hours to beat on highest difficulty available. Core story is almost exact copy of the original with small-ish alterations here and there that don't matter much in a long run. Compared to original, remake is scaled to down by 2-2.5 times. Pointless driving segments are removed entirely, some scenes moved into cutscenes, some - removed entirely. Unlike original... how should I put it? Mmm... remake "gets to the point" much faster than the original. Solid 6 to 8 hours linear campaign that manages to keep you interested till the end.

However, not [i]EVERYTHING[/i] in Mafia: Definitive Edition was to my liking and I don't agree with certain decisions made for it. Side missions for Lucas Bertone were cut entirely. Apart from his brief appearence in previously mentioned infamous Fair Play (by the way, I do love the fact that devs decided to keep Fair Play challenging, this mission does not hold your hand at all) and his micro role in Free Ride, his character is not utilized at all. While I agree that his missions in the original messed with game's already slow pacing, they shouldn't have cut him out entirely. Some of the side missions were quite interesting and obtaining luxurious cars through him felt quite rewarding.

They made a decisiont to cut Free Ride Extreme too, well... not exactly. Original game featured two types of Free Ride modes: Free Ride, GTA-like sandbox and Free Ride Extreme - unlockable by beating campaign, Free Ride Extreme featured a slightly alterated version of Lost Heaven with stunt ramps, Easter Eggs (like that creepy-ass Rock face) and (I believe) 18 missions that unlocked bonus "prototype" cars that eithere were wacky or speedy af. For the remake, devs made a decision to merge these two modes. While it's not a bad idea, a lot of extremely fun missions like "Save a damsel from a Sea Monster" or "Cross a bridge" on Bolt Ace while a blimp above you is bombing you or "Chase the plane" were cut entirely. SOME original missions like "Chase UFO" HAVE made it into the remake, but there's only a handful of these, rest is remake exclusive and all of them are... extremely boring.

Last thing that I did not appreciate in a butchering of "Moonlighing" mission. Literally 75% of the mission is... gone. Cut. Even without cutscenes. Game file diggers found characters and assets that were meant for this mission went unused. Hella weird, considering how faithful rest of the game is. Feels like they simply ran out of time.

Woudn't say that it is worth a full price but it is a steal at a sale. If you liked newer Mafia games, you will like this one to. 7.5 out of 10.

Mafia: Definitive Edition is a decent remake that took me around 8 hours to complete on the highest difficulty. The core story is almost identical to the original with some minor changes. The remake is about 2-2.5 times smaller than the original, with pointless driving segments removed and some scenes moved into cutscenes. The campaign is more streamlined than the original, with a solid 6 to 8 hour linear story that keeps you engaged.

However, I was disappointed with some of the decisions made for the remake. They cut out all of Lucas Bertone's side missions, which I enjoyed in the original, and I missed obtaining luxurious cars through him. They also merged the Free Ride and Free Ride Extreme modes, but cut out many of the fun missions from Free Ride Extreme. Additionally, the "Moonlighting" mission was butchered with 75% of it cut out, which was strange considering the overall faithful nature of the remake.

Despite these shortcomings, the game is still enjoyable and worth playing, especially if you can get it on sale. It's not perfect, but if you liked the newer Mafia games, you'll probably like this one too. I give it a 7.5 out of 10.

I initially dismissed the Mafia series as yet another open-world 'GTA clone', but it appears I've been missing out.

Whilst there is an "open world" in Mafia: Definitive Edition, it is only there in service of the story. It is there when you travel to the mission objective, but it isn't full of icons for things you need to cross off the list. You undertake a series of missions, mostly involving driving around, shooting things, very much like a GTA game, but aside from collecting a few cards and magazine covers, you just do the missions and enjoy the story. Think LA Noir, but on the other side of the law.

From the opening cut scene, you are led from one mission to the next, often skipping the usual trudge back to the next mission marker on the map. Once you complete a mission, the next scene begins. Whilst it is possible to go out and roam the streets, this is a separate mode called Free Ride. You [i]can[/i] just do the missions and walk away. I really, [i]really[/i] appreciate that in my advancing years (lol). 

The story is beautifully told. Set during the depression/prohibition era in the US just as the spectre of WW2 was appearing on the horizon. The world you inhabit during missions is full of atmosphere and period radio stations, classic architecture and classic cars. It takes around 11 hours to complete the story, but it was one of the few games I've played recently that really gripped me. Like a good book I just couldn't put it down.

With this being the "definitive edition', I've not played the original, but the definitive edition looks better than some newer games. With its "optimal" graphics setting it pushes my RTX 3070Ti quite hard at 4K, but it sure is pretty.

I wholeheartedly recommend this one.

Besides the narrative aspect, it is the gameplay that is the element that has received the most attention in this remake. In fact, if the original Mafia used a third-person view but ended up adopting a first-person shooter gunplay, for the Definitive Edition it was thought well to harmonize these mechanics by taking Mafia III as a reference and thus redesigning the entire experience, from the interface to the cover system.

The end result is certainly enjoyable and quite modern, bringing to life some of the most challenging sequences in a campaign that unravels through more than twenty missions that are gradually more complex and multifaceted. The arsenal available to the protagonist is fairly extensive between pistols, rifles, machine guns and special weapons, but a melee combat system based on simple attack and counterattack mechanisms has also been introduced, with some spectacular finishers.
The lack of refinement of certain moments, between more or less obvious glitches (which we imagine, however, will be fixed with the first updates) and various "jams," leaves a little bitter taste in our mouths and reminds us that what we are playing is a remake of a title that has almost twenty years on its shoulders. The artificial intelligence of enemies falls under the same discourse: some behaviors are convincing, see when they change position behind cover to shoot at us from a different point; others are quite inexplicable, such as when they proceed straight ahead heedless of bullets.

All this also applies when driving, at least with the default settings: police cars will only give us grief if we choose to set the original difficulty, and similarly the behavior of our vehicle will become more nervous if we choose the simulative option in place of the arcade approach. It is nice to have this freedom of choice, despite the fact that as mentioned, the scenery is merely functional to the action and does not enjoy a life of its own.

ingredients

For the meatballs

Method

    Make the tomato sauce:
    Heat the olive oil in a large skillet on medium heat. Add the onion, carrots, celery, and parsley. Stir to coat with the oil, reduce the heat to low, and cover the pan. Cook until the vegetables are soft and cooked through, 15 to 20 minutes.
    Remove the cover, add the garlic, and increase the heat to medium-high. Cook the garlic for half a minute, then add the tomatoes (if using whole canned tomatoes, break up with your fingers as you add them to the pan). Add the basil and tomato paste. Season with salt and pepper.
    Bring to a low simmer, reduce the heat to low, and let cook uncovered until thickened while you prepare the meatballs, 15 to 30 minutes.
    Purée in a blender, or push through a food mill if you'd like a smooth consistency. Return to the pan and adjust the seasonings.

    Soak the torn bread in hot milk:
    To make the meatballs, heat the milk in a small pot until steamy. Turn off the heat, tear the bread into little pieces and soak it in the milk until it partially dissolves. Mash it until you get something that resembles a paste. Turn it out onto a plate to let it cool.
    Submerge the bread in hot milk and let it soak Submerge the bread in hot milk and let it soak
    Soak the bread in hot milk in a saucepan Soak the bread in hot milk in a saucepan
    
Make the meatball mixture:
    In a large bowl, combine the beef, pork, ricotta cheese, grated Parmesan, eggs, garlic, parsley, oregano, salt, pepper, and the bread-milk mixture. Mix it well with your hands until it barely combines.

    Don't overwork the mixture or it will become tough. It is OK to have some discernible bits of bread or meat in the mix; better that than overworked meatballs.
    Mix together the meat mixture for the italian meatballs with your hands Mix together the meat mixture for the italian meatballs with your hands
    The meat mixture for homemade italian meatballs The meat mixture for homemade italian meatballs
    Form the meatballs:
    Wet your hands and form the meatballs. A traditional size for this sort of meatball is 2 to 3 inches across, but you can make them any size you want.

    Once you roll the meatball in your hands, roll it in the flour to give it a good coating. Set each one on a baking sheet as you work. You might need to rinse your hands a few times as you make the meatballs.
    Shape homemade meatballs with your hands Shape homemade meatballs with your hands
    Coat homemade italian meatballs in flour Coat homemade italian meatballs in flour
    Brown the meatballs:

    When all the meatballs are formed, heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Brown the meatballs on at least 2 sides. Don't worry about the center getting cooked through, as you will finish these in the sauce.
    Brown both sides of the meatballs in a skillet Brown both sides of the meatballs in a skillet
    Brown the italian meatballs in a skillet Brown the italian meatballs in a skillet
    Finish cooking the meatballs in tomato sauce:

    Once all the meatballs are browned, arrange them in the sauce, turning each one over in the sauce to coat.

    Cover the pot and simmer gently for 15 to 20 minutes. Serve with the sauce and pasta or crusty bread. Sprinkle with a little chopped parsley for garnish if you want.

Pasta (US: /ˈpɑːstə/, UK: /ˈpæstə/; Italian pronunciation: [ˈpasta]) is a type of food typically made from an unleavened dough of wheat flour mixed with water or eggs, and formed into sheets or other shapes, then cooked by boiling or baking. Rice flour, or legumes such as beans or lentils, are sometimes used in place of wheat flour to yield a different taste and texture, or as a gluten-free alternative. Pasta is a staple food of Italian cuisine.[1][2]

Pastas are divided into two broad categories: dried (pasta secca) and fresh (pasta fresca). Most dried pasta is produced commercially via an extrusion process, although it can be produced at home. Fresh pasta is traditionally produced by hand, sometimes with the aid of simple machines.[3] Fresh pastas available in grocery stores are produced commercially by large-scale machines.

Both dried and fresh pastas come in a number of shapes and varieties, with 310 specific forms known by over 1,300 documented names.[4] In Italy, the names of specific pasta shapes or types often vary by locale. For example, the pasta form cavatelli is known by 28 different names depending upon the town and region. Common forms of pasta include long and short shapes, tubes, flat shapes or sheets, miniature shapes for soup, those meant to be filled or stuffed, and specialty or decorative shapes.[5]

As a category in Italian cuisine, both fresh and dried pastas are classically used in one of three kinds of prepared dishes: as pasta asciutta (or pastasciutta), cooked pasta is plated and served with a complementary sauce or condiment; a second classification of pasta dishes is pasta in brodo, in which the pasta is part of a soup-type dish. A third category is pasta al forno, in which the pasta is incorporated into a dish that is subsequently baked in the oven.[6] Pasta dishes are generally simple, but individual dishes vary in preparation. Some pasta dishes are served as a small first course or for light lunches, such as pasta salads. Other dishes may be portioned larger and used for dinner. Pasta sauces similarly may vary in taste, color and texture.[7]

In terms of nutrition, cooked plain pasta is 31% carbohydrates (mostly starch), 6% protein, and low in fat, with moderate amounts of manganese, but pasta generally has low micronutrient content. Pasta may be enriched or fortified, or made from whole grains.

Etymology
First attested in English in 1874, the word pasta comes from Italian pasta, in turn from Latin pasta, latinisation of the Greek παστά, pasta, 'barley porridge'.
