This game has a high production quality overall. It's very clear that it has had a large budget. However, when it comes to the game mechanics and the design itself, it is very apparent that this is not a product that has had any playtesting or Quality Assurance at all. Several missions are pure, distilled cancer. The race and the turret missions are hated for a reason. I cannot think of a game that has worse missions.

Let me say it again: If it wasn't for the GTA film noir premise, no one would have given the game a thumbs up. All those of us who downvoted absolutely love the idea of the game, but the game itself is pure garbage. The missions aren't hard as in you need to git gud. You need to memorise everything and learn to do what the game devs intended for you, when they intended it for you. It is pure cancer. Most of the fights will have you start already with a cover chosen for you. The most cancerous missions aren't helping the story either. They completely rip you out of the immersion because of how stupid they are. If you google "how to beat the turret mission", the most common advice will be "switch on target locking and set it to max", followed by "set your mouse sensitivity to 1" and "set your graphics settings to high to slow the game down".

Oh, and completely disregard the "open world" aspect of the game. You are ALWAYS in a mission. There is no side content. The only "open world" happens as you drive from A to B, where you'll have absolutely no choice and are demanded to approach the game in the most linear way possible. Health and ammo btw. aren't placed where it makes sense. Nor are they placed in a realistic way. If you play the game on classic, you'll have no chance of knowing when and where the health and ammo re up will be. The game will save the latest checkpoint for you. Congratulations, you can start the same shit again with 5% health and no ammo.
The game devs, in their infinite wisdom, have however decided to include the cut scenes so that you can watch or skip them five million times.

So no, this is not a game that I'd recommend to anyone. It is not a playable game in that you have zero autonomy, stories in the mission are often ridiculously stupid to justify the most cancerous missions possible. The most enjoyable parts of the missions are the part where you drive from your hideout to the mission.

The Definitive Edition is Hangar 13's complete remake and rebuild of 2002's "Mafia", the very first title in the franchise's history. Developed on the Mafia III engine, The Definitive Edition boasts modern visuals, controls, story content, and a plethora of features including a mode allowing the player to experience the game in black-and-white. Set in the 1930s, the story follows the rise of Tommy Angelo through the ranks of the Italian American mafia. 

The story is very much influenced by classic mafia films including The Godfather, Goodfellas, Once Upon A Time In America, A Bronx Tale, and The Untouchables. While action heavy, the game does its best to match the pacing and tone of those films with its aesthetics, soundtrack, dialogue and 'rise to power' narrative. But, it is an action game so The Definitive Edition doesn't truly capture the essence of a classic mob film. 

Instead of faithfulness to source material, The Definitive Edition offers a lot of heart by way of direct nods and tributes to moments from those classic films. This also means that the gameplay style is very linear. Although the option of a more stealth oriented approach is available to the player, the gameplay is limited to shooting, sneaking, and fists. Additionally, while there is a free roam mode in the game which allows the player to explore the fictitious world of New Heaven, the player won't be spending much time exploring within the campaign itself given the script-heavy nature of the narrative. 

Despite these flaws, The Definitive Edition is still a lot of fun and the narrative, while predictable, is fun to see play out. The visuals are stunning and well optimised, voice acting is superb, and the overall inspiration for the project is evident. Best of all, the malady of stiff and wooden controllers of the original game (driving in particular) have been drastically improved. 

The Definitive Edition may offer significant improvements over the original title, but it offers little incentive for the player to revisit given the extremely linear nature of the game. But, it's worth journey at least once.

Hey, I wanted to tell you about this game called Mafia that I played recently. I actually beat it back in January, and I have to say, I really loved it. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2886499878

But honestly, the good outweighed the bad for me. I really enjoyed playing Mafia and was emotionally invested in the story and characters throughout the game. Oh, and one more thing - I would have loved to play at least one mission as old man Tommy, to see the life he had built for himself.

Mafia: Definitive Edition is a truly outstanding game that sets a new standard for remakes. Developed by Hangar 13, the game is a faithful recreation of the classic 2002 title with modernized graphics, refined gameplay mechanics, and a reimagined storyline.

The graphics in Mafia: Definitive Edition are simply stunning. The city of Lost Heaven is beautifully realized, with highly detailed textures and lighting effects that create a truly immersive atmosphere. The game also features an impressive cast of characters, each with their own distinct personalities and mannerisms, brought to life with excellent voice acting and motion capture.

But Mafia: Definitive Edition isn't just a visual upgrade. The gameplay has been refined to be more modern and engaging, with improved shooting mechanics, more responsive driving controls, and an expanded open-world that encourages exploration. The game's missions are expertly crafted, blending action, stealth, and storytelling in a way that keeps players engaged from start to finish.

One of the standout features of Mafia: Definitive Edition is its story. The game follows the rise of Tommy Angelo, a cab driver who becomes embroiled in the criminal underworld of Lost Heaven. The narrative is expertly paced, with twists and turns that keep players guessing until the very end. The characters are well-written and believable, with relationships that feel real and meaningful.

Overall, Mafia: Definitive Edition is an outstanding remake that surpasses the original in every way. The attention to detail, refined gameplay mechanics, and reimagined storyline all come together to create a truly unforgettable experience. If you're a fan of the original game or just a fan of open-world action games in general, then Mafia: Definitive Edition is a must-play.

Temat przestępczości w grach wideo istnieje od dawien dawna, kiedy myślę o fantastycznych scenariuszach i światach które można utworzyć dla setek graczy na całym świecie do ogrywania i podziwiania, pierwsze co mi wpada do głowy to fantasy i crime. Gothicki i San Andreasy to nostalgia w czystej postaci dla wszystkich graczy, którzy mają już dwudziestkę na karku, dla wielu z nich również oraz dla młodszych odbiorców największymi grami zeszłej dekady są Wiedźmin, GTA V czy RDR 2. Konkurencja, jeżeli chodzi o takie tytuły jest więc bardzo gęsta i za każdym razem, kiedy wpada mi do ucha, że ktoś ogrywał czy widział gierkę fantasy czy crime i jest ona “niesamowita”, “zachwycająca” czy “z***bista” przykuwa to moją uwagę natychmiastowo. Poprzeczka zawsze jest bardzo wysoko, dlatego dodatkowo imponujące jest, kiedy nowym grą uda się ją pokonać. Mafia I nie jest grą nową, a remake’iem co trzeba wziąć pod uwagę, jednakże przy przytłaczająco pozytywnych recenzjach musiałem ją sprawdzić. No i cóż, wysiadłem z tej parunastu godzinnej przejażdżki nienasycony. 

	Mafia I to stara gra, DE ma przede wszystkim wypolerować wszystkie niedociągnięcia oryginału, nałożyć nową szatę graficzną i nie zmieniać za bardzo rozgrywki co, aby nie podpalić pochodni uśpionego tłumu fanów klasyka. Ja w oryginał z 2002 nie grałem więc nie podchodzę do recenzji z myślą o zachowaniu cech poprzednika co jest główną przyczyną mojego “nienasycenia”. 

Bo Mafia I DE, to gra stara, przynajmniej nie na pierwszy rzut oka, ale im więcej godzin z nią spędziłem tym bardziej czułem, że gram w demo techniczne które miało ciekawe pomysły na niektóre mechaniki, ale ostatecznie je porzuciło. Strzelanie jest najprostszym systemem shoot&duck, arsenał broni skąpszy niż towary Nowo Jorskich bezdomnych skitrane za pazuchą, skradanie nieistotne, a świat przedstawiony zamknięty i żywy tylko powierzchownie. A szkoda, bo na przykład system prowadzenia w tej grze jest bardzo ciężki co ma oddawać klimat pierwszych samochodów, przez co pościgi wykonywane w zawrotnej prędkości 50 km/h co bardzo oryginalne i klimatyczne. Twórcy zdają sobie sprawę, bo jeżdżenia w tej grze jest bardzo dużo i dobrze. Poza fabułą w tej grze właśnie jeżdżenie coraz to różniejszymi furkami do jazzowych nut lat 30 jest najbardziej przyjemną częścią gry. Warto też wspomnieć o systemie policji który ma jakiś zalążek w stosowanych ograniczeniach prędkości, upomnieniach czy mandatach, szkoda, że nie ma z tym więcej, bo czuć tu potęciał. 

	Ostatecznie dla mnie to co Mafia oferuje to fabułę i klimat i jest to rzecz, za którą fani oryginału kochają tą grę jak i rzecz, która przyciąga najbardziej nowych graczy. W moim uznaniu jednak jest po pierwsze niedostateczne a po drugie nieciekawe. Postacie i fabuła z jednej strony wpadają we wszystkie możliwe trope’y aby wytworzyć typową symulację świata gangsterskiego w czasach prohibicji co jest powierzchowne i nudne przy ogromie innych dzieł zakrawających o temat kryminału, a z drugiej tworzy pewien lunapark mafijny który niezaprzeczalnie jest przyjemny. Dla mnie jednak, jeżeli gra zamierza się bronić przede mną tylko i wyłącznie fabułą, posiadając nieinteraktywny świat oraz znikomy gameplay ma to robić na najwyższym poziomie. Tutejszy poziom jest jednak importowanego kanadyjskiego bimbru, z jednej strony pyszny i jak najbardziej mile widziany, z drugiej strony jak mam pić whiskey to wolałbym mieć prawdziwy Kentucky blend. 

Dla mnie 6/10, dla fanów klimatów mafijnych trochę więcej, dla fanów Mafii Classic z 2002 roku jeszcze więcej

Mafia: Definitive Edition is a remake of the classic game Mafia, originally released in 2002. The game is developed by Hangar 13 and published by 2K Games. It is a story-driven, third-person action-adventure game set in the 1930s, where players take on the role of Tommy Angelo, a taxi driver who gets caught up in the world of organized crime in the fictional city of Lost Heaven.

The game features an open world environment where players can explore the city, engage in various missions, and interact with the characters. The game's storyline is divided into chapters, each with its own set of missions and objectives. The gameplay includes driving, shooting, and hand-to-hand combat.

Overall, Mafia: Definitive Edition has received good rating from myself. Also other players have praised the game for its engaging storyline, immersive gameplay, and stunning graphics. The game has been praised for its attention to detail and for faithfully recreating the 1930s setting.

I and maybe some players have criticized the game's controls, particularly the driving mechanics, as being clunky and difficult to master. Some players have also found the game's combat mechanics to be repetitive and lacking in depth.

In conclusion, Mafia: Definitive Edition is a well-received remake of a classic game that offers an immersive, story-driven experience set in the world of organized crime. While the game's controls and combat mechanics may not be perfect, its engaging storyline, attention to detail, and stunning graphics make it a worthwhile experience for fans of the genre.

This is quite a well done remake of the original game. It is a beautiful visual experience, with lovely graphics, lighting, environments, and motion capture for face acting. Of particular note here is the driving experience, the game manages to make driving nearly 100 year old cars exciting while also retaining a sense of the clunky feel of early automobiles. Rattling around in a straight-six Chevrolet or a Model T while being chased by the police is incredibly fun.

The biggest downside of this game for me lays with the writing. While the story is largely unchanged, much of the writing has changed a fair bit. While a lot of the clunky dialogue has been redone with dialogue that feels more natural and flowing, some of the message the original game was trying to convey has been simplified or removed in favour of a different message entirely. Of particular note here is the epilogue.

Another note with the writing is the pacing. While I cannot entirely blame this game itself as these story beats were laid out by the original game, the issue persists that many major plot points sort of just unceremoniously happen, or we are told things have happened instead of being shown this which is more engaging. For example, your syndicate has grown much more powerful than your rivals, and this is mostly just conveyed by us hearing about it. Several characters shift trajectory from their established positions with little build up to this happening, it never really sets up something to happen, it just sort of happens.

Hangar 13's somehow captured the exact same feels and themes of 2002's Mafia: The City of Lost Heaven while improving upon everything that made the original Mafia a decent story-focused crime game. It's the same engaging crime story, told in an even better way than the original could, with an entirely new cast, rewritten dialogue, and some plot details changed slightly in ways that make the twists more believable and add more weight to the game's final act. All set in a gorgeous 1930s Chicago analogue that effectively immerses the player in the era of Prohibition and later on, the tense atmosphere of pre-WWII America. This is not a Yakuza Kiwami/Kiwami 2 situation where RGG Studio added more to the games in terms of side content while retelling the exact same stories almost 1-to-1. With Mafia DE, Hangar 13 went the route of rebuilding everything from the ground up, including the story, and I think they succeed just as much as Yakuza Kiwami 1 and 2 do, but with vastly different techniques.

For anyone who never got to play the original Mafia, I'm gonna say that you certainly missed out, zoomer, but getting this remake instead is gonna take you for the same emotional ride the moment you step into the shoes of cabbie-turned-mob muscle Tommy Angelo, but said ride's gonna be way smoother and more polished. It's not gonna give you any of the insanely difficult moments from the original that are more the result of early 2000s jank rather than actually smart AI and great mechanics. But if you do want these modern mechanics and QOL improvements with the same intense challenge provided by the original Mafia, then choose Classic Difficulty. But take note: if you choose Classic, with its tighter timers, Simulation driving, rubber-banding race and cop chase AI, and both Tommy and your vehicles being made of paper... Guess what: the racing mission that everyone's talking about in the reviews? Heh. Lotta folks with nostalgia goggles on might be criticizing this game's other aspects, but not many of them can say that the racing mission on Classic is in any way less of a headache than the original. You better pray to God that you got the stones to drive a 1930s racecar at 120mph without spinning out, cafone.

Mafia DE, to the horror of some folks I've seen before this game was released, is in the same engine as Mafia III. So expect a lot of the same shooting, movement, and driving from that game, just with 1930s weapons and vehicles. But fear not. Seems with this game, Hangar 13's finally got a handle of many of the issues that plagued Lincoln Clay's romp through New Bordeaux. I've never once had this game stutter on my system, never crashed throughout the story mode, and I've only ever had two or three instances of any visual glitches in Free Ride mode, and only in the most remote areas. These problems were far too commonplace in Mafia III, yet almost don't exist here at all. It's a significantly smoother experience.

And unlike Mafia III, this game still follows the original Mafia's story structure, where it's cut into chapters rather than the bloated district and hitlist system that Mafia III had. So it's a huge improvement to the third game gameplay-wise by way of cutting out the fat, while also taking cues from Mafia III in terms of voice and mocap performances to be an even bigger improvement over the first game in its storytelling. There's also chapter replays in case you missed any collectibles, want to try for higher difficulty, or just wanna experience a certain set piece again. That one's less a compliment to this game, more of a nitpick for others. I'm still surprised that not every modern game has this feature, man.

And then there's Free Ride mode. Upon learning that there was only one Free Ride mode in this game, I was concerned as to weather or not Hangar 13 would include some of the wacky elements that were in the original Mafia's Free Ride Extreme. Turns out, I had no cause for alarm. Instead of having two separate Free Ride modes, they just let you do everything in one. And that's great. You wanna just tour around Lost Heaven? See it for the first time, or if you're a series veteran, see how the devs remade the city? You can do that. You wanna unlock stupid, crazy cars and do missions that unlock new vehicles and weird costumes? You can do that, too. And there's a TON of secrets and artwork collectibles to find throughout both the city, and the vast northern countryside, with progress carrying over into and from the story mode. I'm glad that they brought this mode back and even added to it. I dunno if they'll have my favorite stoner van in this game yet, but hey, they did bring that back in some form in Mafia III, and there's other more tantalizing stuff to unlock now that I've finished the story.

There's one detail I miss from the original Mafia that didn't make it here: Lucas Bertone's optional missions. It was nice to get new cars from that guy by doing him favors, some of which had unique objectives like crashing a hot car into the ocean just beyond the lighthouse, or taking a guy bleeding out in your car to a doctor, after which you get to see Lucas cleaning out the blood from the car as a freebie. In the remake, he just gives you photographs to hunt down hidden vehicles, which was a nice way to get you exploring the world without an objective marker, but it's such a waste to see Lucas sidelined like this, especially since I like that he's recast as a younger, shiftier mechanic now.

I can easily recommend this game to anyone who's itching for a great mobster story packaged in a fun third-person open world game in a gorgeously rendered 1930s American city. Hell, I'm gonna be crucified by some fans of the series for saying this, but this retelling of the original Mafia is even better to me than the fan favorite Mafia II was. Yeah, I said it. Sue me. The performances were stellar. The world-building adds to the tension and weight of Tommy's actions, from newspaper clippings to radio news broadcasts. The atmosphere of the most memorable levels are made better by this game's gorgeous weather effects and a skybox that's SO much better than ugly one we got in Mafia III. Mafia Definitive Edition feels to me like a culmination of everything that Hangar 13 learned from previous entries in the series, improving upon what made 2K Czech's games great, and learning from their own missteps in Mafia III. If there's ever going to be a Mafia IV, it has to be from them. I don't see it being made well by any other studio.

I take back what I said about New Bordeaux in my Mafia III review. I'd love to go back to the bayou in Lincoln's Drifter at some point. But I'll definitely be spending more time in this beautiful recreation of Lost Heaven. I was hooked on just driving around this city when I played the original Mafia. Now that it looks and plays this well? It's gonna be real hard to leave it again.

The first Mafia game isn’t a game that holds up well, or has stand the test of time beyond the concept of its missions and the narrative aspects of its overarching story. 

This remaster builds on this principle by maintaining and updating the graphical fidelity of the game while retaining most of the aspects of the story and above all else, the concepts and ideas of the original game’s missions. 

In turn, this remake also chooses to update the gameplay, adding multiple difficulty options that both provide the challenging experience from the original game, as well as a balanced and easier challenge more akin to the contemporary standards that players expect out of a game’s level of difficulty. 

This is a welcome addition as it is all of the different added upgrades to the visuals, Lost Haven is a beautifully recreated city based around Chicago, New York, and the San Francisco of the 1930’s, the city is brimming with detail, as I drove in the multiple missions of the game I could witness a strike outside of an auto shop, a sign departing my stay from the city as I neared the airport, and a fully functional set of bridges with even an area, in one mission -that remains optional-, where you take one of your companions to a brothel near the docks. 

There are also some pretty welcome additions, the game is fairly linear in its story using the open world more like a stage in which to present it, but there’s also the unlockable bonus mode “Free Ride” which serves as a sandbox open world mode allowing you to explore and play with complete liberty in the city. During the campaign and this additional mode, there are also period comics, from detective novels, to science fiction ones, they serve and contribute in creating the atmosphere of the time. On a later update after launch there was also an alternate visual mode added to Mafia; “The Noir Mode” as the name suggest, turns the picture into a black and white representation akin to classic gangster movies; thanks to the updated graphical fidelity in conjunction with this mode, this offers a unique way of playing through the campaign, truly enhancing in an alternate way both cutscenes and gameplay, capturing beautifully the atmosphere of the time and succeeding in the intentional, of making the game look -for the most part-, like a motion picture. 

If there are complaints for me, they arise with two aspects: one is the fact that when you shoot the enemies, they enter into a very exaggerated death animation that gives you the illusion you can keep damaging them, when in reality you can’t; if you try, your bullets will go right past them. My second complain also stems from the voice acting; you can get used to it (like I did) after a while, but at the beginning it was difficult for me to truly take the dialog seriously because of how exaggerated some of the accents were, especially the character of Paulie which is a fairly important character in the game. 

But like I said, this remake is an improvement on most levels, keeping what works (and still works from the original title) while updating it and adding more than just a visual upgrade to newcomers and past players alike. There might be some diehard fans that would always treasure the original experience above the one provided in this remake, but I personally couldn’t be happier with it.

[h1] Quick questions and answers [/h1]
Is the game good? 
- Yes
Is the game of the same quality or better than original?
- No

[h1] Review [/h1]
Well, the game is actually good. The graphic is really nice and devs didn't forget about us, Czechs, so they didn't forget about czech dub. 

At the start game looks like a copy with better graphics and with some minority tweaks. As longer as you play, you start discovering that game has some really annoying mechanics. I've been playing entire game on classic difficulty and I have to say that for example driving was really annoying. It's not RTS, simulation... honestly, I have no idea what that crap is. I just know it's really annoying and despite my experience in many driving games with different driving models, after 12 hours I wasn't able to get used to it. I wasn't able to predict movement of the car in some situations, sometimes the road felt like it was pure ice. However, it was annoying but I can't really say I dislike it. I honestly don't know, it was just really weird but I can't say it was nightmare and it flushed my joy from the game.

However another annoying thing really stabbed my enjoyment. And that's death screen. Like you wait every time about 5-8 seconds till you can reset your game to last checkpoint? And as bonus, that loading isn't fast enough too. I have fast computer and don't have issues while gaming but I still had to wait around 15 sec after every death to continue playing. And on classic difficulty you die a lot (unless you really tryhard it). That's really big disadvantage of this game.

Regarding story, it's almost the same as in original game, only the end is a bit weird, like triple camouflage of everything, it's more boring honestly and annoying, nothing more, nothing less... 

About gameplay I can't say in general anything really wrong, I expected this game to be trash but it really surprised me and it was a good game. However some parts were really boring and honestly, when you make remake of something, you should at least try to make it better. Jokes are funny and good but the old ones were better I think... Also some tweaks in gameplay and story are more annoying than helpful. For example streets all look almost the same, in the original game you are able to memorize most of the city without any issues on first play, here I had no idea where I am without map. In the end, you can't really say this game is horrible, but it isn't great either. Can't imagine I would buy this game for full price, it's not worth it.

I would rate it 6,5/10, as it's good and you can have fun and enjoy it, but in comparison with original it lacks a lot of ideas and maybe the feeling of entire situation? If you didn't play original game, it might be better for you and you will enjoy it more I guess. But my opinion is that original game had better atmosphere, idea and they did really good job in their year. This is almost like Chinese copy-paste with some tweaks. It's good but could be definitely better.

Now to the review...
There are a few bugs that while immersion killing, not game breaking:
1. [spoiler] if you lose the cop cars at the beginning mission, they will spawn right behind you when you break a barrier to continue the mission...[/spoiler]
2.  2 cut-scenes that had no audio at all, and I had to replay the chapter cut-scene just to see what the mission details were...
3.  killing enemies may or may not have them stuck to what ever they were next to when they died.  Many an enemy died floating in air, or leaning next to a wall standing up.  R.I.P.
4.  I did have graphics freeze on me during cut-scenes.  At first I thought they were for dramatic effect, but then the characters spoke.  I needed to use Task Manager to close the game, but starting the game up again it did put me back in the cut-scene, without having to replay a mission (so +1 for the auto saves).

The game does not care that you have no idea who these characters are.  There is no back story, except through the eyes of your character in flashback form and only so many years back.  This is the Mafia.  You do Mafia things, and if you aren't loyal, you stop doing Mafia things.  The voice acting, while passable, is definitely forced, and you can tell that some of the voice actors tried really hard to portray a gangster, but couldn't figure out what direction they wanted to go.  But some sold it well.
Also, a given in this type of game:  the character that stutters and seems like he never passed 4th grade.

I played in Noir mode, which is black and white for the entire game (should be an achievement).  The reviews talking about the video quality, my opinion is the designers probably wanted to replicate what a colorized version of a movie in the 30s would look like.  That's why I played it in BW.  I wanted to put myself in what 2023 me would watch on something made 90 years ago.
I definitely agree that the racing mission is one of the hardest missions (but I finished it in a spectacular fashion, as the 1st place guy wrecked on the final turn, and the 3rd place guy in an attempt to pass me slammed into him, and I split them down the middle and won).  But playing in classic mode, where if you reload you lose ammo, 4 hits from others you are dead, while head-shots are guarantee kills on enemies, body shots could be 5-10, the game by that definition is very hard, but it is definitely the way to play.  You can find the medkits, but in this mode your health drops like crazy.  Sure I got frustrated, a lot, but it was pleasure-filled once I knew I completed the mission.

I did feel that some of the aspects of the game weren't thought about as needing to be a necessity to play the game. Like, what is the point of having a garage, when they give you a car to use every time you start a mission? Unless it goes fast, they all drive the same.  The armory, unless the game wants you to talk to him, there is no reason to go there.  And where the 4th grader works on cars, unless again you need to see him there isn't a reason.  Many things could have been more, but it wasn't implemented very well. (by the way, because there isn't a backstory, you don't really find the need to care about a lot of the characters, besides yourself, and as I'm writing this review, many names have been forgotten, but this isn't a bad thing.  It's the Mafia after all.  Forgettable characters, to be replaced by others).

The one thing that does suck is that the collectibles are scattered throughout the map, in places you will not have been to in the story line.  I know this because I didn't complete those achievements, and [spoiler] in the mission where you rob the bank and drive Pauly out of there, where you end up has a collectible.  You see it, but after the cut-scene you are thrown to another part of the map, and unless you made notes, you won't find where you were with him.[/spoiler]  You will probably not want to play the game a second time to try to get these, unless you have the time to roam and really want those achievements.
With that, there really isn't a reason to play this game after you finish it.  There would be nothing new, except maybe to try new cars, or do the "lockpick" quest. ( I just busted the windows out of cars if I wanted to steal them).  Its just called free mode (roam) at that point, but I would just play another game, instead of driving around in a city with nothing to do.

All in all, I wish I saw and played this game when it first came out, but it holds itself well, and with all the profanity and violence [spoiler] what about the one with the tire iron on the street huh?? [/spoiler] I didn't regret playing this game now and am very much so looking forward to playing Mafia 2.  Some of the monologues I forgot I was playing a game and thought I was watching a old nostalgic movie.

yes, the game is worth it only for its story.

Story: 

you get to play as Tommy Angelo who's a typical cab driver on streets of Lost Heaven and finds his way through a mafia family, its a typical mafia story you get to see in movies but its a great one and its worth playing it. The settings is 1930 the whole vibe and environment to it is really great and feels good to be in it. The Cut scenes through out the story are great.

Gameplay:

in terms of gameplay this is not the game where you get skill tree and better upgrades as you progress through it's all about shooting which is closely tied in a same loop. However the engagements are pretty fun which makes the whole gunplay interesting and refreshing.

The missions has some variety like there are car chases, some stealth missions and sometimes you have to make your way out.

FreeRide Mode: 
it is unlocked after completing 1st mission, here you can play free ride missions which are 12 in total, you can do typical taxi missions, complete collections and explore the map of the game at your own pace.

Noire Mode: 
The game features a noire mode which is a old B/W filter its a nice touch and looks great as well.  

Graphics and Sound: 
The games phenomenal specially in night there are some visual glitches but nothing game breaking, i just love the way this game looks this is probably where it shines the most. 
The Voice acting is excellent as well, it feels like watching a mob movie.

Cons:

The game is purely dead in terms of open world factors, minimal to zero npc interaction, no interactive buildings, no side quests , no post campaign content and the worst is they have removed the radio music of OG MAFIA.


Final Thoughts:

the game is fairly short but enjoyable one, you can finish the game in about 10 hours, there are no side missions etc stuff there is separate mode for it if you wanna play those missions 12 in total. it looks great, has mission variety tightly focused on story. overall a fine game to look after.

Due to my incredibly busy schedule I did not have the time to experience MAFIA when it was originally released. When I saw it had been Remade/Remastered and was on sale I just couldn't resist.

I don't do a lot of reviews, however, this game deserves a review.

The game doesn't have a very complicated system to conduct combat. I found it very easy to beat the hell out of someone in a fist fight. As for guns there are pretty much four guns; Pistols, Tommy Guns, Shotguns and a Rifle. This is consistent with the period. Aiming the guns and shooting them is also not complicated. Some reviewers have commented  the pistols don't seem to hit their target accurately. Pistol accuracy in real life is most effective from 3-5 feet. As distance becomes greater pistols can become wildly inaccurate. The game reflects this in a very real way. My only complaint is when I obviously hit a target (evident from the targets reaction) two to three times and they are still standing and evading as if they didn't just take two bullets to the chest! 

Although the combat system isn't complicated I did find it to be extremely satisfying. 

So many games try to tell a story with cut scenes. Many of them fail to make the cut scenes blend with the game resulting in them feeling like a sideline story and not part of the game. MAFIA does an excellent job with the story. I feel like I'm in a Mafia movie! The creators did a great job of depicting the brutality of gang violence. Cut scenes, game play and story line all blend together to create a wonderful experience.

The infamous race: No one likes it. Myself included. How did I win? Over and over and over...because I refused to give up.

I read a lot of reviews from players having serious performance issues. I'm eighteen hours into the game and haven't experienced a single issue. TBH, my computer is a bit of a Frankenstein. It was a high end business computer that was never intended to receive upgrades due to the tower design, including the Motherboard. After some special orders from China to modify the Motherboard to upgrade the power supply and cannibalized parts from old computers, I ended up with a computer that runs games way above rated specs. I do not know why! I included my specs for reference. No pics as it looks like a junk yard dog with a lobotomy. :-)


Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-4790 CPU @ 3.60GHz   3.60 GHz
16.0 GB RAM
Windows 10 Pro/21H2
NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 6GB
TR2 RX 850W PS

Eski bir oyun olduğu için beraberinde getirdiği bir sürü hata ve günümüz teknolojisine göre oldukça eski ve rahatsız edici mekanikler ve oynanış yüzünden epey zorluk yaşadım ve sinir atakları geçirdim fakat hikayesinin iyi oluşu, çıkış yılına göre gerçekçiliği yansıtabilmesi ve anlatmak istediği hikayenin ağırlığını iyi verebilmesi oldukça tatmin ediciydi. Gerçekten keyif alınarak oynanabilecek bir konsept, hikaye ve atmosfer sunabilmişti. Günümüze uyarlanırsa nasıl olabilir diye düşünüyordum ve bunun haberini aldığımda heyecanlanmıştım. Bir kaç saat oynadıktan sonra beceremediklerini görebildim. Eski oyuna nazaran bütün havasını mahvetmişler. Hikayenin ve oyunun hiç bir havası kalmamış. Ne ağırlığı ne ne de kasveti kalmış. Silah ve dövüş mekaniği berbat. Ateşlediğiniz silahın su tabancasından farkı yok. Düşmanların hasar almaya verdiği tepki inanılmaz kötü ve terminatör gibi yürüyebilmeleri gülünç. Ekstra ekledikleri sahneler ve diyaloglar bazı noktalarda çok sırıtıyor. Karakter modellemelerini pek beğenmedim. Grafikler orta-alt denilebilir. Bazı karakterleri Hollywood etkisiyle kişiliklerini hafifletmişler ve ağırlıklarını kaybettirmişler. Grafik ve UI güncellenmiş ekstra bir kaç ekleme yapılmış güzelce makyajlanmış ve satışa çıkarılmış. İlk versiyonunda olan bir kaç can sıkıcı şeyleri çıkarmışlar fakat beraberinde iyi olan bir kaç noktayıda bu versiyonda elemişler. Ilk oyunu modlasanız yine böyle birşey çıkarmış ortaya.

Aim assist only works when it chooses to so I am constantly getting moved back to checkpoints that are further back than they should be, and to make things worse there is no first person mode to make knowing where you are shooting just a little bit more manageable. Overall there would be a decent game here if it were a crazy taxi remake, but until there are some serious changes to the core game play this is not a fluid game. 6/10

"I recently played Mafia: Definitive Edition and I have to say, I was thoroughly impressed. From the moment I started playing, I was drawn into the world of Lost Heaven, and the characters and story kept me hooked until the very end. The graphics are stunning, with a level of detail that brings the 1930s to life in a way that is both beautiful and immersive. The voice acting is top-notch, and the music sets the perfect tone for each scene.

One thing I particularly appreciated about the game was the attention to detail in the recreation of the era. The cars, clothing, and architecture all felt authentic, and it was clear that a lot of care was taken to make sure the player felt like they were really living in that time period.

The gameplay is smooth and satisfying, with a mix of action and puzzle-solving that keeps things interesting. The missions are well designed, with just the right level of challenge, and the controls are intuitive and responsive.

Overall, I would highly recommend Mafia: Definitive Edition to anyone who is a fan of the original game or who is looking for a well-crafted, immersive crime drama. It's a must-play for anyone who loves action-adventure games or who wants to experience a piece of gaming history. 5 stars!"

[h1]Premise[/h1]
It's a movie game (interactive film). The main story consists of chapters of an up-and-comer mafioso's life in a mafia family, throughout the 1930s. Post story there's the "Free Ride" mode featuring taxi fares, track races and a series of fun extra missions accessed through notes left around the safehouse by a mysterious figure.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You're first introduced to driving, which is bad but you slowly get used to it until the race mission, which forces you to become a good driver through failing. What you won't be told is there's a fuel gauge that you should always keep track of when driving personal cars. Refilling is done manually by driving to gas stations and if you run out, your car becomes useless until you refill it. There's also two radio stations featuring newscasts and songs of that era. Combat is mostly shooting / peeking from cover, throwables and the infrequent shooting while driving. Cars are easily destroyed by bullets. While the map is surrounded by docks and features an airport, planes  and boats aren't accessible. There's no swimming, but neither is there a need for it. The game's design shows its age by lacking any form of fast travel.

[h1]Completion[/h1]
One achievement requires the story to be completed on the highest difficulty, "classic", and without ever changing it, which took me 14 hours at an average pace. There are varying collectables spread separately across both story and free ride and combined with the lack of fast travel it really drags out the collectathon to over 10 hours. It's fine to miss them during the story as to not break immersion. After finishing the story, chapters can be replayed on a lower difficulty and you're not required to recomplete them. Quitting right after picking up a collectable will save it. As for completion unrelated to Steam achievements, Carcyclopedia's car counter is bugged (52/53) because of an unobtainable car cut from the game, but still existing in the files. There's also the Chicago Pack DLC which doesn't come with the game but can be picked up from resellers for about 1 euro.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
It's an old classic, beautifully remade into an immersive experience. While lacking any in-depth systems, it masters it's theme, storytelling and visuals.

There are quite a few issues with this game in the technical department due to HANGER13.
The game freezes a lot. Some forums said to play in windowed mode which didn't really help at all. 
Although the game feels alive, the AI don't really react to the player. They're just living their life as if you don't really exist. 

Example: AI walk out in front of cars willy nilly. Cars pull out in front of the player all the time. Sometimes cars just stop moving while on the road, where they should be mobile. Same goes for the trams. 

I think the voice acting is an upscale of the original? I think? Anyway, some scenes-particularly early in the game- the audio is awful, I don't know what happened but it sounds hella decompressed and atrocious. 

Leafs can flow through the characters body. 

Objects don't render in correctly in some cases. 

This is all down to Hanger 13, really. I found similar issues in Mafia 3, too. At least in Mafia Definitive Edition, the cops will actually recognize when you break the law... unlike in Mafia 3 where the cops are literally just an image walking around the map with no commands at all. 

Overall, it's a really good game. I was going to play the original eventually, but, glad I got the chance to play the remake. Just... it has a fair few flaws but it can be overlooked. This is a remake / remaster of a 2002 game, which explains a lot of things. The original game was released right after GTA 3, which, of course, elicited comparisons between both titles, which was a bit unfair, given the different scopes. GTA 3 was an open-world game (one of the first, and certainly the most popular at the time), while Mafia was more story-driven and completely linear. I played de OG at the time, and had fun with it, but I never though it was on the same level as GTA.

For starters, let's say that Mafia Definitive Edition is a good game, featuring beautiful graphics and a very nice rendition of a 1930's American big city. The atmosphere is very well done, and story is well told, although a bit bland by today's standards. The presentation is definitely good, but the game lacks more depth. Gameplay, for example, suffers from decision of making a linear game. It feels like there's wasted potential here, with a very big city, but not a lot to see or visit. There is a free roaming mode, but it definitely doesn't add sufficiently to content.

I recommend the game at a discount, but know what you're getting into, as it has a different scope from GTA games.

The game consists of mostly driving and shooting with a few stealth segments. Nothing really amazing that makes any of those three things stand out, but it's all pretty polished and refined. I played on hard difficulty and I did die quite a bit, but never to bugs or glitches or anything like that.

Mafia is a masterpiece, it's a story of greed, love, and betrayal and will have you captivated the whole entire time. Of course the game is about the mafia and in the city of Lost Haven their are two major bosses that own the city Don Salieri and Don Morello. The two dons were childhood friends working under Don Peppone's rule but Morello wanted more power so he killed the Don and split the city into two different factions Salieri's Faction and his faction. In this game you work for Salieri and his family who are the underdog gang. Even though the city was "split up evenly" Morello pretty much has a full grasp around the city, paying off cops and politicians so he can do whatever he wants. This man literally beat up one of his most profitable fighters with a wrench in the middle of the street and the cops didn't even bat an eye. Morello is such a cool antagonist in this game and I like how he is the complete opposite of Salieri in the since that he is always getting angry and beating people to death with his strength while Salieri always stays composed having some sort of strategy. You (the player) play as Tommy Angelo a cab driver who is simply just driving around normal people until suddenly two of Salieri's men Sam and Paulie put a gun to your head and you aid them in escaping Morello's men. Don Salieri is very pleased with you for this and you join his family. The game only picks up from here and I highly suggest you play it everything from the antagonist to the story is super good, god damn this game slaps. The gameplay plays just like gta or saints row classic hide behind something shoot guys or drive after man escaping (like gta 5 with the stolen boat) this may sound lame but Mafia Definitive Edition actually makes this fun and does very unique things. For example in the 5th mission "Fairplay" you get to race in 1940s race cars and zoom at super sonic speeds (yes this mission is kinda terrible because its hard to win but it's still unique). Overall Mafia 8/10 very very very very good video game and an enjoyable experience. *SPOLIERS* Now my favorite mission in the game is Bon Appétit what a fire mission, eating with Don Salieri when the whole place suddenly gets shot down in blazing gunfire then after you kill all Morello's men you pull up on the man who snitches on you and smash his head like a watermelon starting a war between the Salieri family and the Morello family. Best mission by far maybe one of my favorite video game missions of all time.

Mini Plot details: You play as Tommy Angelo a former Cab driver who enters the Mafia life by accident. He is held at gunpoint one night while waiting for a fare and is forced to outrun fellow gang members.

Pro's:
Graphics: The graphics are a real treat, the game was remade from the ground up with better lighting, physics, cars, sounds, etc. Although it's 100 percent different than the original you can still feel a sense of familiar , while driving throughout the new and improved Lost Heaven.

Sounds: The memorable track from the original Mafia makes it triumphant return with a new score this time around. I for one usually had the music off so i can't really quote on the music all too well.

Plot: The plot from the original is well in tact actually. You can almost play both games at the exact same time and both would play out almost the same minus different cut-scenes at certain points.

Free Ride mode: In Free Ride mode, Tommy starts at Salieri's Bar with access to his garage, wardrobe, and armory. There are options to change the time of day and weather. Free Ride mode unlocks after completing An Offer You Can't Refuse. 

There are 12 phone booth missions in Free Ride. They are activated by reading the notes in Salieri's Bar. After completing the first mission, additional ones will become available as you progress through the game. Missions are given by Herbert Baskerville, and completing each one awards a vehicle, weapon, or outfit. These end game contents are pretty much fun and challenging at the same time.

Cons: Length: The plot itself is around 10/12 hours maybe. Right when you get nice and comfortable with the game and you really start to enjoy yourself the damn credits roll. Also it's a linear story so it's chapter after chapter. This isn't a GTA game where you go to mission to mission in your own leisure. 

This game still gets a 10 out of 10, the pacing itself was good i just wish it was at least another 10 hours longer.

As someone who never played the original (didn't even know there was one until I read the reviews), I will say this game is probably best experienced for nostalgic purposes only. I will start by saying that the storytelling, music, and voice acting really give you an immersive 1930s experience. My problem, however, is there was nothing else keeping me engaged (you meet the boss, do the jobs he gives you, you watch the plot thicken, and repeat). There's nothing urging me to explore, there are no choices I can make besides finding random dialog to listen to, and there is no growth or reward for playing the game - it's just a story. I feel like I could watch someone else play and not miss out on anything, and tbh I probably will just to know how the story ends, but overall this was boring to play for me. It is a straightforward game that some may appreciate more than me, but I was hoping for more.

I never played the original Mafia, although I did beat both 2 and 3 when they came out. Seeing this remake on sale, I decided to pick it up. I am over halfway through the game right now, and I can tell that this game remains authentic and faithful to the original. The graphical fidelity is top-notch, and this truly helps make the experience worthwhile.

Yet, my primary concern with this remake is that it is simply not well-optimized. The highs and lows with regard to FPS are all over the place, and often, downright awful. I have a damn good build, I'm VERY WELL OVER the suggested specs, and I still can find myself in single-digit frames. OOF.

Then there's the racing segment. About 2 hours into this narrative experience, you're forced to deal with an INCREDIBLY frustrating and hamfisted racing segment. I could complain about this for hours, but I respect the developers for staying true to the original game's level of difficulty here. Regardless, this segment still sucks. BAD.

So far, I'd give this remake a solid 7 or 8 out of 10, due to performance issues. If you get it on sale like me, it makes the technical difficulties all the more bearable.

TLDR; if you like video games as an art form, I would recommend it. If you play video games because you want to have 'fun', there are definitely better games. 

This is a fairly short game, and I definitely cannot recommend it to everyone. So first I will list negatives. The gameplay, while not unfinished, is bland. It is a very typical cover shooter with only about 4 guns to choose from at any given time. Headshots instantly kill enemies, so action consists of moving to cover, shooting 3 or 4 guys in the head, and then moving and repeating. Melee fighting is fine, but also very boring. Driving is pretty good, very little bugs, but not on the level of GTA V. Also, most of the driving is just going from one place to another with no shooting or chases. When the facial animations screw up it is hilariously bad. Replayability is low, unless you are an achievement collector.

Now to the good stuff. This game is close to a Picasso painting or a Mozart concert in that it is put together as an art piece. From the beginning the way that the story is told hooks you with the animation quality on the prerendered cutscenes being some of the best I've ever seen. Everyone's face perfectly matches their emotion and changes with the conversation in a subtle but noticeable way. These cutscenes do not drop in quality throughout the whole game. The voice acting is generally amazing, you can really tell the level of communication between the actors and animators was spot on. 

The characters are incredibly well-developed, and you really get to learn about each of them. They were stereotypical for 'Italian mobsters' but also had a personal flare that made them interesting. The dialogue is really well written throughout the entire game, to the point where even the side conversations between NPCs that don't even have names is worth listening to.

Music and sound design in this game are perfect. The radio quality sounds as though it were from the 1930's, and the level of detail is such that the radio fades when you go to low service areas. Speaking of detail, they even included the Wilhelm scream in one of the opening cutscenes. The radio music is all big band, jazz and blues which really adds to the immersion factor of the game. I would sometimes just stop the game to sit in the car, look at the city and listen to the music, which is in my opinion the sign of a good open world.

The way they also tell another real historical story in the background of the main story is also fascinating. Just by using radio broadcasts and a few lines in the main story they are able to summarize the Great Depression, its instigating factors, and the way that it influenced the American political system and allowed organized crime to flourish. They used enough real world stories to add immersion to the main storyline and give history fans more to explore in the open world.

All in all, my enjoyment level reminded me a lot of Red Dead Redemption 2 in its main story. If you play video games for the story, or are just a history fan in general, you won't be disappointed.

-NO SPOILERS-
Mafia: DE is really interesting, it brings back the original and enjoyable parts from the 18 year old Mafia 1 and adds more depth to the story, voice acting, gameplay and of course graphics. The game looks stunning (and thus requires you to have a decent PC to get good frames). I'm Running the game on 2k resolution with around stable 90fps using a good pc build, RTX3060. The animations in certain combat scenarios had it's fair share of criticism but I do not think it is that bad. The soundtrack is awesome and is composed by Jesse Harlin, who also composed the OST's for Mafia 3 (Which was one of the rare great things in that game). The story is, well, *almost* the same with Mafia 1 but I should say that there are more lore pieces and backstories and most importantly depth. The acting, mo-cap included, is insanely good. Voice acting is outta this world. The gun play is a bit too close to Mafia 3's (because of the same engine), however both the fighting and driving shapeshifts if you play the game on classic mode (Which I say you should give it a go altho' it may be hard). Driving is really unique (and has it's own challenges) as you will be driving Late 20's to Late 30's cars which come with no ABS, no Stability Control and no Traction Control (They also use bike wheels so good luck lol). The challenge is fun. There are some really good community made mods that you can download to further enhance your gameplay both in the story mode and in Freeride*

*Let's talk a little about Freeride

Freeride allows you to roam around the world that Hangar 13 team re-created, it is simple but beautiful. The main game, although has an open-world, mostly gets you places in linear story-style. Think of GTA but instead of going to the missions you have cutscenes and you get right into the story and next chapter. This is fine but if you want to travel the world, the game allows you that in a seperate from story-mode "Freeride". This is also an old mode in Mafia 1 that made a return. For some the freeride is totally useless and has no meaning but I disagree, especially with the mods that further enhance the mode itself (also there are minigames-challenges in vanilla freeride that can unlock secret cars, again a throwback to the original game's "freeride extreme" mode).

So, this game really deserves the title "Definitive Edition" as it sticks to the original feeling of the Mafia series, and tributes the original game, plus adds a lot on it. Graphics are great and the game feels smooth.

9/10, I have no regrets Pre-Ordering (2020)

The original Mafia: City of Lost Heaven is one of my favourite games of all time. It came at a time around the launch of GTA VC while technically superior in every way with a great cast and writing. I was hesitant to try the Remake, but today I got it on a sale to give it a try and I was shocked at some of the changes they made. 

The original came out a long time ago so I can understand the changes to the character's faces, even though personally I don't like them at all. Original had some distinction between the faces of the major characters like Sam and Paulie, while in this game they look almost the same to me. The voice acting is another area which new remake let me down. The original was A tier, this is B tier at best with a different direction and tone to the characters which I do not like. The writing is even changed to the point the remake makes the characters come off very different and changes to the point it does not feel like the original game anymore. 

Finally the game itself is simplified and dumed down. Cars have arcade physics which makes them feel like they have no heft to them like they did, there is almost no repercussion to speeding and the animations are also simplified and copied from Mafia 3 (which were terrible btw). Car chases were thrilling in the original because you have to use your skills to evade the chasers, pick roads which would allow you to speed up because the cars were slower back then. Over here,  you simply drive through a marker and a small cutscene maps and the chaser crashes into a roadblock. 

Granted this is a remake, however the a good remake should honor the original vision of the game and improve on the aspects which needs updating like visuals and quality of life. However, this game touched way too many things which did not need changing at all. Original is a fantastic game still, with some assists with mods, it is a much better option than this game.

Gripping story. This game has a large emphasis on driving! If you are one who said to yourself "You know, Mafia 2 was cool but there just wasn't enough cruising" this game is for you. There is an option to skip drives that you can select before beginning the campaign which mitigates this if you're not big on that. I would encourage you not to skip most of the drives as there is usually conversation that is either just funny to listen to, provides context for the task at hand, or gives crucial details on how the given job is to be conducted. All in all, 12 hours of fantastic story is enough for me to say it's worth it.

Mafia is a great remake of a classic title which tells a great story with fun, cinematic gameplay. While it may be more hand holding and long. uneventful driving sequences it still contains a really enjoyable crime game set in the golden years of American gangsters.

PRO
- The story is great of the criminal life of Tommy Angelo. You meet some great characters and really feel for them as things just get deeper and deeper in the life.
- Gun play and action sequences all feel really fun.
- There's very little filler (aside from driving) so each mission has a purpose and you're thrown right in.
- The ending is made better that connects it to Mafia II.
- The game itself looks amazing and the cutscenes look really, really nice.
- Soundtrack has that 1930s feel which works perfectly.
- It feels very cinematic.

NEUTRAL
- If you don't want to drive around all the time you can skip the uneventful driving sequences. This will however cut your game time down by about 30-40%.
- There's nothing else to really do besides the main game, free roam is just driving round the city and collecting cars. For me that's pretty useless so the main game is all there is.

CON
- It is unclear sometimes of what you actually need to do. E.g. I had to stop a guy from escaping to his hideout but I couldn't shoot his car otherwise it would explode but no matter how many times I rammed him he always escaped.
- I got a "You died" game over screen after a cut scene where I had already finished the mission so there's some odd bugs.
- The infamous race segment is still terrible and it doesn't help that your car can get bounced around with light taps on other objects.

If you're a fan of crime based games or just a good story then this is definately one to play. I wouldn't say it's worth the money at full price as you'll have done it in 10 hours or less but grabbing it on a sale (which it is quite often) is your best bet.

First time play the mafia franchise, so here was my review
Pros : 
•	starting from the story I really like that, depicting the 80s era mafia with a very thick culture and a very striking vintage atmosphere
•	the world is very beautiful, really describes life in the combined era of chicago and new york in the 1900s.
•	tommy angelo the main character really describes people who lived in that era, he was very brave and had his own ideals. he is also loyal to friends and superiors which depicts a very strong against the mafia family
•	the graphics in this world are also very beautiful, neon lights in every capital city, vintage vehicles that pass by, rainfall and twilight are very beautiful, between morning and night which are very beautiful and the reflections of water on the beautiful streets make me feel at home around the city use a car
•	vehicles of that era are also described accurately in this game, where the weight and torque are very different in this era. which is very impressive for depicting cars in the vintage mafia era
•	the voice filling is very good and detailed, the storytelling and talking from one character to another is very pleasant to listen to and easy to understand
•	The cinematic of every scene in this game is also very good and feels like a mafia movie
•	the ending is satisfying enough to close Tommy's story as a retired mafia

cons : 
•	Of the many good remakes of this game, the shooting battles are actually really bad. the shots in this game are very clunky like games in 2010 and down not like modern games. then the melee fighting mechanism is also very clunky, there is no satisfying feeling to hit, the stealth killing animation is also very boring and not varied
•	This open world game should provide a lot of side activities, not just the main mission, I'm surprised I only do the main mission and there are no side missions or other activities as a break to take time after the main mission
•	healing and health bars on characters and vehicles are also very low, I don't understand why a very low health bar is given, especially for characters where healing is in random places
conclusion : this game is very good and beautiful, there are lots of good spots and stories that describe the mafia of that era. the vehicles and atmosphere are very thick with the 80s era, unfortunately there are some deficiencies that are quite contrasting in the gameplay mechanics such as fighting and shooting.

Yes, this is a remake from the ground up. Not a "re-imagining" or a "remaster", as those things have developed overlapping (and outright wrong) definitions over time. 

The script is nearly identical to to original, and everything looks amazing. So, if you enjoyed the story & suspense of that game, and you're willing to experience it again with improved graphics and handling tweaks, you'll like this game.

However; if you're new to Mafia, and looking for an open world game like GTA set in the 1930's, you might be disappointed.  Yes, there is a beautiful open world brought to life in the creation of Lost Heaven, but there really is no need to explore. In fact, I believe you can choose to skip any non mission essential driving portions of the game altogether. This is kind of a shame, because the map is beautiful, and it looks as though a lot of work went into the overall design.

The real strength of this game is it's narrative and presentation. It's like a mobster movie that you play out and interact with a little. Much like a movie, there's no alternate endings or events. Decisions do not have an effect on the outcome, there aren't any side quests or activities, or any RPG elements like upgrading or leveling up. Some might see this as "bare bones" relative to other games but, for me, it's a breath of fresh air.
It's a strictly linear story based game.  I like that.

So, if you want to play this game for the story, do it, you will love it. But if you want to enjoy a driver/shooter game, well, Mafia just does not meet today's standard.

I've been a big fan of the Mafia franchise since the original Mafia released in 2001. Mafia II was amazing, and Mafia III had a great story, but the first Mafia was always my favourite release. Set right in the middle of Prohibition and the rise of the Italian Mafia, everything about the game appealed to me as a huge history buff; I can recall spending hours driving around Lost Heaven taking in the sights, and beating the spectacular campaign over and over again. I had long hoped that one day this gem of a game would get a remaster, and when I heard the news of Hangar 13 remaking it, I was elated.

Hangar 13 really outdid themselves here, as this remake truly is accurate in replicating the original in almost every way. Not only did they keep everything that made the original a unique, unforgettable experience, they brought the city of New Heaven to life in ways one could only dream of back in 2001. The map is filled with historically accurate details that were lacking in the original due to hardware limitations, and while driving through the city, you'll see busy streets brimming with beautiful classic cars and trucks, and sidewalks full of people and vendors going about their daily life. The graphics have also been completely overhauled utilizing the Mafia 3 engine, improving every visual aspect of the original game above and beyond what was capable in the original. Dynamic lighting with accurate reflections, shadows, and god rays, high-quality textures, better anti-aliasing; everything comes together to create a truly believable, living, breathing city of the 1930's.

Despite the all-around improvements in every area of the game, I would be lying if I said this game was completely faithful to the first game. Not quite a 1:1 recreation, subtle changes have been made in many areas, which really isn't a big deal overall, but someone who has played both titles would absolutely notice. 
-The original voice actors are gone, which was quite a disappointment to myself and many others on the first playthrough. The original voice actors are simply iconic to me, and while the new ones are great, I can't help but miss the old ones.
-Quite a few cars are missing from the lineup, limiting the variety of vehicles that can be found on the street at any given point in the storyline or in Free Ride. Not a huge deal, but as someone who truly loves classic cars, I do wish they included every vehicle available.
-Some missions are slightly altered. In most cases this was done to improve the flow of the story, but some alterations I would prefer to be left out.
There are more changes, but I feel that these are the biggest ones to me that I find to break from the first game in any big way.

All in all, this is a great way to experience the beauty and tragedy of Thomas Angelo's story, and that of the city of Lost Heaven. I would definitely recommend playing the original first, but this is a great way to get that same experience in a modernized fashion.

I've played the original many times and it was a very very good game. Compelling story, good gameplay, beautiful graphics for that time and so on. The remake does the original game justice by capturing most of what made the original game. But not all. The new visuals of the characters are good, but they are a bit to far from the originals. The don is not really a nice looking older guys anymore, but more the typical mafia boss. Same for Sam and Pauli (who'm I had trouble recognizing from one another for the first few scenes). So for someone who played the original a lot and has a good memory of how they looked, it's a bit annoying they didn't keep the characters closer to the originals.

Story and missions wise, those are still the same (mostly, apart from some small differences from the original) and are still fun to play and interesting to play. Gunplay is good, driving is a bit easier than in the original and so on. They modernized the game further by having very good cover mechanics that really work well and are fun to play with (all though it makes things a bit to easy i think).

There are however some things that were cut. The drives home after a mission, the fact that you had to learn to boost certain cars and in doing so you could make your car collection bigger. I mean, you can still do that, but the little side missions are not present anymore. The fact you could drive around in the city much more is gone now (don't stray to far during a mission or you fail after 10 seconds). The chat with Ralphy is mostly gone.  And with that the incentive to drive around town, find a better car for the garage, so you have a good car to drive during your future missions. Is that bad... not really, but I did enjoy those things in the original. It made the map feel more alive, it made it so you saw more of the city itself and it made it feel like you had a life in between the missions.

So all in all it's a fun and good game to play. I really enjoyed it, even with the shorter missions (over in 12 hour) since you don't have to drive home anymore.

Mafia: Definitive Edition is a remake of the classic 2002 Mafia game released for the current consoles and PC. The game continues the storyline of the original and takes the player to the city of Lost Heaven, a fictional town in 1930s America.

In Mafia: Definitive Edition, the player takes on the role of the protagonist Tommy Angelo, a humble taxi driver who accidentally gets involved in the Mafia's criminal activities. The action of the game is characterized by a gripping storyline that draws the player in from the start.

Mafia: Definitive Edition gameplay is extremely realistic and detailed. The city of Lost Heaven has been recreated with great attention to detail and offers the player an authentic atmosphere reminiscent of the films of the 1930s. The characters are well thought out and have depth and personality. The game's driving physics are also impressive and feel realistic.

A special highlight of Mafia: Definitive Edition are the action-packed and exciting missions that involve the player in various criminal activities. Whether it's transporting money or taking out opposing gangsters, there's always something to do and the missions are varied and challenging.

All in all, Mafia: Definitive Edition is a successful remake of the classic mafia game, which takes up the strengths of the original and has optimized it for the current consoles and PCs. The realistic city of Lost Heaven, the gripping storyline and the action-packed missions make the game a must for fans of the genre as well as for those looking for a realistic and exciting action-adventure.

[list]
[*] Beautiful open world and characters

[*] Able to change certain aspects of the game (Police response and player driving methods)
[/list]

[b] CONS [/b]
[list]

[*] Melee combat
[/list]

Mafia: Definitive Editon is a mob story delivered into the player's hands. Find yourself immersed in the 1930s prohibition era where the two station radio plays while you make your drive from point A to B. The structure and the missions of the game are linear. This mob story is the creme de la creme, but it is worth the ride. See the life of Tommy Angelo, from driving a cab to driving the Mafia. 

This game is about story and atmosphere. Mainly, the player will be completing missions and driving from point A to B. Shooting can be wonky at times, but it fits the aesthetic of the game. Melee combat is clunky and probably the most disliked aspect of the game. Collectibles can be found throughout the world and even during missions, but to gain them all, the player might use the Free Ride mode of the game to freely explore the open world and collect.
For the amount of driving there is in the game, that means driving has to work. Luckily, the driving in this game is solid when you factor in what type of model and year the cars are from. 
The game has a phenomenal checkpoint system that resumes the player where ever their last played story beat is. The player is able to make the tale as easy or hard as they would like with difficulties ranging from Easy to Classic. The police response can be changed as well as driving methods and modes. For example, police can attempt to stop the player when they cause trouble, or they can make more of an effort for the player if they are not following traffic laws (Running red lights, stop signs, speeding, or driving on the wrong side of the road). The player can decide if an automatic or manual transmission is preferred when driving and if simulated driving is more natural than an arcade-y feel.

Immerse yourself in this 10 hour ride and learn, Family is Everything.

I'm on to Mafia II and having a harder time connecting with everything there but it is still a good enough continuation of the Mafia story to keep me going. With Mafia II, though, I actually feel as though I want to explore more of the city/town before/after a mission and possibly once I'm done with that game. It feels, in a way, more inviting of things to find out and explore to me.

Was super excited to play this again. Visually astounding. Racing mission is just about if not more cancerous than it was back in 2002. Why they changed parts of this but left he racing? We'll never know. Maybe it's easier with a controller but I am once again replaying a insignificant part of this game over and over just to see the rest of it.

This is one of the best games that money can buy. I personally do not usually play a game twice, especially 3 times. Same as movies and TV shows. I watch them once and once that element of surprise has been compromised, I'm done...
But this game is different. One simply cannot take it bit of detail in one go. There's always something different that'll amaze me about this game with each time I play through it... The conversations taking place between people just walking through town, The girl dancing to the music off in the corner of the room during a party, or that man running to take shelter as it starts to rain.. These things are MEANT to be over-looked just to further push the realism of the atmosphere. This game humbles me like no other game ever has. Not all will agree, but It's what I consider to be a masterpiece. I will be playing this game again, again, and again.
Unfortunately, the same cannot be said about Mafia 2 or 3, but we haven't got that time to go there.

I played this game originally on PS4 and on the PC release there is a problem with clothing clipping at certain camera angles.

I also can't tell a difference between high and low settings. This is a pretty alright remake, but fumbling the PC release leaves a bad taste in my mouth for this version. This is my personal gripe but I don't like the Mafia 3 engine AT ALL. The gunplay feels sluggish in this game. Not really a fault of the game, just a minor complaint from me.
